that your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to remove 53 Pharmaceutical drugs from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme including the best available for the treatment of high blood pressure, cancer, epilepsy, high cholesterol and uneven heartbeat-and place them for cost saving reasons only on a special list requiring Authority from a Canberra bureaucrat; and,

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cross Mr M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I present the Committee's report entitled Personnel Wastage in the Australian Defence Force, incorporating a dissenting report, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's 1987 policy information paper, The Defence of Australia, identified the men and women of the Australian Defence Force (ADF) as the Defence Force's most valuable asset and a vital resource in the security of Australia. It follows, therefore, that personnel wastage-that is, loss rates-which exceed a certain numerical and qualitative level will be inimical to the national defence effort.

SPEECH.PARA: Given that wastage rates in the ADF have for several years significantly exceeded historical levels, this report by the Joint Committee is topical and important. The inquiry attracted a great deal of service, public, academic and media interest. The Committee received 226 written submissions, compared to 35 and 26 respectively for the Committee's preceding two inquiries into defence matters. Public hearings and meetings were held in many different localities across Australia. Overall, more than 4,000 pages of evidence were collected. Committee members found that throughout the ADF service men and women were keenly aware of the personnel wastage issue, usually held an opinion on the subject, and were keen to discuss it.

Throughout the course of the inquiry Committee members were fully aware that personnel wastage is the most pressing matter facing the Defence Force. It is an issue which requires prompt but at the same time considered resolution.

In order to achieve that end, many individuals have worked with considerable dedication over the past 12 months. We would like to acknowledge their contribution and express our thanks. As Chairman of the Defence Subcommittee I would like to record my appreciation of the efforts of my Subcommittee colleagues who, between them, spent hundreds of hours working on what has been a most demanding inquiry. We would also like to thank those who presented evidence and submissions; in particular, the cooperation of the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly), the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) and the Chief of the Defence Force was appreciated. The Subcommittee wishes to acknowledge the contribution made by our staff, in particular, our secretary Mr Alan Stephens, and word processor operator Ms Kylie Freer. We are also indebted to the main Committee, its Chairman, the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney) and secretary, Mr Peter Gibson.

Before turning to the Committee's main findings, I believe it is important to comment first on the nature of this inquiry and, second, on the higher management of the Defence Force. The subject matter has made this a difficult inquiry. Throughout its deliberations the Committee has been aware of the fact that there is a persistent negative overtone inherent in the topic. If people are asked what is wrong with their organisation and why they are leaving it, that is precisely the kind of information they will provide. They are unlikely to say much about the positive aspects of their employment. Because of the terms of reference, this report, unavoidably, is a critical examination of defence personnel management. We believe that is proper, as the question of wastage rates in the ADF has been of concern to this Committee for some years. The very fact that we accepted the subject for inquiry is indicative of widespread public concern. The Committee also believes that while at a superficial level the inquiry may appear to have been a somewhat negative process, it has been necessary and, in the long term, will be of significant benefit to the ADF and Government.

Personnel wastage has been the subject of considerable media attention. Indeed, the extent of that attention may even have contributed to wastage. This inquiry has opened up a vexed and contentious issue. In the long term that process will be in the best interests of the ADF. Because of the critical nature of the reference, Committee members wish emphatically to place on record their respect for the Australian Defence Force and its members. As an organisation, the ADF has attractions which few others can match. It offers comradeship, a sense of adventure and opportunities to develop both leadership and specialist skills. Above all, it has a compelling ethos of service. During our visits to many ADF establishments and in discussions with thousands of service men and women, we were continually aware of the high quality and commitment of those people. The Committee's report should be read with those admirable features of the ADF and its members clearly in mind.

As far as the higher management and direction of the Defence Force is concerned, several important points must be made. In the form of the 1987 White Paper the ADF has, for the first time in decades, a logical and coherent policy guidance document against which Force development can be directed and assessed. That document has been widely endorsed within the defence community. The central role played by the present Minister for Defence in the development and implementation of that policy deserves the high praise which it has attracted. The Joint Committee supports the re-equipment of the Australian Defence Force as detailed in the White Paper.

Since mid-1987 the Minister and the Australian Defence Force have been supported by an energetic and committed Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. Again, it is widely accepted that without her untiring efforts many of the conditions of service improvements which have been effected in the past 12 months simply would not have happened. Those are, briefly, the major positive aspects of recent higher defence management. I believe it is most important to note that they have taken place not only against a background of years of benign neglect of our Defence Force by previous governments but also during what is currently a period of extreme financial constraint.

I should now like to turn to the Committee's major findings. Like all other government activities, defence must compete for a finite pool of resources. Within the defence vote there is intense competition for a limited number of dollars. Personnel costs must be evaluated against bids for capital equipment, capital facilities, operating costs, defence cooperation programs, and so on.

Senior management must decide whether at a particular time one or more functions can perhaps be reduced to a level which may be below the historical average. Such decisions should be taken only after a rigorous appraisal of Australia's strategic circumstances and should be consistent with the broader long term interests of national security.

It might be argued that if Australia's defence managers consider that a particular wastage rate is acceptable within the context of our strategic circumstances and broader defence planning then, whatever that rate may be, there is no problem. Such an argument would be facile, for while statistics are an essential management tool, the examination of mere numbers is not in itself sufficient. Any worthwhile analysis of wastage must come to grips with the more subjective but vital factors of defence force quality and effectiveness. A central issue there is the pattern of wastage, that is, who is leaving and when. It is also important to remember that the lead time to replace a highly skilled and trained individual can be at least as long as that required to introduce into service an item of capital equipment. A controlled, manageable personnel separation rate is essential if the ADF's operational capability is to be maintained at the necessary standard.

Against that background and after careful consideration of a great deal of evidence, the Committee concluded that the present level of wastage in the ADF is substantially too high and has been so for some time. Further, there has been a clear and consistent trend towards this situation for several years. The Committee does not support the Department of Defence's conclusion that wastage is of concern only in some specific specialist areas. That kind of assessment pays insufficient attention to the qualitative aspects of wastage as well as understating the overall effect and extent of numerical losses. Our assessment is that there is cause for concern across a wide range of ranks and skills. The extent and the magnitude of wastage in some areas are such that wastage will adversely affect the ADF for at least the next decade.

In sum, the effects of wastage identified by the Joint Committee amount to a loss of operational capability. It is manifestly obvious that the prevailing excessive level of personnel wastage is damaging the organisational health of the ADF. Wastage is undermining the experience and competence level of personnel. It is impacting on the capacity of the training and personnel management systems to maintain the Force's integrity. The financial costs arising from the abnormal loss of skilled staff and increased training effort is enormous. At the psychological level, morale in some areas is lower than normal and the potential has been created for institutional polarisation.

Having reached that conclusion the Joint Committee would like to emphasise that in its judgment the ADF remains a capable organisation staffed by many high quality and committed individuals. The Force continues to attract praise for its performance in Allied exercises. It operates high technology equipment with skill and, as demonstrated by the contingency preparations to evacuate Australians from Fiji in May 1987, can respond rapidly and effectively. Nevertheless, the nation's senior professional single service military leaders--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Personnel Wastage in the Australian Defence Force report is the end product of an inquiry which resulted from Opposition pressure on the Hawke Government to investigate the causes of, establish the magnitude and effect of and recommend appropriate action and reforms to redress the high Defence Force wastage rates which have had such a disastrous impact on the defence preparedness and capability of this nation. I would like particularly to draw attention to the foreword of the report, which emphasises the endeavours of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade to adopt a positive approach to its task and carry out its responsibilities in an objective and constructive manner. I believe we have achieved these goals.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously, it is not remotely possible to discuss even briefly all of the many important and significant aspects of this report. Therefore, on this occasion, I will confine most of my comments to chapters two and three, which cover the extent and magnitude of the current wastage crisis, illustrate how the problem has developed over the past six years and examine the effects of wastage.

In table 2.1 on page 23 of the report, details are given of Australian Defence Force (ADF) separations as a percentage of the total strength for the period 1978-79 to 1987-88. These figures illustrate the enormity of the problem which we are now facing. The rate for officers in 1982-83 was 7.14 per cent. In 1987-88 it had risen to 12.58 per cent. In 1982-83 the separation rate for other ranks was 10.16 per cent. By 1987-88 it had risen to 13.3 per cent. From tables 2.2 and 2.3 we learn that at a time when the total number of defence personnel is at one of its lowest levels the total separations for four of the first five months of 1988 are the highest recorded for those months in 10 years. Prior to 1986, monthly separation figures reached 1,000 once only-in January 1982. In the past 2 1/2 years, the 1,000 monthly separation figures have been exceeded on five separate occasions. Of particular concern is the disturbing increase in officer separation rates. As stated in the report, it is clear that the ADF is losing too many of its very best people. These trends are obvious throughout all branches of the Services.

The 10-year average male officer separation rates for the Royal Australian Navy (RAN) has been calculated variously at 8.7 per cent by the Department of Defence and 7.4 per cent by the Navy. For 1986-87 the rate was 9.8 per cent, and in 1987-88 it rose dramatically to 12.6 per cent. In the first nine months of the financial year 1987-88, 155 notifications of intent to separate in the ranks of commander and below were received, compared with a 10-year average of 98 for the equivalent period. Notices of intent to resign from captains and above were following the same pattern. The report notes that the impact of these resignations, both quantitatively and qualitatively, should provide cause for serious concern.

An examination of wastage by ranks reveals that for commanders the eight-year average separation rate is 9.8 per cent, and the projected 1987-88 rate is 20.4 per cent. Thirty seamen commanders left in 1987; 23 more than the long term average of seven. Among those officers, five were current or very recent destroyer commanding officers-the core of the Navy. For lieutenant commanders, the average rate is 8.7 per cent and the projected 1987-88 rate is 13.5 per cent. Currently there is a shortfall of 69 in the total number of engineer lieutenant commanders required by the Royal Australian Navy. In percentage terms this is a deficiency of 45 per cent.

The report notes that the dramatic increases in separation from those two key middle level ranks is most disturbing in terms of both the immediate hands-on management of the RAN and the long term health of the organisation. Further, it indicates that the Navy's problems in retaining well trained and experienced officers are serious and the separation trend is upwards. Increased wastage is occurring at a time when the Navy's requirement for experienced specialists to staff the new submarine, the Anzac ship project and other projects is also increasing. Shortfalls have so far been met by filling positions with junior, less qualified officers, resulting in lower quality performance and a greater load being borne by those experienced officers remaining. The shortfalls increase pressure on all personnel and become a contributing factor to wastage. In popular terms this can best be described as a vicious circle.
The Australian Army has also sustained high wastage in recent years from both soldier and officer ranks. The Chief of General Staff advised the Committee
The current high wastage in the Army is of major concern to my senior commanders and myself and has the potential to pose significant long-term consequences for national defence.

The yearly average of officer wastage in the financial years 1985-86 and 1986-87 was three percentage points higher than the preceding seven-year average and constituted an increase of 40 per cent over historical levels. The projected wastage rates for all officers for the financial year 1987-88 of 12.1 per cent was the largest for at least 10 years. Of particular concern is the large number of junior officers separating. In the financial years 1985-86 and 1986-87 there was an average numerical increase in separations of 160 above the historical level. Over 84 per cent of that increase was in the ranks from lieutenant to major. The same trend was persisting in 1987-88. The loss rate of lieutenants has been more than double the long term average and that of captains greater by a factor of two-thirds. The report states that, although the number of officers lost is in itself disturbing, the quality and potential of those leaving is of greater concern. The Committee shared the Army's conclusion that this loss of high level talent at the mid-career point is of grave concern. It stated:

It must inevitably lead to a severe reduction in the number of quality officers available for promotion in the future. This will have an adverse effect on long-term quality of senior management and leadership in the Army.

Perhaps the greatest publicity in regard to defence personnel wastage in recent times has concentrated on the exceptionally high resignation rate of Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) pilots. However, as the report points out, wastage rates amongst highly skilled, specialist technical and logistic RAAF personnel are also causing significant problems.

Overall, Air Force's assessment is that `the current separation rate is increasing, and is too high because it is exceeding our capacity to replace our losses with trained personnel'. The 10-year average separation rate for RAAF officers is 8.43 per cent. The wastage rate for 1986-87 was 10.57 per cent. For 1987-88 it had further increased to the unacceptably high level of 12.4 per cent. Once again, junior officers loss rates, including the significant pilot resignation component, have been particularly high over the past three years.

As the report points out, the Air Force is arguably the most technical of the three Services, and the acquisition of technological skills can be a time-consuming process. It is in this area that the RAAF is suffering most. High wastage rates among skilled technicians carry a long term penalty, as long lead-times are involved in training replacements. An illustration of this problem is the increase in separation rates of Air Force engineers. The long term average loss has been 56 annually. In 1987-88 it was expected to exceed 80. In ADF terms, the increase of 24 is small, but it is highly significant to the Air Force in view of the difficulty of recruiting engineers and the four-year lead-time to train them at the Australian Defence Force Academy and elsewhere.

Although the pilot resignation rate has been, as I mentioned previously, very well publicised, it is certainly worth mentioning it again-if only to reinforce the enormous and critical effect it has on our overall defence capability. The long term average annual pilot loss is 47. In 1985-86, 70 pilots resigned from the RAAF. During 1986-87, 107 left and in 1987-88 123 left. In the first six weeks of the financial year, 1988-89, a further 42 pilots had given notification of their intention to resign. Consider these figures in light of the fact that the number of RAAF pilots graduating each year is between 55 and 65.

In April 1988, the Air Force had a shortfall of 171 pilots-that is, actual strength against established posts. By June, the number of pilot vacancies had further increased to 182, including 29 wing commanders and 73 squadron leaders.

It is becoming increasingly difficult to maintain required levels of supervision and training in flying units. The effects of this problem of diminished experience levels were highlighted by the Acting Director of Air Force Safety during an appearance before the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal in June of this year. The officer-a former category `A' pilot and qualified flying instructor with some 6,000 hours flying experience-told the Tribunal:

We have had an increasing accident rate in the air force over the last 12 months and especially over the last six months. In fact, the first six months of this year have been the worst introduction to the year that we have had in the last 20 years . . .
Time is running out, both for me to make these initial comments on the report and, far more importantly-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Time has run out. The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cross Mr M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Opposition for its courtesy in enabling me to complete my statement. I was referring to the fact that the nation's senior professional single service military leaders have all acknowledged that the current high wastage rates have reduced capabilities. Those judgments were confirmed by the Chief of the Defence Force when he appeared before the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. It is clear that, under the existing organisational structure, capabilities will continue to diminish if wastage remains high. The greater part of the Joint Committee's examination of personnel wastage was spent assessing measures to resolve that unsatisfactory circumstance.

SPEECH.PARA: In its report the Committee has presented a range of recommendations which, if addressed vigorously and constructively, should enable the Government to reduce wastage to acceptable, more manageable levels. Those recommendations-there are 48 in all-are too detailed to discuss at length here. However, in broad terms they encompass the following areas: policy, leadership and morale, career satisfaction and personnel management, the service family, and conditions of service.

A point of particular significance is that, in general, service men and women who leave the Australian Defence Force (ADF) before completing what might be considered a full military career tend to do so for the same reasons, regardless of rank or skill category. For example, while much media attention has focused on the salaries which airlines offer Air Force pilots-salaries which the ADF cannot hope to match-the reality is that pay is only one of a number of factors which influence a decision to separate, even for those who can command much larger wages outside the Defence Force.

Changing community values mean that senior defence management must remain dynamic and responsive to change. If the expectations of service men and women are not met on such issues as, for example, job satisfaction, good housing, continuity and stability in the education of children, particularly at secondary school level, work opportunities for spouses and dependants, and child care, then retaining the right people in the Force is likely to remain a problem.

Across the ADF the kinds of issues I have mentioned affect all service men and women. It is unlikely that one issue by itself will trigger a resignation; rather, it is probable that a combination of events will eventually generate the critical level of dissatisfaction. We believe, therefore, that it will be necessary for the ADF's senior management to adopt a wide-ranging and coordinated strategy to resolve this fundamental problem. Addressing issues in isolation is unlikely to produce a satisfactory long term outcome. It is also essential that the system by which the ADF's men and women are rewarded for their service recognises the unique nature of the ADF and the special circumstances under which Defence Force personnel and their families live and work. The recognition of those often onerous circumstances must include a substantial element of compensation through a wide range of conditions of service entitlements.

The majority of the Committee's recommendations could be implemented at little or no extra cost to the defence budget. In many cases determined and innovative management within the ADF and the Department of Defence could do the job. Nevertheless, it is clear that there will need to be either an extra allocation or a reallocation of resources to service personnel.

I should like to conclude by reiterating that this comprehensive and detailed report is the end result of a great deal of effort by a large number of individuals. That effort is indicative of the Committee's concern over the present level of personnel wastage in the ADF and our commitment both to national security and to the men and women of the Defence Force.

The Committee believes that continuing, vigorous action is necessary to control the present level of personnel wastage in the ADF which, under the existing organisational arrangements, is excessive and inimical to national defence. The recommendations presented in this report have been framed to achieve that positive objective. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report which we are beginning to debate today is one of the great examples of the benefits of the joint committee systems which operate in this Parliament. A report such as this would not have seen the light of day if it were not for the committee systems of the Parliament. I am pleased that it was the Opposition which, in fact, was instrumental in having the reference put to the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade last year, and it is a tribute to the work of the Committee that a report such as this, as detailed as this and as extensive as this has come to be debated in the Parliament as quickly as it has. Real benefits can be gained by honourable members on both sides of parliament from the workings of such committees, and this report is an example of that. The report was presented without any dissenting views of any of the members of the Committee and that in itself is a particularly important fact.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that the prime responsibility of any government is to maintain the security of the nation. This report clearly points out that the Government is failing in that duty. The Chairman of the Subcommittee, the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Cross)-and I give him credit for this-maintained at all times an objective analysis of the material being placed before the Committee, and the Committee report, when read, will demonstrate a calm and an objective response to an immense amount of material put forward to the Committee over a long period by an extraordinary number of witnesses, both personally and through written submissions.

However, I should like to take up some of the matters which are addressed in the report and to which the Chairman of the Subcommittee has already drawn some attention. We state, quite categorically, that the report is predicated on three fundamental points. The first two are that Australia must have a high quality Defence Force and that people are the Force's most valuable asset and vital resource. The third point is that the Australian Defence Force is a unique institution.

I underline what the Chairman has said about the analysis of wastage and the requirement that any worthwhile analysis of wastage must come to grips with the more subjective but vital factors of Defence Force quality and effectiveness. A central issue that we addressed in the report is the pattern of wastage-who is leaving, and when. I would like to underline as well this point we made in the report:
It is also important to remember that the lead time to replace a highly skilled and trained individual can be at least as long as that required to introduce into service an item of capital equipment.

We must not think about the Defence Force as being the repository of untrained people, people who cannot do anything else. In fact, defence forces in modern time are composed of highly trained people whose difficulty in getting into the force is, in many cases, quite extreme. The Defence Force is not the repository of the flotsam and jetsam of the Australian population; it is composed of highly trained and skilled individuals. It does take time to achieve that skill and training. The report refers to wastage rates. I should like to underline, again, the Committee's finding:
It is clear that the present level of wastage is substantially too high and has been so for some time. Further, there has been a clear and consistent trend towards this situation for several years.
This is not something that has suddenly come about; it is not something that has snuck up on an unsuspecting government. The Government has known about it for some time.
My colleague the Chairman has already mentioned the levels of wastage in various areas of the Defence Force. I would like to underline this point, which, again, was brought out by the Chairman:
The Committee does not support the Department of Defence's conclusion that wastage is of concern only in `some specific specialist areas'.

Clear and unequivocal evidence before the Committee gave the lie to that somewhat complacent attitude expressed by the Department of Defence. The extent and magnitude of wastage in some of the areas that we have outlined is such-and I shall quote from the report again-that:
it will adversely affect the ADF for at least the next decade.
That is a damning indictment of what has been happening in this Government's management of the Defence Force since it has been responsible for the Force. The report says:

In sum the effects of wastage . . . amount to a loss of operational capability. It is manifestly obvious that the prevailing excessive level of personnel wastage is damaging the organisational health of the ADF. Wastage is undermining the experience and competence levels of personnel. It is impacting on the capacity of the training and personnel management systems to maintain the Force's integrity. The financial cost arising from the abnormal loss of skilled staff and the increased training effort is enormous. At the psychological level, morale has fallen and the potential has been created for institutional and community polarisation.

In my 19 years as a member of this Parliament, I cannot remember any language from any report that is more damning of a situation than the language I have just read from the Personnel Wastage in the Australian Defence Force report brought down today. It is a credit to the Chairman of the Committee, to the members of the Committee and to those who appeared before it, as well as those who assisted the Committee, that that sort of clear and unequivocal conclusion has been reached and brought forward for debate in this House.

The Committee dealt with a great number of issues that were brought forward by the individuals who appeared before it. I shall give one example of something that I, as a member of the Committee travelling around Australia, was horrified to find out. Under the heading `Equipment' the report states:

Equipment was an issue about which, like training, most of the criticism was directed at the Army. Comments on the inadequacy of such basic items as webbing, backpacks, boots and combat uniforms were usually made with some feeling, and in many instances anger. In our opinion, that anger is justified. It seems extraordinary that in the Australian Army of 1988 the quality of those essential personal items can be so bad that many soldiers buy their own from commercial outlets, yet that is the case.
. . . The importance of this matter lies in the considerable failure of management it represents and its damaging consequences for morale . . .

Honourable members might think that that is a minor point to bring out, but when front-line soldiers, people who will be out there facing the shot and shell should that be necessary, have to go out and buy for themselves the equipment that they believe is essential for their well-being and their competence as trained soldiers, it is a damning indictment of the way the Australian defence forces have been run and it is a damning indictment of the Government for allowing that situation to develop.

The report goes on to direct its attention to a great number of issues. Let me give just one example which is always talked about when I meet with Defence Force personnel around Australia. I am talking about the Russell Offices, and I quote from the report:

Given Russell Offices' unenviable reputation, the Government's continuing refusal to promote more harmonious and efficient working relationships between the broad military and civilian components of the diarchy through fundamental organisational reform remains something of a mystery. As long as senior management continues to subscribe to the absurd euphemism of `creative tension' as a description of the work environment within the Defence complex, the `Russell office syndrome' will continue to generate avoidable wastage.

That is tough stuff and it is right. One has only to go around the Australian Defence Force establishments and talk to the people who are actually doing the job to find that that attitude, that response to the Russell Office syndrome, is shared by every Defence Force individual that one comes in contact with.

Obviously the defence forces are essential to the security of this nation. This report very clearly demonstrates that there are tremendous problems within the defence forces. I do not want to reiterate the separation rates, as that has already been done. It is a matter of the greatest concern. More importantly, an enormous number of people within the defence forces-in fact I would suggest everyone within the defence forces-have been waiting for this report to be published; have been waiting for this debate; have been expecting and demanding that something be done as a result of the publication of this report. We, in this Parliament, now have an enormous responsibility not only to note the contents of the report but also, much more importantly, to put into effect the recommendations contained in it. It is a responsibility that this Government cannot escape. It is a responsibility that this Government must accept and that we, as parliamentarians, must ensure that it accepts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bilney Mr G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a very great pleasure for me, as Chairman of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, to speak in support of my colleague the Chairman of the Defence Subcommittee, the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Cross), in the debate on the tabling of the Committee's report entitled Personnel Wastage in the Australian Defence Force. Before I make some specific remarks on that report I would like to congratulate the Chairman of the Defence Subcommittee for his outstanding leadership and direction of the work of that Committee in the years since he has been Chairman of that Subcommittee.

SPEECH.PARA: This report is the third of a trilogy of reports on issues of major defence significance undertaken under his chairmanship. The first report, which was tabled in 1984, dealt with the structure and capabilities of the Australian Defence Force. The second report, which was tabled in 1987, dealt with the management of national defence. This third Cross report turns attention to the most critical commodity in any nation's defence-that is to say, the skills, the dedication and the professionalism of its service men and women. It is a thorough, well-researched, well-presented report which I predict will be not only a best seller but also particularly influential in suggesting lines of policy and administrative reform which need to be pursued in the future.

In commending the honourable member for Brisbane, I would like also to express the thanks of the Committee to all members of the Defence Subcommittee. In the debate this morning there was a contribution from the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson)-I notice in the chamber this morning the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay)-and there was also a contribution from the Deputy Chairman of the Committee, the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar). Together, those people supported the core of the Subcommittee, along with Senator David MacGibbon who played a very crucial role as a Deputy Chairman of the Defence Subcommittee, in considering the vast quantity of written submissions which were received, to which the honourable member for Brisbane made reference; in conducting lengthy public hearings; in visiting Defence Force establishments, both on a formal and an informal basis; and in discussing relevant issues with men and women in the Defence Force. I commend all those members for their diligence. I also wholeheartedly endorse the remarks of the honourable member for Brisbane when he gave warm thanks to the Committee staff, especially Alan Stephens, the Secretary of the Subcommittee; Kylie Freer, who did the voluminous typing and word processing; and Peter Gibson, the Secretary of the full Committee.

In my remarks I would like to focus on the central themes which are enunciated in chapter 9 of the report. The Australian Defence Force is a unique national institution and it has to be viewed in that manner by society. Its special role cannot ever be forgotten or underemphasised by the Parliament or by the Government. As the report notes:

Members of the Defence Force contribute significantly to regional stability, the law and order of the nation, the maintenance of national prosperity and trade, and the protection of valuable off-shore assets . . . That fundamental reason for the existence of a defence force requires its members to be ready to risk their lives at any time to protect their community.

This situation applies to no other social organisation within our national fabric to the same extent. As such, the Defence Force commands our respect and deserves no less than our diligent attention to its well-being and sense of purpose. For those reasons the acknowledged existence of a personnel wastage problem in the report is a cause of considerable national concern. However, I point out-I think to some extent the debate has reflected this-that that concern has to transcend the trivialising effect of party politics. The national interest is at stake here. Governments of all persuasions have permitted this situation to arise. I think it is noteworthy in this context that the report itself is agreed to by all the main parties. One person dissented from one or two of its conclusions, or rather its thrust, but the main political parties agreed to the report. We must now address ourselves single-mindedly to the resolutions of the problems which are adumbrated in the report and which we all recognise.

The report makes a number of specific recommendations-48 in all. Of those I want to highlight in particular the recommendations which deal with the social and material conditions which affect the lives of members of service families in fundamental ways. Very few occupational groupings require that the families of employees shift their location frequently, and occasionally at very short notice, move their children between countries, States and/or schools every couple of years, undergo repeated separations and, at the same time, be prepared to defend their country or its interests at any time and possibly risk their lives in the process. Indeed, the only other which, in some respects, meets a number of those same criteria is Australia's diplomatic service which I left a few years ago and which has also become a fairly dangerous occupation.
I commend to the House chapter 6 of the report, which starts with the dictum:
the Australian Defence Force recruits soldiers and retains families.

We make specific recommendations on family-related issues such as education, compensation for removals, defence housing, geographic stability in postings and factors relating to dual career families and child-care. I commend those recommendations to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly), who is at the table, and note the considerable efforts that she has already made to address and deal with a number of those problems up until now.

Without a more acute concern for problems such as these, which at least in part contribute to wastage and originate in these areas, the problems we have identified and brought to attention will only be exacerbated. As the honourable member for Brisbane has noted, the report acknowledges the considerable progress made by the present Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) in the development and implementation of a logical and coherent defence policy. In the specific context of this reference we commend, on a bipartisan basis, the effort, the energy and the commitment of the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel since her appointment. But a lot still needs to be done. The Joint Committee hopes that this report will serve to focus on a more detailed understanding of the complex network of issues and factors which have contributed to the present circumstances and will be a set of signposts towards a solution to the problems now being experienced.

It is as a result of reports like this that we are in danger of giving the Parliament and its committee system a good name. I agree with the honourable member for Warringah that a job of work like this could not have come out of the bureaucracy, and perhaps it is not unkind to suggest that it would have been regarded as too much of a political or bureaucratic embarrassment to go into it in this way. But it is an important and necessary job of work and the report itself does not pull any punches. I know the Government and the Ministers responsible will treat the report and its recommendations seriously, and I commend it to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are not many minutes remaining in this debate, so I will keep my remarks short. The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) may wish to make a few comments before the time for the debate has concluded.
—I would call the Minister only if no other member on either side rose. This time is for private members' business. If any member rises, the Minister will not be called.

—Prior to 21 October 1987, members of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade had considered, with concern, reports that there was a serious wastage problem in the Australian Defence Force, and it was coincidental that a motion was moved in the Senate shortly after members of the Committee had given this matter consideration. The Committee subsequently decided to adopt the motion referred to it by the Senate. I shared the concerns of the Committee about the wastage in the Australian Defence Force, which had indeed arisen before that motion was moved in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, as previous speakers have said, this report is of fundamental importance. It is fundamental because it concerns the Australian Defence Force, fundamental because it concerns the most important duty of any government-the protection of Australia and its people-and fundamental because the Australian Defence Force is charged with the implementation of that responsibility. There is no greater responsibility for any government than that.

I intend to comment on staff ceilings, personnel management, families, and also the Defence Force retirement and death benefits (DFRDB) scheme. We received many complaints about the limitation on staff-so-called staff ceilings. If ever an issue needs to be addressed quickly, it is staff ceilings. Put simply, money must be made available to ensure that staff ceilings are lifted, that sufficient numbers of people are provided to complete the task at hand and to reduce the demands on unpaid overtime by members of the Australian Defence Force. We found it to be an issue of concern and bitterness among many members of the Defence Force whom we met during our hearings.

I enjoin the Chief of the Defence Force to give urgent consideration to the issue of personnel management. That is referred to in recommendation 14 of the report, which seeks to instruct the single Services to introduce a specialist personnel management employment category, and also to establish the post of Assistant Chief of the Defence Force-Personnel within the headquarters of the Australian Defence Force.

I was surprised to learn during the hearings we conducted that this issue of personnel management seemed to have been neglected, seemed to have been put aside or even never to have been considered as an issue worthy of top line consideration by the senior management of the Australian Defence Force. It seemed to have been taken for granted that, because it was the Defence Force, the system itself would attend to and look after personnel management. The attitude seemed to pervade that it had worked well in the past, it was working well now and would continue to work well in the future. Of course the fact is that it was not working well and so could not continue to work well in the future. That is why this important recommendation was placed in the report.

Chapter 6 deals with families. That is an important matter, and I know the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has devoted much time and much of her considerable ability to dealing with issues that concern Defence Force families.

In regard to the Defence Force retirement and death benefits scheme, recommendation 34 speaks for itself. Nevertheless, I enjoin the Government to restore as soon as pos- sible the 2 per cent that was discounted from the indexation increase, in the 1986 incremental increase given to Commonwealth superannuants, which include, of course, Defence Force retirement and death benefits scheme beneficiaries. That is an issue that rankles DFRDB pensioners. They say that they have a contract with the Government with respect to the payment of their pensions. The decision to take 2 per cent off their increase in 1986 is, as they say, a breach of contract. I know that the Government is looking at this issue at present. I know that the matter has been raised within the ranks of the Government, within its party meetings, and I am confident that, as soon as economic circumstances permit-namely, in the 1989-90 Budget-the Government will restore that 2 per cent taken from Defence Force retirement and death benefit scheme recipients in 1986.

There must be no reallocation of resources to meet the challenges contained in this report. Put simply, the Government must spend more money to meet the recommendations, to ensure their implementation. The Government must respond positively. This Government is charged with the responsibility of administering the Australian Defence Force and, if that requires more money, so be it.

I thank my colleagues on the Committee for the support they have given me, particularly, and for the tremendous way in which they participated in the determination of the report. I thank also the Committee staff, particularly Alan Stephens, who played such a critical role in assisting the Committee to bring down this report. The report is of great significance. The implementation of its recommendations will challenge this Government for many years to come. It is a challenge for us all, as has been said by previous speakers, to ensure that the Australian Defence Force receives the consideration it is entitled to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak on the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, entitled Personnel Wastage in the Australian Defence Force. As an Opposition member, I am pleased to be able to agree with members of the Government, because this report is a great example of the work of the parliamentary committee system. It shows that people from both sides, whether in government or in opposition, can come together in a bipartisan way, throw party politics aside and carry out committee work of this nature. Here we have an in-depth examination of a most serious problem, the problem of personnel wastage in our Australian defence forces in our bicentennial year. We have a most comprehensive study, and I might also say that I think the Government was happy to accept the reference to the Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, and it now accepts the important work it has done and that the role of Parliament and parliamentary committees will be important for the resolution of the enormous problems and difficulties that exist in the Defence Force. I note the presence in the House for the tabling of this report of the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly).

SPEECH.PARA: The wastage occurring in the Australian defence forces is cause for great concern. My colleague the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) earlier referred to the Russell Hill syndrome. It is a serious syndrome, and I identify myself with his comments. Another syndrome is the wastage syndrome. When I visited Exmouth in Western Australia with a Committee, I spoke to a very competent and capable Royal Australian Navy technician who had been in the Navy for 20 years-a salt of the earth type that makes not only the defence forces but Australia great. He told us that he was resigning the following week. I said, `Why are you resigning?'. He said, `There is no future'. When asked what he intended to do, he said, `I'm going to Perth. I'm sure I'll get a job'. I am sure that he would, too. He was qualified, capable and competent, But it hit me that that Navy person was resigning because there was insecurity and because it was becoming fashionable to resign. So there is a syndrome abroad, as has been said in this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is true.

—I thank the honourable member for his comment. A variety of factors contribute to it. It is largely a matter of morale. I guess it is a matter of leadership. The report deals with that point. It is a serious problem and it is not easily solved by quick administrative action. That is the dilemma that faces the Government. There is bipartisan criticism of that point. I hope that the report will be studied by both the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) and the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, who is at the table, so that solutions to the problems that face us can be found.

SPEECH.PARA: There are 48 recommendations. I hope they will be taken seriously. They include the importance of families and the importance of dual career families. It is important to note the problems faced by families with children when they are transferred. I think it is recognised that when half of the Royal Australian Navy is transferred from the east coast to the west coast there are massive dislocation problems. There are problems in relation to children's schooling. This report deals with that very serious matter. It is a problem for children to have to attend eight schools in as many years. Families want stability; children want stability in education. There is an acknowledgment in this report and an in-depth study of the role of the service family. Chapter 6 outlines the problems of disturbance, the need for a disturbance allowance, the need for adequate housing when one moves, the problems of education, the problems of paying for removals, the problems of being posted to isolated and remote locations.

There is the problem of careers. I talked to a person-I will not name her because I could embarrass her-in this building yesterday. She has a career in Canberra. On the weekend she will move interstate, to another city, and will have to abandon that career which she enjoys because she is married to an officer in the Defence Force. Families are prepared to make those sacrifices. That is one of the great things that we found during this inquiry. We discovered, in talking to service men and women of all ranks and at all levels, their great dedication to serving their nation. I wish that their example could be followed by those unions and union officials who mess up this great country.

TALK.START.PARA: —And big employers like John Elliott.
—I heard the interjection; I make no comment on it.
—But you ensure that it goes into Hansard.

—You made the point, Mr Deputy Speaker. I was talking about the question of dual career families. The other comment that I make concerns the recommendations with regard to lateral recruitment. Part of the Russell Hill syndrome-and it happens in the private sector as well-is that, unless a person joins the forces when he is young, unless he attends a training school, having joined as a recruit-or attends the right officer cadet school, the Jervis Bay training school or the Defence Force Academy-unless he embarks on a whole career, he is not appropriate to be in the Defence Force.

SPEECH.PARA: We must look at lateral recruitment. The report does look at this issue. I will limit my comments to the area of pilots. It seems to me that an enormous number of young men and women are training to become pilots. They are having a hard time getting jobs. They have to go to remote locations such as the Kimberleys and areas in the Northern Territory, including Arnhem Land, where they gain great flying experience. The Royal Australian Air Force takes the attitude that it does not want such people because they cannot possibly have been trained as well as the Air Force pilots. If they have trained under Australian conditions and acquired a licence under Australian regulations and examination procedures, quite frankly, I think they are good enough to fly VIP aircraft, Caribou and Hercules aircraft. I believe there ought to be a scheme for lateral engagement of young pilots, both men and women. I say to the Minister at the table that I would like to see more women pilots in the Australian Defence Force, just as I would particularly like to see more women officers on ships, but that is a side issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —In combat?
—Yes; why not? Why should women be denied the opportunity to serve their country at the ultimate level?
—It is a bit too radical for me.

—It is a matter of choice. I am delighted that I am a bit more radical than the Minister on this issue. I was talking about the development of lateral recruitment for men and women to enter the Air Force. I think it could be looked at in other areas. Certainly, in the technical trades there must be similar opportunities. Innovative, imaginative ideas must be adopted by the Government, particularly in relation to the combining of a civilian career with a Reserve career so that people who are skilled in computers, black box technology or electronics can work in their civilian job by day and perhaps, by night, for two or three months of the year, they can work for the Defence Force and impart those vital trades and skills that we need.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to have been able to speak on this important bipartisan report. I hope that people in the gallery and people listening to the broadcast-if they can ever find the parliamentary broadcast on the radio dial these days-note the important bipartisan work of the Parliament and the committee system.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON TRANSPORT, COMMUNICATIONS AND INFRASTRUCTURE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Neil Mr L.R.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, I present the Committee's report entitled Efficiency Audit Review: Australian National's Commission Traffic, together with the minutes of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —In presenting the report, I would like to make some brief remarks. Australian National's commission traffic is the transport by AN of its own staff, stores and equipment. It is not a large area of AN's operations and it has received little management attention in the past. The Auditor-General in his efficiency audit made some criticisms of AN's controls and noted that, although some measures had been taken to manage commission traffic more efficiently, these reforms had not been well controlled, nor fully applied in all branches. The Auditor-General also noted that AN had agreed with most of the recommendations of the efficiency audit. The efficiency audit was referred to the Committee on 24 March 1988.

SPEECH.PARA: On 8 and 9 June 1988 the Subcommittee of the Standing Committee on Transport Communications and Infrastructure, consisting of me as Chairman, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) and the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott), was briefed by AN executives and inspected facilities in the Adelaide area and Port Augusta in South Australia.

I would like, on behalf of the Committee, to thank Mr Russell King, AN's Acting General Manager, for the effort he put into our visit. He and his executives arranged the itinerary for our visit, briefed us thoroughly on AN's operations and showed us through some of its more important facilities. We were all particularly impressed by the dedication of AN's work force and its commitment to the future of the organisation. Since the amalgamation of the South Australian and Tasmanian systems with the former Commonwealth Railways in 1978, AN's total numbers have declined from 11,614 to 7,250 at the end of May 1988. Management initiated and voluntary retirement schemes have been very effective in this significant reduction in work force numbers at AN. In the same period, significant new technology and work practices have been introduced for the benefit of AN.

We were particularly glad to have the opportunity to hold wide-ranging discussions with significant numbers of union representatives at both Islington and Port Augusta. During these discussions, we noted the concern of the unions that the time had come for the number of tradespeople and apprentices with AN to be re-examined. The unions believe that AN's work force has been reduced to the point where it is having difficulty in maintaining itself. Given the commitment we saw, we believe these views demand strong attention.

Although not covered by the terms of reference of the review of the efficiency audit, there were two other matters which arose in the course of our visit to AN. The first is the question of AN's east-west freight traffic and the possible relocation of its eastern terminal from Broken Hill to Parkes in New South Wales. I believe the honourable member for Farrer will deal with this matter during his remarks. The second matter is AN's debt to equity ratio. The Committee agrees with AN that an increase in its equity capital would increase its flexibility in the competitive transport sector.

AN's objectives and goals, and its restructuring strategies, mark it as an organisation with its eye on increasing its share of the market and reducing the amount of subsidy by the taxpayer. Such are the economies of its operations that it must continue to look to its commercial activities to achieve the latter aim. Its achievements since 1978, on the basis of the briefings and material given to us, appear to be significant.

It would be remiss of me not to acknowledge the contribution of Mr Patrick Regan of the Committee secretariat for his untiring efforts and commitment to assisting our Committee. His efforts were invaluable and I place on record my sincere personal thanks for his outstanding support. Finally, I would like to thank the honourable member for Aston (Mr Saunderson), the Chairman of the Committee, for giving me the opportunity to table this review. To the honourable members for Farrer, Throsby, Mayo and Hindmarsh I extend my thanks for their assistance and constructive participation during this review. It was indeed a pleasure to be a part of such an enthusiastic team. I commend to the House the review of the efficiency audit into AN's commission traffic.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to follow the honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil) and I support his comments and the acknowledgments he gave to the staff and other members of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure in the production of the Efficiency Audit Review: Australian National's Commission Traffic report. It was a privilege to work on this subcommittee of the Standing Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to touch on two matters relating to the report. It is a timely reminder to the House and the nation that there is a justifiable and vital role for rail in this country's economic infrastructure in the twenty-first century. It is a role which is essential if we are to service our expanding economy by the best means possible. That is not only for the key capital city routes, the standard gauge routes by and large, but equally for certain key regional routes as well. This should be done on a basis which must be assessed in accordance with stringent economic criteria.

Unfortunately, due to a number of factors which time does not allow me to elaborate on, this concept of a revitalised and revamped rail system quite often becomes derailed because of factors such as State boundaries, work practices and other historic reasons which are not easily rectified. This report, in one sense, is a step along that path to greater efficiency and more rationalisation.

Included in this report is a very strong comment that the Committee should go on to look at the very specific question of revamping and improving east-west freight operations between Sydney and Perth along that very long and significant transport corridor. At the moment a train pulling a container or freight van from Sydney to Perth has to be remarshalled or re-engined at Lithgow; have a crew change at Bathurst; have further alterations at Orange; have a complete revamping at Parkes; have another remarshalling at Broken Hill and again at Peterborough-on occasions it will have a crew change there-have a major remarshalling at Port Augusta; have a refuelling stop at Forrest; have a remarshalling at Kalgoorlie; have a crew change at Merredin and/or Northam; and ultimately eight days later, on average, it will arrive in Perth.

In 1988 that is not good enough. We have had a standard gauge operating from Sydney to Perth for many years. Yet we still have not extracted the best advantages from that operation. What is required is some simple lateral thinking. What is required is an examination, putting aside State government prejudices and Federal Government notions and looking in a dispassionate sense at transferring the Parkes-Broken Hill section of the main line from the New South Wales Government to Australian National. This would entail shifting its eastern terminal to Goobang Junction just west of Parkes, where the terrain begins to change sharply and where a site has already been identified. That is what the Committee has found in its studies and is desirous of looking at in more detail.

It is my hope that flowing from the tabling of this report more pressure will be brought to bear. I am pleased to acknowledge that the Federal Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) has made reference to discussions between Australian National and the State Rail Authority of NSW along not dissimilar lines. Progress is being made. Let me remind the House and the nation that we need revitalised and revamped rail in the next decade and in the next century. It is about time we got about the task of getting in place the right planning and policies to bring this about. It is food for thought.

Australian National has made great progress in recent years, not only under this Government but under the previous Government, and will make further great progress. If, in fact, there was a rail lobby equivalent to the Royal Automobile Club of Victoria and the National Roads and Motorists Association preaching the cause relating to modes of transport or anything else, as one has to today, the priority for rail and the modernising of rail in this country might be a good deal higher than it is. I commend this report of the subcommittee. I hope that it will pave the way for an additional term of reference to introduce some lateral thinking, especially relating to the east-west freight movements between Sydney and Perth.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, I present the Committee's report entitled A tale of three cities-A review of the efficiency audit of the Australian Taxation Office: Taxpayers in unincorporated businesses, together with the minutes of proceedings and the evidence received by the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report which I have just tabled deals with an investigation of provisional taxpayers in three industries in three cities. The investigation was an efficiency audit by the Auditor-General's Office of the Australian Taxation Office (ATO). It is the twelfth audit report on the Australian Taxation Office and commenced in November 1985. It was tabled in the House on 7 December 1987 and referred to the Finance and Public Administration Committee for examination. The industries chosen and the locations examined in the efficiency audit were: luxury holiday units on the Gold and Sunshine coasts, restaurants in Hobart, and Canberra builders.

SPEECH.PARA: The inquiry was both disappointing and encouraging-disappointing in that there were no startling discoveries during the course of the inquiry, but encouraging in that it is evidence of the improvement taking place within the ATO, since the report of the Expenditure Committee in September 1986. The Audit Office advised the sub-committee that, had it now been considering the audit, it would not have undertaken it. Audit did, however, change the focus of the audit during the course of the investigation.
The report contains 54 recommendations and the ATO has agreed with most of these or has indicated that they have been accepted practice. As the ATO witness said at the first hearing:
Virtually all . . . have been acted upon either prior to or following the audit report.

The investigation was productive as far as the Commonwealth revenue was concerned. The audit report noted that the investigation discovered omitted income of over $3.4m which resulted in additional tax and penalties of $2.7m. Since the audit report was tabled, these figures have been revised. As of 27 July 1988, the omitted income stood at $4.5m and the additional tax and penalty at $3,337,000. The cost of the audit was $321,000.

In spite of these returns, the ATO suggested that the results achieved were well short of those achieved in other projects. For the record, the Queensland luxury units project returned $296 per hour of work done in the efficiency audit; the Hobart restaurants, $67 per hour; and the Canberra builders, $141 per hour. The ATO suggested that the average dollar per audit hour figure, which it admitted was a crude measure, was $363 per hour.

A feature of the luxury units project was not the discovery of loss in income from the rental of the units that led to the undisclosed rental income but rather that undisclosed income was discovered when people were asked to account for how they obtained the funds to purchase the units. During the course of the inquiry, the Subcommittee was informed of other potential industry projects or targets for the ATO. I suppose that in some respects this is giving fair warning to those industries which the ATO believes in the future will be the subject of audits of this nature. They are abalone fishing, rental properties, the racing industry-which I am sure will affect some honourable members in this place-plumbing and real estate, as well as a couple of perennial favourites, barristers and solicitors.

One of the values of the audit report is the coverage it gives to initiatives within the ATO, particularly the score system which ranks professional taxpayers by allocating scores for variations from industry standards and from the previous year's performance. The returns with the highest scores are generally expected to be, and here I quote from the audit report, `those with the best audit potential'. As noted in the audit report, the ATO will reduce the resources allocated to the unincorporated business sector. However, this does not mean that the area will be neglected, as there will still be an audit force of around 800 directed at the unincorporated business sector. There will be a greater concentration on the large corporate sector. The Committee endorses the ATO's policy of concentrating on the top end of the market.
The most important priority, according to the audit report, was the development of a high integrity, unique identifier for all taxpayers. The audit recommended at recommendation 44:

The AAO recommends that the ATO develop a high integrity unique identification system for all taxpayers which will provide full cross-referencing of relationships among companies, partnerships, trusts and individual taxpayers including those whom the ATO exempts from having to lodge returns. This index should be readily accessible to ATO officers in their compliance activities and should be exploited fully by automated procedures in such routine processes as the issuing of assessment notices and the analysis of lodgment histories.

The Committee draws the attention of the Parliament to that recommendation and to the recommendation of two earlier reports by the Committee, A Taxing Review and A Taxing Problem-in fact a report by the former Expenditure Committee which was tabled in September 1986. Both of these reports, as you, Mr Deputy Speaker, will be well aware, recommended that the ATO take the necessary steps to establish a high integrity identification system which would ensure maximum taxpayer compliance. I guess it can be said that the third time proves it. I note that the Parliament has already accepted the idea of a high integrity tax file number and that it has been debated and passed through this House with the assent of both sides of the Parliament. This also is a reflection of the work of the Committee as the report on this occasion, as on previous occasions, has been a unanimous decision of the Committee.

The Committee has noted in its report some of the changes taking place within tax administration. We have referred to the tax amnesty, self-assessment, the non-lodger strategy and the extension of the prescribed payments system, which my colleague the Deputy Chairman of the Committee, the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson), will comment on shortly, and welcomed these initiatives.

I pay tribute to my fellow committee members, particularly the honourable member for Sturt, the Deputy Chairman, and the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons), both of whom have served on the three subcommittees which have looked at the 12 audit reports on the ATO and each time have suggested a high integrity identification system. I also place on record my thanks to the Committee Secretary, Mr Phil Bergin, and Sharon Fisher, who prepared the manuscript, on a number of occasions with rewrites. Both are in the chamber and, on behalf of the whole Committee, I extend our sincere appreciation to them. I also place on record the Committee's thanks for the assistance received from both the Australian Taxation Office and the Australian Audit Office.

The Committee has a current inquiry into the thirteenth efficiency audit of the ATO. I hope to be able to present an interim report on that inquiry before the end of this period of sittings. I suspect that the recommendations of that report will have far more direct impact than this report on unincorporated businesses. The report I am referring to refers to international profit shifting. I think that is an issue which is just coming into focus and the Committee, I am sure, will sharpen that focus.

In conclusion, I commend the report of the Committee to the Parliament. I believe that it shows how members of the Parliament can work together effectively to examine an issue and to make specific findings, although in this case no recommendations as a result, I think, of the acceptance by the Australian Taxation Office of many of the recommendations put forward in the efficiency audit. Nevertheless, I believe that it has sharpened once again the focus of the Parliament on the improvements presently taking place in the Australian Taxation Office. I commend the Taxation Commissioner on the initiatives we have seen over the last 18 months or so in that office. I commend this report to the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration in commenting on its report, A tale of three cities-A review of the efficiency audit of the Australian Taxation Office: Taxpayers in unincorporated businesses. In the time available I do not propose to canvass the whole range of issues that came before the Committee when it examined these particular efficiency audits by the Auditor-General. I want to focus attention for a few moments in particular on those sections of the report that deal with the prescribed payments system (PPS). Honourable members will be aware that this system commenced its operation in May 1983. It was a system by which income tax was deducted at source from some forms of income not subject to pay as you earn (PAYE) tax deductions or other instalment deductions prior to its introduction.

SPEECH.PARA: The system was introduced to overcome tax avoidance, tax evasion and so on in what had been identified as an area of tax loss. It was introduced to overcome the tax evasion that was identified as occurring in certain industries where cash payments were prevalent. The system required people brought into it to make deductions from those cash payments and send them directly to the Australian Taxation Office. The tax payments were deducted by the person in an employing relationship-not only the employer, some cases involving a contractor paying a subcontractor. That person would deduct the tax that would have been payable by the subcontractor or the employee but was not deducted because they were not caught by the PAYE system.

The system was designed and set up to exempt the good taxpayers from the prescribed payments system-those who had a sound taxpaying record. On that basis one would have expected that, as the scheme became effective and collected tax raised the level of compliance, PPS tax collections would have begun to decline. That has not happened. The very reverse has occurred. In 1983-84, $251m was collected in five months; in 1984-85, $412m was collected; in 1985-86, $515m was collected; in 1986-87, $765m was collected; and last financial year $935m was collected. Given the origins of the scheme, one could well ask what has gone wrong. Why are we collecting more and more tax? Is there more and more tax evasion and avoidance in these industries? I do not believe that is the case.

What the Committee discovered-I certainly did by listening to the evidence-was that a significant number of taxpayers who were brought into the prescribed payments system have found it to be a convenient way of meeting their tax obligations. They prefer it to the provisional tax system where they are liable under the annual payment system or the quarterly payment system. That being the case, it is important that the Parliament, the public and the Tax Office begin to change the basis upon which the prescribed payments system is now founded. It should not be seen as a means of collecting tax from those who were formally non-compliant. It should be seen as one of the general mechanisms for withholding tax at source-like the PAYE system, the imputation credit system that operates in the same way and withholding taxes in their relationship to the income of people overseas.

During the period that the PPS has been in operation, the Tax Office has improved its methods of collection. It is introducing personalised deduction forms for PPS payees. This is becoming a standard administrative practice. The Tax Office is printing forms for these taxpayers with their PPS numbers on them. I agree with what the Chairman of the Committee has said about the Committee's clear, unequivocal view about the need for a high integrity tax file number-not an ID card, but a high integrity tax file number. This number could appear on the PPS forms. I hope that, as a result of providing numbered forms to PPS taxpayers, the Tax Office's system will be so efficient that it will help taxpayers. I hope that it will be seen as a cooperative effort, bringing together the information that is collected under the PPS stationery with the PPS deduction numbers on it. At the end of the financial year the Tax Office could produce, not only for its own internal use but also for the assistance of and use by the taxpayer, a list of the prescribed payments and a quantification of the PPS tax deducted. This would be done in order to tell the taxpayer, `This is the minimum income which we expect you to disclose to us'.

One would hope that this assistance would be extended to PAYE taxpayers in general and to those who pay interest. Banks now provide the information. The Tax Office could help the average citizen and small businessman in preparing their tax forms, although still leaving it an an obligation on the taxpayer to disclose income from sources that have not already been recorded on the Tax Office's database through the prescribed payments system or other withholding tax mechanisms.

When this cooperative attitude is pursued further, aided by the use of computerised equipment, I am sure that it will add to the level of compliance of taxpayers and the spirit of cooperation which one must have between honest taxpayers and a fair, understanding Tax Office. Along with the Chairman, I was pleased to note that some of these improvements are in train. I hope that A Taxing Problem, The Taxing Review and now this report A Tale of Three Cities will encourage the Tax Office to pursue this more positive relationship with those who have tax obligations.

There were one or two other matters relating to the report which I wanted to bring to the attention of the House but I know that one of my colleagues wants a few minutes to present another report before the time allocated for the discussion of reports expires. I would like to give him that opportunity. I conclude by thanking the Chairman and other members of the Committee for the way in which we have been able to develop a common sense of purpose and direction in the recommendations and reports that we have been writing on these issues relating to the Tax Office. I also thank, as did the Chairman, the staff of the Committee and, in particular, its secretary, Mr Phil Bergin.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON TRANSPORT, COMMUNICATIONS AND INFRASTRUCTURE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, I present the Committee's second report on proposals for variation to the plan of layout of the city of Canberra and its environs.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson) for his courtesy in allowing me time to make this brief statement. This is the second report this year of the Joint Subcommittee on the Australian Capital Territory on variations to the plan of Canberra. The variation provides for a road and four service lanes in the Tuggeranong Town Centre service trades area to facilitate the progressive release of commercial sites in the area.

SPEECH.PARA: Inadequate information about the variation was provided in the first advertisement so, following an objection, the Australian Capital Territory Administration readvertised the variation with an explanation about the location and nature of the proposed changes.
