The time for lodging submissions was also extended. Following this mistake, the Australian Capital Territory Administration has set up new procedures for public comment on proposed variations to the city plan of Canberra. I will read these procedures now and would welcome any comment on them from the public. The procedures as laid down by the Australian Capital Territory Administration are, for day one: the Australian Capital Territory lands section receives advice that the instrument has been signed by the Minister, refers the variation details to the Joint Subcommittee, determines which day the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette will be published, contacts public venues to arrange displays for a period open for comment, prepares displays, sends draft advertisements to the public information section which provides for 14 days for comment for a normal series or 21 days for a large number of items or an item with expected high community interest, and sends a draft press release to the media relations section.

On day three the Gazette is published; the press release is issued; the advertisement is cleared for publication on the following Wednesday and Saturday; and displays are set up on the ground floor of the National Capital Development Commission building and the ground floor of the south building in London Circuit and in other public venues; and on day 18 displays are taken down and all letters concerning the variation series are referred to the Joint Subcommittee.

The ACT Administration, in preparing these new procedures, has attempted to ensure that the correct balance is drawn between the need to ensure that the public has adequate time to consider any proposed variation and the need minimise the total time frame for consideration of variations so that private enterprise land development package developers are not unduly delayed from developing and selling residential and/or commercial parcels of land.

As I said, if any Canberra residents are uneasy about any part of these procedures, I would like them to let me know. The Joint Subcommittee has approved the proposed extension of commercial sites in Tuggeranong. They are simply an addition to the number of sites available for commercial use and, as such, will increase opportunities for business close to Tuggeranong Town Centre. The Committee's only concern was to ensure that there is no intrusion of the proposed roads into the footpath, cycle path or foreshore landscaping around the lake. We were assured that this would not happen. Therefore, I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to direct the attention of the House and, in fact, the nation to this matter, and I have no objection to the revised procedures and the fact that the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) has brought this report forward as an additional item on this occasion. It is relatively minor in many ways but it is, nevertheless, a step along the path to a more efficient approach to these variations. As I happen to sit on this Subcommittee on the Australian Capital Territory, I have had a passing interest in these types of matters. What in fact is buried in this is yet another error by public servants who have not been named in the consequence of their proceeding about their duties. In fact, the honourable member for Fraser alluded to this. In questioning in the Subcommittee, I eventually reached a stage some months ago, after narrowing down an error with regard to the United States Embassy fence and the regazettal and readvertising and the whole repeat of that procedure following mistakes made in the ACT Administration, of establishing a cost of these errors.

SPEECH.PARA: Errors, one might say, are made every day and therefore why be fussed about them? Well, it is about time that the House and the nation became fussed about this type of error. And the way to stamp out these administrative, clerical, descriptive errors of one kind or another is to bring in a degree of lateral thinking and accountability by naming the public servants directly responsible for their handiwork in creating those errors in the first place. I bet that one would soon see a great improvement, if that were done, in the accuracy of the documentation flowing from this particular aspect of governance-namely, incredible variations to minor fence lines and roads and other situations. Important as I am sure they are to the honourable member for Fraser, to be fair, nevertheless in the scheme of deliberations of the national Parliament they are relatively minor matters, yet they are matters which have now been codified as being in error in terms of the way in which they have been handled, leading to an additional cost and an abuse of taxpayers' funds.

Therefore, let us name the public servants responsible for those errors, to inject a degree of exact accountability into deliberations of this kind. Let us perhaps take that even a step further and consider a dockage of pay, where it has been a gross error involving incompetence, to regain the costs associated with the error involved. It is not unreasonable; it would be required in certain private enterprise companies where a hopeless error was made, one which could have been avoided and one for which there was no justification. The public at the grassroots level, away from the Taj Mahal of the new Parliament House in Canberra, are sick and tired of this lotus land approach to the governance of this country, be it on the small matters of ACT administration or be it on the larger matters of macro-economic policy, the higher rates of interest, higher taxation rates, and the like. It is part of this arrogant, out of touch and now X-rated Government which is governing the country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Farrer is proceeding beyond the statement which has been made. If he wishes to make further remarks, I ask him to stay within the confines of the statement.
—Has the honourable member for Farrer never made a mistake?

—I have owned up to my mistakes. That is what I am asking for on this occasion-that there be an owning up to the mistakes, because the way to eradicate those mistakes is to see the names of the public servants involved embraced in the reports. We came close to that aim, as honourable members will recall, in the old Parliament, in Senate committee rooms 1 and 2, when we had some officers sweating. That is a good thing, because that is what our parliamentary committee system is all about. Too often the bureaucracy goes its own way with regard to its modus operandi, yet it is accountable and that is what I am on about.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, we all make mistakes, but those mistakes which fall into the category of being careless mistakes, of being unacceptable mistakes for which there was no real excuse, are the ones which should involve a degree of naming and a degree of direct accountability, because that is what the vast majority of Australians would like to see. They are pretty sick and tired of the alternative approach.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Nehl.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1988 in what I believe to be a thoroughly bipartisan spirit without a strain of antagonism towards the Government. I do not seek to embarrass the Government by doing this; rather, I seek to resolve some ambiguity and an anomaly. The Bill does not seek to reduce a tax or to change the substance of the law; rather, it is designed to clarify the interpretation of the existing law.

—Because of the deficiencies of the sound system, as a courtesy to the honourable member for Cowper, it would be best if he moved closer to the microphone. In that way, the House will be able to better hear him, and he will receive better coverage of his comments.
—If we can't hear the honourable member for Cowper, we are in real trouble. It is about time we got the sound system looked at.

—I take the point of the honourable member. To be fair to the honourable member for Cowper, I want to ensure that he receives the best possible coverage, and the sound system is not doing him a service.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. Gifts to the Life Education Centre Incorporated and life education centres have been accepted as being gifts to a public benevolent institution in terms of section 78 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. However, some claims have now been disallowed, contrary to the earlier position. The purpose of the Bill is to give the House an opportunity to remove the ambiguity that has arisen and so clarify the situation. There is a need, in the public interest, to clarify the position and so give some certainty to the organisation in respect of the interpretation of the law in so far as its funding arrangements are concerned. For 14 years, life education centres have been accepted as public benevolent institutions, until a change in interpretation made in March 1988. I do not attack the Taxation Office for that; it is a question of interpretation, and again I stress that the purpose of the Bill is to remove the ambiguity.

SPEECH.PARA: At present more than 600,000 children have contact with or see a life education program every year, and in the next 1 1/2 years that number will double. Approximately 1.2 million children will have contact with an anti-drug program which is effective, which is working and which is in the best interests of Australia. It is interesting to note that, of those 600,000 children who currently are in contact with the life education program, some 30 per cent had already begun to get involved with some substance of addiction. It is important that this program should carry on.

The whole thing hinges on the definition of a public benevolent institution. I am delighted to see the Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Peter Morris) at the table, because in his letter of 20 September 1988, he said:

Although the phrase public benevolent institution does not have a statutory definition it is generally understood to be an institution for the relief of poverty, sickness, suffering, distress, destitution, misfortune and helplessness.

I can do no more than go through those words again, because drugs-drugs affecting our children-do cause poverty and crime, too. Drugs do cause sickness; drugs do cause suffering; drugs do cause very great distress; drugs cause enormous destitution; and drugs cause misfortune and, certainly, helplessness.

Every child counselled by the Life Education Centre is provided with both the knowledge and the motivation to avoid drugs. I repeat: the Bill does not seek to reduce a tax or to change the substance of the law. Rather, it is designed to clarify the interpretation of the existing law. I commend the Bill to the House.
Bill read a first time.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it would be appropriate if I now mention a procedural question in respect of the Bill introduced. Standing order 293 provides that a proposal for the imposition, or for the increase, or alleviation, of a tax or duty, or for the alteration of the incidence of such a charge, shall not be made except by a Minister. The provisions of this Bill, as I understand them, do not seek to impose increases or to alter the incidence of a tax, nor do they propose to alleviate a tax.

INTERJECT.PARA: The Bill seeks to clarify the meaning of the term `public benevolent institution' and, in particular, to ensure that gifts to the Life Education Centre movement should continue to be accepted as deductions, as they have apparently been in the past. I note the assent of the honourable member for Cowper to that. It could be agreed that, in seeking to restore an earlier interpretation of the provisions of the Act, the Bill would cause an alleviation of the sum a person may in fact pay in taxation. However, it would seem that the proposal is not to alleviate a tax, to return to the words of standing order 293. In procedural terms it is certainly a grey area; but in the circumstances it was felt appropriate to permit the honourable member for Cowper to initiate the proposal. If the Government wishes this matter to proceed, and if it has any doubts about the validity of the Bill, it can, of course, introduce its own Bill. I thought it might assist the honourable member for Cowper to make that statement.
In accordance with sessional order 104a, the second reading will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in view of the massive stockpiles of nuclear, chemical, conventional and other types of weapons and of the continued technological escalation of the arms race, notably into space, this House calls on the Government to use every possible means to encourage disarmament through measures which would enhance global security including:
(1) continuing to advocate a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty;
(2) continuing opposition to research on, or deployment of, space weaponry;
(3) supporting establishment of a permanent, effective international verification organisation;
(4) supporting strengthening of international disputes settling procedures through mediation or adjudication under international law;
(5) supporting establishment of permanent United Nations peacekeeping forces; and
(6) seeking permanently reliable sources of revenue to fund these activities.

In the last few decades, our planet has been wired to explode. The reality is that there are 50,000 nuclear warheads in the world with 1 1/2 million times the destructive power of the Hiroshima bomb. More are built every day, and more countries are gaining the ability to build them. The reality also is that, while the world spends a trillion dollars a year in search of military security, our security in virtually every other aspect of life is being eroded as global, environmental and economic problems go untreated for lack of adequate funds and political attention.

Security from the threat of war cannot be achieved by nations accumulating ever more frightening mountains of weapons; nor can it be achieved by their elimination alone. It can be achieved only through a common enterprise among nations to develop international security institutions based on a system of enforceable international law that can create the confidence and stability needed for disarmament. This requires commitment to the goal of global security.

The United Nations Charter was signed in a different world. It was a world without nuclear weapons or jet engines. Whole regions were still colonised. It was a world at war. War has continued, but other things have changed. Fifty thousand nuclear weapons have been assembled. One hundred new states have joined the international community, countries that had no voice in San Francisco. Each year the world has grown smaller, linked together into a single community by aeroplanes and satellites, and by an interdependent world economy and a shared global environment. Just as the world institutions of 1919 were inadequate to prevent World War II, so the institutions of 1945 are proving inadequate today to protect an increasingly global civilisation. Nowhere is this more true than with the problem of war and peace. Only by building stronger common institutions can nations regain their sovereignty over decisions about whether their own people will live or die. Today, even for the most powerful nations, those decisions are taken finally by men and women and machines, in cities far away from their own borders.

The time has come to begin to create a third generation of world institutions. We are approaching the year 2000, which will be the start of a new century as well as the beginning of a new millennium. But we may never cross that threshold unless we find alternatives to the outdated doctrine of balance of nuclear terror and mutually assured destruction as the basis of national security. However, it is not enough to consider only measures for arms control. Disarmament, even in the relatively short term, will inevitably require that we confront the practice of war itself, because it is evident that, so long as the practice of war continues and the possibility of war remains, the motivation to do away with the instruments of war will be undermined.

Even if we could imagine that nuclear disarmament had been achieved in a world in which the vagaries of war continued, we could hardly imagine that as a stable condition. The pay-offs to a country that could secrete a few weapons would be too great. Distrust would run high, as would the likelihood of defection from an arms control agreement. If a war broke out, which might be more likely in a world where there were still wars but no nuclear weapons to induce dread, the rush to build nuclear weapons would be on again under circumstances so unpredictable that those weapons might well be used.
To that extent, those who have argued that nuclear disarmament cannot, by itself, bring peace make an important point. George Kennan put it succinctly when he said:

While the earliest possible elimination of nuclear weapons is no less vital in my eyes than it ever was, this will not be enough, in itself, to give civilisation even an adequate chance of survival. War itself, as a means of settling differences . . . will have to be in some way ruled out.

The key to the prevention of war has been acknowledged time and again by leaders and thinkers down through the centuries-from William Penn to John F. Kennedy, and from Immanuel Kant to Albert Einstein. It can be stated simply, even if it is hard to achieve: The prevention of war requires the rule of law among nations. Wars occur, whether between tribes or superpowers, when parties in conflict have no system of law between them for the just settlement of disputes. This century has seen advances in the rule of law among states; but much more remains to be done before nations can entrust their security to the reliable operation of the due process of international law and security institutions.

Regrettably, political leaders have devoted themselves in earnest to the creation and strengthening of international institutions only in the aftermath of our most devastating wars. Those who stood among the ruins of the First World War founded the League of Nations. It helped, but it was a flawed institution-a first effort which proved too weak and unreliable. The United Nations was established at the end of the Second World War. Its founders affirmed again that the key to peace is a collective will to suppress war through enforceable law among states. But the founders of the UN recognised that its charter was an incomplete document and not a final solution. They intended the UN to evolve through review conferences every 10 years. These conferences, like many of the UN's other intentions, have gone unrealised, and so the world today is left with the institutions of a global security system cast half a century ago, before the nuclear age began.

Once nuclear weapons were developed the machinery of the United Nations was left behind. The major powers quickly forgot their commitment to developing further the international legal and security apparatus of the UN and put their faith instead in nuclear deterrence and regional alliances. By the mid-1960s all expectation that the UN could prevent war and provide for the security even of non-nuclear countries had evaporated.

We certainly cannot afford a third world war to supply the political motivation needed to start thinking about a third generation of international organisations. But since the 1960s, tragically, little thinking has been done on how to create a fuller and more reliable international security system. However, there are signs today that a new generation of political leaders may at last be ready to return to the unfinished job of the founders of the UN. Many countries have begun to demonstrate a new attitude towards multilateralism. The Soviet Union has taken steps that may signal a profound shift in its attitude towards multilateral approaches. In the past six months it has gone as far as calling for improvement in the UN's peacekeeping ability, a UN role in verification and even the mandatory jurisdiction of the world court. It is also catching up with its arrears to the UN. President Reagan and General Secretary Gorbachev, in their joint statement of the summit last December, `emphasised the importance of enhancing the capacity of the United Nations and other international institutions to contribute to the resolution of regional conflicts'.

The pendulum is swinging back towards a more constructive view of the role of international organisations. In the last year we have seen the UN and multilateral efforts playing a more active role in resolving regional conflicts. Perhaps the most impressive example is the mediating efforts of the UN Secretariat for a settlement in the Afghanistan war. UN peacekeeping forces are operating now between Iran and Iraq and in Lebanon, and are likely to go to Angola. There is a growing interest in a UN sponsored conference on the Middle East dispute.

With the political climate improving for multilateralism, consideration of a third generation of international security institutions is essential, as is building the political will for their creation. Some of the most important actors on the international scene are rediscovering that their national security interests may be best served by a strengthening international system. We may have ahead of us an opening, an opportunity, which absolutely must not be missed.

I want to outline six points which I think would contribute to this third generation of international institutions. The first is a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty. A comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty would stop the development of weapons by currently non-nuclear countries and also prevent further technological escalation of the nuclear arms race. A comprehensive test ban barring testing for all nuclear and near-nuclear nations would be a monumental step towards curtailing not only the arms race but also the proliferation of nuclear weapons to other countries. Australia has for a long time been a strong opponent of nuclear proliferation on a bipartisan basis and a committed advocate of such a treaty. Continuation of such advocacy is essential.

The second proposal is opposition to star wars. One of the most dangerous policies enunciated in the last few years, principally by President Reagan, has been the so-called strategic defence initiative, or star wars. Star wars is a dangerous initiative because it involves extending the arms race to space. So far there has been no space weaponry and the anti-ballistic missile treaty has constrained research on defensive space weaponry. Star wars threatens both those limits to the arms race. Inevitably the Soviet Union is also actively researching these types of technology. A space weapons race is now under way. All Australians should wholeheartedly support the Government's opposition to this seriously threatening development. Opposition from allies of both the superpowers will constrain what they can do. Such opposition may also contribute to reducing the enormous financial and human waste which such research involves.

The third proposal is verification. A central element of a global security system must be the establishment of an international means to verify compliance with disarmament and security agreements. In a world of multilateral disarmament there will necessarily have to be a multilateral verification process. Most countries will not be satisfied to leave this to the superpowers alone. An international verification organisation would have to be able to operate through everything from satellites to on-site inspection. The information collection abilities of a verification organisation could further be used to monitor crisis areas and military build-ups. They could provide intelligence to peacekeeping forces and help them in their monitoring role. Satellite information could even be redirected towards other UN agencies to help developing countries with resource monitoring of deserts, forests and crops.

The beginnings of such an agency could be made today. Putting a multilateral verification system in place now, before the process of disarmament truly begins, would give the necessary lead time to train staff and build the confidence of states in the institution. It would also pave the way for arms control treaties that require multilateral verification by solving the verification problem in advance. Again, Australia has given a lead in verification through a lot of work that has been done here on seismic verification technology.

The fourth proposal is conflict resolution. A global security system would operate on the premise that countries would make binding commitments to settle their disputes peacefully either through mediation or through adjudication under international law. At present the UN has virtually no machinery to mediate disputes and the jurisdiction of the International Court of Justice is recognised by less than one-third of the world's countries. Obviously, stronger agreements are needed among states to improve the institutions for the peaceful settlement of disputes and to oblige states to use those institutions. Not all nations will live up to these undertakings. The enforcement of court decisions is a particularly difficult issue which must receive careful and creative attention.

The fifth proposal is peacekeeping. Unless countries can feel secure with the guarantee of international military protection, it seems likely that they will continue to amass national militaries as large as they can afford. Disarmament requires that there be assurances for countries fearing an attack that the international community will not fail to defend them and assert the rule of law. I dealt in a similar speech last week with the importance of building up UN peacekeeping forces.
The sixth proposal is that it is necessary that there be reliable and substantial revenues for these activities. Without such revenue it will be impossible for these activities to be assured.

This summary of the functional requirements gives some idea of the range of issues which must be addressed in the creation of a global security system. Many ideas have been put forward on all of these issues. It is vital that we develop the third generation of multilateral institutions which are necessary for creating conditions for strong global security.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion, and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) for his very commendable, albeit idealistic, motion. I agree in large part with the general thrust of the motion but it will come as no surprise to him that I disagree with his comments on the strategic defence initiative (SDI), or Star Wars aspects. I would like to say a few words in the time that is allotted to me and in particular, I would like to draw heavily on, in my view, the recent highly persuasive views of the American Secretary of State, George Shultz.

SPEECH.PARA: Twenty-five years ago experts assumed that the spread of nuclear weapons was inexorable. They predicted that between 15 and 25 countries would have nuclear weapons by the late 1980s. These earlier prophets of gloom did not anticipate the ability of countries, such as the United States of America of President Reagan, and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics of Secretary-General Gorbachev, to control this threat to world peace through a web of institutional arrangements, through legal commitments, through technological safeguards and through alternative security means. They did not understand that the will of people throughout the world is embedded heavily in the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons.

In promoting non-proliferation efforts we should be mindful of the underlying reality that basic nuclear knowledge cannot be kept secret. The futility of trying to do so was recognised by President Eisenhower in 1953 when he proposed a program of international nuclear cooperation-the fundamental principle behind the creation of the International Atomic Energy Agency and the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, which is that peaceful nuclear development can be secured by agreement not to engage in the development of nuclear weapons. However, stopping the spread of nuclear weapons and weapons technology is, in my view, not enough. The Reagan Administration has worked hard and, I suggest, quite successfully, on arms reduction agreements through creative and sustained diplomatic dialogue which has led to fair and mutually beneficial agreements to provide for greater international security-in other words, substantive achievement through a combination of strength and diplomacy.

But arms control and arms reduction are not enough. There have to be unprecedented efforts on all aspects of human rights, bilateral relations, arms control and regional conflicts. I would suggest that the starting point is the concept of President Reagan, agreed to by Soviet Leader Gorbachev at their first meeting in Geneva in 1985, that nuclear war must never be unleashed and there can be no victors in it; that any conflict between the USSR and the USA could have catastrophic consequences, hence there was a necessity to prevent any war, nuclear or conventional, between them; and that both sides would seek not to attain military superiority.

To this end the USA has negotiated the historic intermediate-range nuclear force agreement-or INF agreement-the first agreement to require reductions in nuclear arsenals rather than simply slowing down increases in nuclear capability. This sets out to eliminate an entire class of nuclear weapons. It reduces and reshapes nuclear arsenals, it has rigorous provisions of inspection, monitoring and data exchange which will result in effective verification and, of course, it sets valuable precedents for future agreements. These provisions will produce openness and cooperative contacts on sensitive military matters that, over time, will, in my view, profoundly affect how the superpowers perceive one another.

The strategic arms reduction talks-or START-are pursuing this course of reducing nuclear arms. This has proceeded a long way down the road towards completing a treaty calling for 50 per cent reductions in strategic offensive arms, although some key issues remain unresolved. But the outlines of the agreement and many of its details are already in place, providing a sound basis for completing the treaty early in the Bush Administration. With the indulgence of the House I would like to congratulate President-elect Bush on yesterday's result.

START will contribute to the policy of deterrence. It will require substantial reductions in both US and Soviet forces, including a 50 per cent reduction in Soviet heavy intercontinental ballistic missiles. Its objective is to stabilise reductions, structured so as to decrease incentives to launch an attack. The draft treaty being worked out in Geneva will do just that. The sooner it is completed the better off we will all be.

Continued efforts on non-proliferation and intensified negotiations on arms control and arms reductions can help meet the challenges of the nuclear age. However, two new dangers appear. The first is the increasing availability on the world arms market of relatively long range surface to surface missiles. Weaponry of enormous destructive potential is reaching the hands of parties with little regard for traditional inhibiting controls. I am reluctant to single out areas but I think we have to look towards the Middle East. Secondly, the renewal of chemical warfare would surely be the most despicable and abhorrent development of our day. Nations are now confronted by violations of the oldest and most widely observed arms control agreement-the 1925 Geneva protocol that prohibits poisonous gas and chemical warfare. I regret that the scourge is spreading and the protocol is repeatedly being violated.

The most frightening nightmare would be the eventual combination of chemical warheads on ballistic missiles in the hands of states with little regard for international opposition to their use. For this reason, the United States has taken the lead to curb the proliferation of both technologies. In bilateral talks with the Soviets and in the United Nations Committee on Disarmament there have been negotiations on a comprehensive chemical warfare ban based on a United States draft convention tabled in 1984. On 26 September last, President Reagan called for a conference of parties to the 1925 Geneva protocol and other concerned states to strengthen norms against the use of those abhorrent weapons. This conference will be held in Paris in early January.

The efforts of the superpowers in non-proliferation, in arms control and in arms reduction have helped to confront the challenges of the past and those of today. George Shultz suggests seven ingredients for success in confronting the challenges that lie ahead of us. Today time does not allow me to go into those in detail other than to mention point 7, in which he stated:

. . . we need to establish priorities. NATO's ministers agreed in June 1987 that the leading arms control tasks for the period ahead were concluding a S.T.A.R.T. agreement, achieving a more stable balance of conventional forces, and negotiating an effectively verifiable global ban on chemical weapons.
It seems to me that those priorities are very sound. In addition, George Shultz stated:
. . . we must continue to strengthen our efforts against the proliferation of nuclear weapons and other destabilizing weapons technologies.
In conclusion, on the point of SDI or star wars I would like to quote from President Reagan's State of the Nation address in 1986 where he said:

As I told the British Parliament in 1982, we seek to rid the world of the two great nightmares of the postwar era-the threat of nuclear war and the threat of totalitarianism. And that's why, by pursuing SDI, which is a defense against offensive missiles, and by going for arms reduction rather than just arms control, we are moving away from the so-called policy of mutual assured destruction-
or MAD-

by which nations hold each other hostage to nuclear terror and destruction. So, too, we are saying that the postwar policy of containment is no longer enough; that the goal of American foreign policy is both world peace and world freedom; that as a people, we hope and will work for a day when all of God's children will enjoy the human dignity that their Creator intended.
I thank the House for its time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Ms C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to second this motion. I thank the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) for the opportunity. I also thank him for the benefit of his earlier contribution to the debate. I am sorry that I cannot agree with the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor) on the question of the strategic defence initiative. I do not believe that Star Wars has any future, nor should it in this universe. We do not want to establish a system which will put nuclear weapons into space. I certainly do not agree with that.

SPEECH.PARA: In seconding this motion, I totally endorse the sentiments expressed by the honourable member for Fraser in his motion and in his speech. It was an excellent speech, a far-sighted speech, and one which expresses sentiments that we ought to hear more often in this House and around the nation. I think people have to start thinking about new generations of international bodies that can deal with the problems confronting the world today.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was statesmanlike.
—It was very statesmanlike; I thank the honourable member. The honourable member for Throsby has sat in the chamber and listened to the speeches, and he is now making his own contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: If the nations of the world are to pursue lasting peace and stability, they must work together with greater cooperation and understanding. Armaments are a symptom of the suspicion and distrust which exists in international relationships, as much as they are a hangover of an expansionist past era. Agreements to reduce arms must not be seen in isolation. People and nations have to learn to resolve their differences in non-violent ways. Mediation, compromise and cooperation must be firmly implanted in the international lexicon if we are ever to reduce the occurrence of conflict and war. Without an improvement in trust disarmament will not be possible. Trust of each other is important, but trust of an independent arbiter is even more so as a transitional arrangement, especially for the resolution of disputes or the verification of disarmament agreements.

Effective international verification will require the pursuit of possibly intrusive inspections in a number of sensitive technical areas. The complexity of obtaining workable verification agreements was recently outlined in an article by Lynn Hansen, the Assistant Director of the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency. It was pointed out in the article that both the Stockholm document and the intermediate-range nuclear forces agreements, the United States-Soviet Union treaty on the elimination of intermediate range and shorter range missiles, were reasonably simple to verify-the former because, while it involves 35 states, it demands an annual calendar listing of notifiable and observable events such as troop and equipment movements in Europe, and the latter because it involves only two nations and covers the complete elimination of a specific category of weapon which is produced only for military purposes. Sadly, I do not think we can expect such simplicity to recur in the international disarmament scene.

Lynn Hansen went on to contrast the verification procedures of the two agreements with those that would be required with the proposed agreement on strategic arms reduction and the prospective comprehensive global ban on chemical weapons, which the 40-nation Geneva Conference on Disarmament is currently negotiating. They would certainly be considerably more comprehensive and intrusive and require the establishment of an acceptable, independent, international verification agency to be successful. The United Nations is currently the only body with any ability to carry out such a task. I agree with the member for Fraser's comments on the shortcomings of the United Nations, and I also believe that its role requires recasting.
On 18 February 1988 a Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister proposed to the new session of the United Nations Convention on Disarmament.

The States participating in the talks agree to allocate each, on a voluntary basis, one facility at which a specially formed international expert group would test procedures being developed at the negotiations for systematic international monitoring over the non-production of chemical weapons in the commercial industry.
That is where the problem will lie.

However, the United States remains concerned about Soviet trustworthiness and is also increasingly worried about achieving a wide measure of ratification by a number of other countries and verifying their compliance. Of all the actual and potential arms control agreements, the chemical weapons convention probably poses the greatest difficulties for verification because it is potentially so easy to hide the manufacture of chemical weapons within normal industries, chemical production and because so many countries possess the capability for chemical weapon production. However, that is no reason for us in Australia, or for international bodies, to stop seeking a verification mechanism.

There is little point in calling for disarmament on a world scale if a peaceful means of settling disputes cannot be devised. There are a number of ways for countries to solve conflicts between themselves, starting with direct negotiations and including the various United Nations mechanisms. The International Court of Justice stands out as the pre-eminent place to find a solution, if countries are willing to accept its jurisdiction and verdict which sadly they have not always been willing to do in the past. Widespread acceptance is the key point of any such judicial system and it is the major weakness of all international bodies. International law attempts to regulate the actions of states, primarily their external relations with other states and much less so their internal activities. The nation state stands as the most significant political entity in people's experience and they are resistant to proposals which seem to restrict their state's power. However, I submit to the House that this has to cease in the future, and people and nations must learn to trust an independent international body.

The value of a stronger system of international law would be that states could settle their disputes at lower cost and less disruption to their internal policies, except where their internal policy is based upon external aggression. States would know that their neighbours were subject to the same processes and restrictions and could set aside their fears of violent intervention. Trust in the system, as I said earlier, is crucial and depends upon agreed principles being followed and enforced upon all. The International Court of Justice suffers because countries are willing to use it for cases which favour their position, yet deny its jurisdiction in cases where it rules against them. Enforcement has always been a problem for international agreements and judgments because enforcement agencies are state based, which blurs the distinction between international enforcement and the interest of the states involved. This has been accentuated by the tendency of states to lend support when, and only when, they agree with the action; that is, sadly, the interest of the state remains paramount over the wider issue of world good and world peace.

Forty years ago an active collective security role was envisaged for the United Nations. The formation of rigid Eastern and Western blocs and the development of the Cold War prevented articles 39 to 51 of the charter ever being developed in the way originally foreseen. The United Nations, or a body extending from it, should be given the teeth and the authority it needs to resolve disputes between nations.

The continued acquisition of conventional and nuclear arms poses a threat to prospects for economic development, as well as world peace, particularly in the Third World. Between 5 per cent and 8 per cent of the world's total output had been allocated to military purposes over the past 30 years. The Third World accounted for 75 per cent of all conventional arms imports during the 1970s, such purchases being made at the expense of limited foreign reserves and the well-being of their indigenous populations. Those familiar with elementary economics will recognise the classic opportunity cost scenario involved; that is, guns or butter. It could just as well be guns or bread, guns or schools, or guns or housing, for these are more likely to be the choices which are made when military expenditure comes up against the practical requirements of a poverty-stricken Third World population.

As well as the measures outlined in the motion being debated, there is a role for Australia in convincing the World Bank or the International Monetary Fund to take action to ensure that military budgets in debt-burdened developing countries are kept to a minimum so as to maximise the benefit to economic development of moneys made available. This matter has been discussed in the United Nations over a number of years. I think the concept of an international development fund was first raised in 1955. The idea is worth reconsidering, given the change in the climate of international affairs and also the change in economic development in the international scene. The improvement in international relations, particularly between the United States and the Soviet Union, is noteworthy and laudable. I believe that the United Nations, or the third generation world institution proposed by the honourable member for Fraser, has a role to play in maintaining the existing climate of compromise and change. Australia should use its influence in international affairs to promote the United Nations as an independent arbiter which can be trusted in order to maintain the momentum for a peaceful world.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the one or two minutes remaining, let me just say that there are a couple of members and senators in this Parliament about whom in can be said that they are committed peacemakers. The honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) is one of them. I commend him for bringing this motion before the House. One of the unfortunate realities of the 40-year debate on nuclear weapons around the world has been that people committed to a just, free and peaceful world have differing views as to which paths to that world are right and prudent. They do not acknowledge one another's good faith. I am sorry that that intruded a little into this debate today. There is a view-and it is one which I share; I hope in the future to be able to expand on it-that in the dialectical process of debate between doves and hawks, what eventuates is a policy for wise owls. I hope that that will be the end product of the debate which is about to conclude and which will continue at some future time. I will reserve the rest of my comments for when the debate resumes at a later date.

—The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday. The honourable member for Macquarie will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Rothwells Ltd-Tasmania-Visits by Warships-Media-Drug Abuse-Nursing Homes-Queensland Government-

PROCTEXT.PARA: X-Rated Videos
Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today in this grievance debate I would like to talk about the situation in Western Australia. I was never particularly enamoured of the Brian Burke style, but I want to place on record my support for the actions of the Government with respect to the rescue operations it was forced to undertake, especially the decision to guarantee Rothwells Ltd following the stock market collapse of 1987. One Liberal senator said to me yesterday, `You won't hear me criticising the Government over the Rothwells decision, as I believe that there was no way it could have known it was anything other than a liquidity crisis'. In any case, I believe that the Government had very little choice. Had it allowed Rothwells to go under, there is simply no way of knowing where the panic would have stopped. There could have been as many as 7,000 jobs lost, not to mention the 10,000 investors, large and small, who made up the shareholders of that bank. The investors include church and charitable organisations and local government authorities. There is no doubt that, had they lost their money, the Government would have had to meet a lot of the costs for services they now provide. So the Government would have had substantial demands imposed upon it. The Government was damned if it did and damned if it did not.

SPEECH.PARA: If one looks at the editorials of the time, one will see that even the hypocritical, smug and sanctimonious publication the West Australian, on 17 October 1987, when commenting on the possible effects of a Rothwells collapse, stated:
. . . and that would have been little short of disastrous for business and the economy as a whole.
The economics observer Max Walsh, on the 7.30 Report, said:

There was a risk of a crisis of confidence, in Perth in particular, and as we saw in that report there a significant number of people who doubtless were quite important employers in Perth are dependers upon finance from Rothwells to keep going and so it could have had a domino effect . . .

Those are the considerations that the Government had to take into consideration when it looked at this issue in a very short period, over a weekend. Even the Leader of the Opposition agreed that something should have been done for Rothwells. He said:
. . . Allan Bond, Laurie Connell and others who put their money on the line, I think they are to be congratulated.

It is interesting to note that at the time he also said that he believed that there had been no mismanagement of Rothwells. The Executive Director of the Confederation of Western Australian Industry, Mr Bill Brown, said of the Government's involvement:
. . . this seems to be a prudent exercise in damage control and not for the sake of the particular company but for the sake of the wider community.

The more than $200m committed by leading Australians as part of the October rescue package appears to have been swallowed up. The Government was advised that its $150m guarantee would be unlikely to be called upon. As Premier Dowding has said, only a full investigation by the liquidator will reveal the full details of what happened. That investigation is being held. However, by earlier this year, Rothwells appeared to be benefiting from a restructure and the consolidated financial statements for the half year ended 31 January and released in March showed that the company was in a sound position.

With the benefit of hindsight, it is all too easy to say that the Government should not have become involved. I reject this argument because I believe that the Government has nothing to be ashamed of. All the decisions were made on commercial grounds. As I have already observed, there was a very substantial cost in the Government simply doing nothing. As it was, over 8,500 of the 10,000 investors have been able to get their money out. Any small investors who left their money in really deserve no sympathy because the Government has been sending out signs that only the stupid or the greedy could have ignored.

The woman who was recently featured on the front page of the West Australian, lamenting that she had lost her life savings, had taken her money out and then put it back in again. That the West Australian should feature her says more about the west than it does about anything else. The Fairfax Press can be discounted, because little Lord Fairfax is locked in a court battle with Laurie Connell over the payment of fees he incurred when this born-again egomaniac tried to take over the family newspaper.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest to the honourable member that he may be transgressing on matters that are sub judice.
—No, I do not think so, but I will leave those things for the court to decide. That is why there is a vested interest on the part of the Fairfax group in discrediting Rothwells.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to return to the hypocrisy of the west as I see it. Let us look at what is happening in Western Australia. As a result of the Government's action-timely action, I would say-to limit the damage that was done on that occasion, the taxpayer will not be called upon to make any additional payment. That is not to say that there will not be a cost; there is potential for a cost. The potential cost to the Government ranges between virtually nothing and $100m. But it is not money that can be called on to be made up by the taxpayer. Yet we see in the west and in other places people jumping on the bandwagon in a most blatantly political manner. I can excuse the Opposition for being political and short-sighted and engaging in all sorts of outrageous and high-flown rhetoric. That is what we expect of it; that is what we are used to. I had hoped that we could have expected more from the only daily newspaper in Western Australia.

Let us contrast the situation with that which occurred under the Court Government when Charlie Court, against the advice of every competent consultant, signed a contract with Woodside Petroleum Ltd-a very small and, in those days, quite obscure explorer-to supply gas to Perth on a take-or-pay contract at prices substantially more than the ruling rates and then to build a pipeline at taxpayers' expense. That exercise had the potential to cost the taxpayers of Western Australia $7 billion. I have copies of all the papers that detail the dilemma in which the Government was left. The Western Australian Government has had to renegotiate many of those leases and has certainly been able to contain the cost. But the cost is still substantial and it is being met by the taxpayers of Western Australia, who are paying more for their gas and electricity. So the people of Western Australia are paying for this piece of madness by Sir Charles Court. It is, incidentally, a decision that makes gas in the Pilbara more expensive than gas in the metropolitan area. It is this, principally, that has precluded the development of a chemical industry in the Pilbara.

We have heard nothing from the West Australian on this. It has accepted this and, in fact, it has lauded it as an example of development. It was a foolhardy development, a development whose time had not yet come. The Western Australian Government has taken a very responsible attitude on this. The Liberal Party of Australia obviously felt that it could get out of it by simply closing down the coal industry in Western Australia, which would have had a traumatic effect on the 2,000 jobs involved-even if we disregard the fact that we would have had to pay much more for the electricity generated by gas. It is a wasteful way to use gas, which is certainly much more expensive than coal.

The Australian Labor Party has opted to maintain the more efficient coal industry and to seek to use the gas by renegotiating the contract and by developing a petrochemical industry in Perth. This is a sensible decision which will provide jobs to the community and contribute to the overall wealth of the State. This is the sort of leadership that the Labor Party in Western Australia has shown and is being criticised for. I am not saying that the Government has not made mistakes; it clearly has. But they have been mistakes of commission, and the Government has done these things in the best interests of the State and getting it moving. This attitude compares very well with that of the previous Government. It could be argued that when Mr Mensaros was the Minister he was acting, in a sense, from a limited information base.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I promised a couple of people that I would not talk about Tasmania, but I will. Let me say from the beginning that I have been here for 13 years and I have never known of very much personal stuff being thrown around this House. The amount that has been thrown around this House has not been liked by the majority of us. I could name a couple of occasions but I will not. It saddens me to think of what has happened in my State of Tasmania. I do not want to allot any blame in Tasmania. I remember when I was first married a long time ago.
—Where were you married?
—I was married in Tasmania and we were only very young at the time.
—You are still young, Bruce.

—I thank the good hockey player, the honourable member for Perth. We lived opposite a nice young couple and we got on extremely well with them. They became friends. I remember walking into a shop, and before I could ask for what I wanted the shopkeeper said to me, `Have you heard such and such about your friend opposite?'. I said, `I am sorry. I am not interested in that'. As a matter of fact, I said to my wife when I went back home, `We won't go into that shop any more'.

SPEECH.PARA: Rumour and innuendo can kill people and make it very difficult. We are all sinners in this place. So are the people in the gallery. There is nobody in this place who is not a sinner; rest assured of that. When people start throwing stones they have to be very careful. I have had my arguments with the Premier of that State; I argue with everybody. What has happened in that State and what I read in the papers today absolutely shocked me and made me feel sick inside about the sort of level we can get down to in the political arena. I am not going to allot blame. I do not know who started it in Tasmania. Some of the people in Tasmania ought to be ashamed of themselves-on both sides of politics, both north and south. It is sometimes a rotten State-that State I love so much. Tasmania's parochialism sometimes kills a lot of good people.

I read of what has happened in Tasmania as I ate my breakfast in my room today, as I drank a nice cup of coffee and an orange juice, and I thought to myself, `Boy! What's happening in my State of Tasmania?' I felt sorry for the Premier of Tasmania but I felt very sorry for his wife, Judy, who is in hospital at the moment recuperating from a fearful accident which has left her with many broken bones. To read of and hear of what I saw in the paper today appals me. To think that we have got down to that sort of a level. We are making it very difficult for ourselves. Once one starts throwing a bit of dirt, a little bit comes back, and more goes over. There are lots of people in the Tasmanian Parliament who are sinners just like we are. So when one starts throwing it around one has to be very, very careful. My heart goes out to Judy Gray and her family and my heart goes out to the Premier of the State, irrespective of whom he was or whom he is.

I think that we have started on something, and so have the media. They love a bit of gossip down in Tasmania, and they love it everywhere. Regrettably, it hurts and it hurts a lot of very good people and if we started it in this House, God help us! It has been started and thank God it was curtailed fairly quickly. We do not want any more of it because once it starts it is very hard to stop and we are not liked by the people outside. They do not like politicians any more. There is enough going on up in Queensland to make one wonder where it is all going to finish. I am not allotting blame up there but once it starts, once we start bringing ourselves into disrepute, once we start allotting blame and start getting personal about the lives of ourselves and our wives and our families, we are in real strife. A lot of people out there would love to bring us down to the lowest common denominator and if they get a little inch they will take a proverbial mile.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is just as well that you are squeaky clean.
—I am not squeaky clean and you know it. You are not squeaky clean, either, and you know it.
—Order! The honourable member will address the chamber through the Chair.

—Okay, but I know that he meant that only in jest. We are none of us squeaky clean and that is the reason I am saying that I feel sorry for the poor Premier of Tasmania and his wife. I cannot express exactly how she must feel. I know that he is in it; he is at the top of the scale; he is the leader and he has to take it and regrettably it is not very nice.

SPEECH.PARA: I will get off that and back on to Tasmania again.

TALK.START.PARA: —A great place.

—It is a great place. I have noted that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) applauded the introduction of the Wesley Vale Mill in Tasmania; a consortium between Australian and Canadian interests that will provide 2,500 jobs for Tasmanians. I have said before that Tasmania today is being dominated by single issue politicians who do not really worry about all the problems that we have, but to suit their cause they become very vocal. Regrettably the media give them a hell of a lot of attention and sometimes forget the bread and butter politicians who are trying to make the lot of Tasmanians a little bit better.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members know that I disagree with the Prime Minister most of the time, but he did say publicly that it was good for Tasmania that there were to be 2,500 jobs provided. Here is going to be one of the biggest consortiums and one of the biggest enterprises commenced in Tasmania. What happened? I waited for it and sure enough they came out of the woodwork; Dr Bob Brown-and I am not being personal-and Bates. I could name them every time. I do not even have to look at the newspapers. They are back into it again. The protest rallies begin; 2,000 people protest in Sydney. What the hell would the people of Sydney know about Tasmania? The greenies up there did enough damage over the dam. They stopped that and they have stopped nearly all the timber industry in Tasmania.

Good, hardworking Tasmanians are being protested against by some proverbial socialists or greenies or whatever you like to call them up in Sydney. Two thousand of them rallied up there and 500 rallied in Melbourne to stop the Wesley Vale Mill that is going to employ 2,500 Tasmanians and provide a lot of work. The Prime Minister said it was great; it was great for Tasmania. I saw it, I read it, I heard it. Right, that is number one. Huon Valley is in my electorate. They are at it down there too. They are trying to get a chip mill down there. They are trying to get a licence. They are doing everything humanly possible to make it easy for the people of the Huon.

They are trying to provide jobs where there is high unemployment. But the same group is active again, the same single issue politicians, the same ones who have protested year after year and have put Tasmania behind, have made it a laughing stock for the rest of Australia. They have created us with two heads and six fingers and have made it difficult for us to provide jobs for our families and those ordinary hard working people down there.

I note that somebody is coming from overseas, a Mr Clive Jenkins who has always looked like the cat who got all the cream. Clive Jenkins looks like a cat which has cornered the international market in dairy produce. A trade union man, he is coming from England to settle on the east coast of Tasmania, being given a grant by the Federal Government. I ask the question: Why a grant for him? The trouble with this damn place is that you cannot get up to ask a question; once a year you get called to ask a question. I would like to ask the Prime Minister: why a grant for this fellow coming from England, who failed over there? He is settling in Tasmania; he is going to get involved with the Wilderness Society; he is going to get involved with the trade union movement in Australia.
He failed over there yet the Government has given him a grant to go round. I would like to ask the question why and a lot of Tasmanians would like to ask the question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Write a letter and you will get the answer.

—I will get the answer, do not worry about that. But I want to find out why this bloke is coming down there thinking he knows all about Tasmania; coming to create trouble, that is all. He failed in England and now he is going to retire in Tasmania like that stupid Bellamy did, like Yehudi Menuhin, the great violinist. Like Prince Charles or Prince Phillip-whatever his name is-they are the ones who say they know all about Tasmania. They know nothing about Tasmania and, remember, I am here to try to get jobs for my family and the families of ordinary working people of Tasmania.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Recently there has been much comment, both in the press and this Parliament, on the issue of visits by nuclear capable warships to Australian ports. The Opposition has repeatedly attacked this Government over our handling of this issue, in particular with regard to the treatment of the British aircraft carrier Ark Royal. According to the Opposition, this Government has failed to fulfil obligations to our allies on defence cooperation.

SPEECH.PARA: Rarely did the arguments of the Opposition raise any new points on this issue. The whole exercise seemed to be just another opportunity for the honourable members opposite to publicly prostrate themselves before our allies. Their actions can only serve to give comfort to a lunatic fringe element on the right of the political spectrum in Australia which continually hinders rational debate on these issues. For example, on 28 October that infamous right wing rag, News Weekly, published an article on the visit of Ark Royal to Australia. It was titled `Moscow's hand behind ban on Ark Royal'. Someone perhaps needs to inform the cold war warriors at News Weekly that this year is 1988, not 1954.

I do not propose to waste the time of the House responding to such absurdities. The issue of whether or not we should allow nuclear capable warships into our harbours has often been canvassed in this place and government policy on that issue is clear to everyone. However, the issue of safety plans in the event of an accident involving one of these warships in our harbour remains a vexed question and it is this issue which I wish to address in the time given to me today, particularly the state of accident planning in the Port of Sydney.

The first concern to be expressed with regard to accident planning for the Port of Sydney is that no plan is publicly available. Presumably the purpose of an accident plan is the protection of the residents of Sydney in the event of an accident involving a nuclear capable warship. Yet it seems that the residents of Sydney are not to be informed of the details of this plan unless the worst possible scenario arises.

This state of affairs could hardly be described as forward planning, as the term would normally be understood. The reason given by the Greiner Government for refusing to release details of the plan is security. What an utterly ludicrous excuse. There is no suggestion from any quarter that in the process of releasing details of an accident plan there would be any need to release military or nuclear secrets. Clearly the New South Wales Government would not be privy to any United States military secrets anyway, so it would be impossible for them to be released as part of an accident plan.

All that needs to be released are clear details of potential evacuation plans for the population in harbourside suburbs and some details of the coordination of civilian emergency services. Failure to release such details raises the clear suspicion that no plan exists. However, plans by Australian officials to cope with any disaster are only one side of this issue. We must also ask what actions would be taken by the nation whose warship was involved in any accident and, importantly, how the efforts of Australian and foreign officials could be coordinated to best cope with an emergency situation.

It is the Navy of the United States that poses the greatest possibility of either a nuclear fuel or a nuclear weapons accident in both Australian waters and the Pacific as a whole. There is reason for grave concern as to how the United States would respond in the event of an accident involving one of its warships. This concern exists for a number of reasons. It is well known that the policy of the United States in relation to its nuclear capable warships is neither to confirm nor deny whether nuclear weapons are being carried by those vessels at any particular time. What is perhaps less well known is that in the event of an accident involving one of those vessels it is likely that the United States Navy will continue neither to confirm nor deny whether nuclear weapons have been involved in the accident, thus making it impossible for local emergency services to assess the danger of radiation spills. Indeed, it has been reported by the United States Defence Nuclear Agency that, in an exercise conducted by the United States military in 1983 which simulated an accident involving nuclear weapons, it was the practice of military officials to spread false public information in order to divert attention from the nuclear spill.

It must be remembered that in the event of a nuclear accident security remains the top priority of the United States military officials. The protection of local populations is subordinate to this consideration. Another area of concern in relation to the response of the United States in the event of an accident is its policy of immediately sealing off the area of the accident and allowing access only to United States military personnel. This is consistent with the United States objective of preserving security in relation to its nuclear forces, but raises huge problems for local emergency services in the event of an accident. They may simply be refused access to the site.

In an accident involving nuclear forces on United States territory, the immediate area of the accident is defined as being all areas giving direct visual access to the accident, including air space up to 5,000 feet above the accident site. This is the area that is sealed off. Is this also to be the case in the event of an accident on Australian territory?

The security of the area around an accident is taken most seriously. In 1981 exercises were held in the United States to simulate a nuclear accident. A number of military personnel were assigned the role of demonstrators. In the words of the United States Defence Nuclear Agency report on these exercises, it was simulated that one demonstrator was shot. All these facts raise an urgent question. In the event of an accident involving a United States nuclear warship in one of our ports, are we expected to temporarily relinquish sovereignty over the site of the accident and its surrounding area? Are we expected to entrust the protection of our harbours and surrounding populations to United States military officials who have as their top priority the protection of the United States nuclear secrets?

This would seem to be a heavy price to pay for the alliance. It is in fact a gamble. We are hoping that in the event of an accident there will be no great conflict between the interests of the Australian people and the interests of the United States military. On the balance of previous evidence this seems to be a very doubtful gamble indeed. In its 1981 report, the United States Defence Nuclear Agency recommended that joint exercises should be held between the United States military and any nations that host United States nuclear forces to prepare for any potential accidents. To date this certainly does not seem to have occurred in Australia. Indeed, the United States Navy has not held a major exercise designed to plan for the problems of nuclear accidents since 1983, let alone holding joint exercises with host nations.

This is despite the fact that the handling of nuclear weapons at sea is, as acknowledged in the words of the United States Navy manual, `One of the most hazardous of all shipboard operations', because it `contains all the dangers found in conventional ammunition transfer plus the grave consequences of accidental loss or contamination'. How much greater is the risk of an accident in a crowded port, as opposed to the open sea? We should be seeking to hold joint exercises as soon as possible. Only this can guarantee the development of an adequate contingency plan for it to cope with an accident in our ports.

It is frequently the case that those of us who question the wisdom of visits to our ports by nuclear capable ships are accused of sticking our heads in the sand, or of attempting to abdicate our responsibilities under the ANZUS agreement. I would argue that it is equally a case of sticking our heads in the sand to pretend that nuclear capable warships in our harbours are not carrying nuclear weapons. It is an abdication of responsibility to pretend that they do not pose a potential threat and it is naive to think that the Greiner Government in New South Wales has the capacity or the political will to devise an effective emergency plan to deal with that threat.

For too long the debate over visits to our ports by nuclear capable warships has been narrowed to the question of whether we allow the visits to continue or whether we ban them. Too little attention has been given to safety aspects. I am pleased to note in this regard that the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence has been conducting an inquiry for some time in this area. I am certain that its work will prove to be of great value.

In 1976 the Fraser Government produced guidelines for the visits of nuclear warships to Australian ports, after that Government took the decision once again to allow those warships to visit Australian ports. These guidelines were supposedly the result of exhaustive consultation and research. Part of this process involved sending a delegation to the United States, the United Kingdom and France. The purpose of this delegation, which left Australia in 1972, was ostensibly to investigate safety aspects of nuclear-powered and capable warships.

Documents published in June 1987 showed that this delegation was able to do nothing of the sort. Security restrictions, particularly in the United States, meant that it was able to investigate nothing about safety aspects of nuclear-powered warships. It was in fact limited to `The investigation of overseas policies regarding acceptance of nuclear propelled merchant ships and the study of the status of light-water reactors'. Is this any base on which to build an adequate set of guidelines for dealing with the dangers posed by nuclear warships?

The situation that currently exists in this country in relation to contingency plans for a nuclear accident is seriously inadequate. We cannot allow ourselves to rely upon a foreign government to have as a primary concern the protection of populations potentially affected by an accident.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, tomorrow Australia commemorates Armistice Day, or Remembrance Day, and we recall the end of World War I but we also think of the tragedy of World War II. Fifty years ago today in the early hours of 10 November 1938 the nazis burned down the synagogues throughout the length and breadth of Germany. Jews were murdered and injured and their homes were destroyed by violent racists. The streets were littered with broken glass and the nazis called it Kristallnacht-Crystal Night. Many Australians alive today remember that and they remember even worse. There are examples of nazi racism fresh in the minds of many Australians today and, of course, six million Jews died in the Holocaust which demonstrated humanity's inhumanity far more horrifically than ever it has been demonstrated in humanity's cruel history.

SPEECH.PARA: Australians died in World War I in the hope that no further wars of that magnitude would arise again. But less than 30 years later one did, caused by the same power which had caused World War I. Allied losses are frequently repeated but it is often overlooked in the West that 20 million Soviet citizens died as well. How did it happen? Analyses often refer to the severity of allied reparations, coupled with the Depression which provided ground which was fertile for the rise of nazism. But its rise was certainly facilitated by a massive concentration of media ownership which served the cause of the nazis very well.

David Bowman has just reminded us again of this in his book released this week entitled The Captive Press. Rupert Murdoch, the American newspaper publisher, said at Victoria Falls in Zimbabwe on 6 October of this year that the media must watch politicians, but Bowman asks what is really the age old question: `Who guards the guardians?' Who watches the Press? Who watches the media?'.

I have warned repeatedly in this House and elsewhere in Australia in the last two years that once this Government started pandering to greedy media proprietors we were in danger of having no-one to watch either the government or the media. Now Bond has been caught out at the very kind of behaviour which I have warned of in this place and elsewhere. David Bowman calmly reminds us that the concentration of ownership of a narrow and unrepresentative press worked against democracy in Germany after World War I. We would be mad to ignore that lesson. Bowman warns:

When governments and media proprietors can be mates we have a conspiracy at the expense of the public. Perhaps a new generation of politicians will have the guts to do something about the rod that Hawke and Keating have made for their country.

There must be no perhaps about it, Mr Deputy Speaker. The concentration of both print and television ownership must be reduced greatly if our basic right to information is to be enhanced and preserved. I ask all who are here today and listening today to recall Kristallnacht and tomorrow when remembering our fallen to ponder the link between a press mouthing its own interests hand in hand with its mates in government and the disinformation which can cover up criminal conduct, produce internal conflict, or even get us into a war.

Only a resounding demonstration of public concern is likely to produce a government courageous enough to fragment the concentration of media ownership which this Labor Government has gleefully and irresponsibly created and permitted. Caucus asked for the Trade Practices Commission to conduct an inquiry into the concentration of print media ownership but the Trade Practices Commission's request for more resources was rejected by the Government and so nothing will be done.

This Government has sold its soul. It has forgotten history. This Government is trying to prove that George Bernard Shaw was right when he said that we learn from history that we learn nothing from history. But we must never forget the Holocaust and the horrors of war. Australia must do all that it can to help the President-elect, Mr Bush, and the Secretary-General, Mr Gorbachev, to continue the process of disarmament. We must continue to remember the horrors of war so that no future generation will find glamour in war. We must continue to remember the Holocaust so that those sick revisionists who say that it could not happen and did not happen are exposed as liars and apologists for racism.

We must continue to celebrate the heroes of the Holocaust such as Schindler and Wallenberg. Some of us have had the privilege of going to Yad Vascheun in Jerusalem and seeing the memorial, the museum for the Holocaust. Those who cannot do that ought to go to the Holocaust museum in Elsternwick, in my electorate. The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), who is at the table, and I were there at the opening of that museum. Apathy is our enemy. We have to keep informed. If we are apathetic about our freedoms, they will soon be eroded. If we do not have free media, we cannot be informed, and if we are not informed we cannot decide objectively what is correct.

Professor Ian Kershaw from Nottingham University reminds us of the horrific consequences of the interaction of a racist totalitarian regime with a compliant, concentrated media ownership. Writing in the Guardian in London, and it is reproduced in the Canberra Times on Tuesday of this week, Professor Kershaw has this to say:

However widespread anti-Semitism had become in Germany, the German people had been found wanting-in the eyes of Nazi leadership-in their reactions to Kristallnacht. They had not shown the necessary `understanding' for these `radical measures' against the Jews.
