Years of Nazi propaganda had unquestionably deepened anti-Jewish feeling in Germany, but it had not produced in most Germans the depths of inhumanity sufficient to approve of open violence against the Jews.

The lessons drawn were twofold. Anti-Jewish propaganda would have had to be intensified to prepare people better for the merciless treatment of the remaining Jews in Germany, and (once war had begun) in the conquered territories. At the same time, Jewish policy had now to be carried out in a coordinated fashion and in conditions of the greatest secrecy. Control over that policy was now to be centralised in the hands of the SS.

The organisational framework within which the `final solution' would be implemented was put in place after Kristallnacht had revealed to the Nazi leadership the limits of an uncoordinated Jewish policy.

The long-term significance of Kristallnacht was a double one. The program marked the end of the vulgar rabble-rousing attempts to `solve the Jewish Question' through displays of public barbarity, and the beginning of a transition to a `rational' course of action, in the hands of the SS and with the public as far as possible excluded.

Among ordinary people the shadow of brutality by the regime that November, enhancing a feeling that the individual was powerless to combat the terror, strengthened the tendency to shrug shoulders and retreat into the comparative safety of a depoliticised private life-where everything to do with the `unpleasant' topic of the Jews was excluded from consideration. Most of the people for most of the time would carry out their lives without thinking about the Jews.

The only time that the `Jewish question' fell fully under the spotlight was after Kristallnacht. But interest in the fate of the Jews rapidly evaporated again. The apathy and indifference which had characterised the behaviour of the great majority of the German people in the face of the persecution of the Jews was only momentarily stirred by the brutality of the program. In later years, as the Jews of Europe were being murdered in their millions, most Germans had other things on their minds.

The relevance of that is to remind us that in this community very few people want separatism; most people want integration; few have imported their problems into Australia. The problems with the Croatians and Macedonians are largely settled, but one irritant does remain and that is at the Lakemba Mosque in Sydney, where the Imam, Sheik Tajeddin Al Hilaly, continues to circumvent efforts to deport him and continues to be controversial. He does continue, whether he is sometimes misinterpreted or not, to provoke Jews and Christians, to embarrass more liberal Moslems, and he becomes the sort of isolated example of separatism and lack of cohesion which those who want a discriminatory immigration policy seize upon so that they can say that the exception proves the rule.

I call upon Australian Moslems to help to moderate the behaviour of the Lakemba Mosque and, if they do not, I call upon the Government to remember the lessons of the past and to act so that that one potential irritant does not become a major sore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The recent suggestion by the National Health and Medical Research Council that heroin be made available to intravenous (IV) drug users has caused considerable debate and discussion in this place. Earlier this week in an adjournment debate I suggested that of course it was a worthy idea and one which we should support in a trial form, because it is my belief that the theory behind this suggestion is that there is great concern about the spread of the AIDS virus through IV drug users into the heterosexual community; and thence we open a Pandora's box if that virus should become a significant part of the heterosexual community. So there is certainly a great deal of concern about that. But today in the Australian I read an editorial headed `Nonsense about Heroin'. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: No matter what risk AIDS may pose to our community, it is nonsense to suggest that we should fight the spread of the virus by accepting the added and unknown risks of legally supplying heroin to drug addicts.

In that editorial comment there is much, I think, that is sensible but that particular statement I see as being facile nonsense. Firstly, it clearly underestimates the extent of the AIDS virus and the pernicious nature of that virus in our society. There are over 1,000 people who are known to suffer from the full-blown AIDS virus syndrome but equally concerning, or of much greater concern, is the fact that it is estimated that 50,000 Australians already have the virus and, as such, are HIV positive and potentially will suffer from the syndrome in the future.

On top of that we already have 500 Australians dead as a result of this disease. So it is a very significant disease and one which, I think, if it continues the way it is going, will certainly outmanoeuvre or take over from heroin addiction as a cause of death in our community, unless it can be controlled. That is the first thing.

The second thing is that we are already using a very addictive substance, methadone, in the treatment of IV drug users and so as such there is a contradiction in the view that we should not release this substance. Of course, no-one is suggesting that heroin should be freely available, but there is concern, because presently the illegal status of heroin makes the drug user a covert, isolated person, and, indeed, out of contact with mainstream society and with no chance of breathing space or opportunity to reassess perhaps the possibility of rehabilitation.

In fact, our total attitude towards the drug problem in this country is one of hypocrisy. Clearly, the biggest pushers of addictive drugs in our community are the tobacco industry and the brewers and, indeed, we revere these people for their business acumen and one aspires to be Prime Minister of this country. The motivation of these people is no different from the Mr Bigs, the triads and the drug pushers that abound in our country. The motivation is no different; it is profit. The reasons that these substances are acceptable are historical and cultural, I suppose. No-one would seriously suggest, I do not think at this stage in this place, that we should consider prohibition. It has shown not to work. It would be inhumane to those many, many people who are already addicted to those substances. But do we ostracise in the same way the tobacco or alcohol junkies or even the valium junkies?

I think what we do is accept that they have a health problem. We know that many of them function very well in our society, even considering that problem. Certainly they are not considered as criminals. When they are out of control they are treated with compassion. It needs to be understood that not everybody who smokes dope or marijuana becomes a junkie. Not everybody who sniffs cocaine becomes a junkie. Not everybody who shoots up on heroin becomes a junkie. In fact when practising as a medical practitioner I often saw young persons at night with unexplained nausea. Very often the cause of this was the fact that they had earlier in the evening had a go with heroin. Many of them were warned off it because of the terrible side effects that the drug caused on those occasions.

Clearly the experience from Vietnam is that of those GIs who were repatriated back to the United States and who were addicted to heroin when they left the United States. Only 50 per cent of them ever used the drug again when they arrived back in the United States and of those only 14 per cent ever became fully addicted again. Clearly it is a problem but we need, I think, to put it in perspective. The more I read about the problem, the more I realise what a complex issue it is.

There are cogent cases for and against the legislation of those presently illicit drugs. How one sees it depends on one's perspective. The economist looks at it and says, `The pillars of the market are prohibition and price and the illegality has not changed the availability of these substances; all that it has done is increase the price'. So there is a very pragmatic view put by economists. I have been reading an article, `A freer market for heroin: Alternatives to subsidising organised crime', by Robert Marx from the Australian Graduate School of Management at the University of New South Wales. He argues the case, referring to the costs to society, those of the hidden economy, those of the non-productive citizenry, the crime, prostitution, theft and the massive money which entrenches the organised crime that is involved. The cost to society in all of those areas is greater than the problem of addiction.

The law enforcers look at it another way. Some of them are attracted to the economic model. Others believe that what is necessary is more resources. If they are going to deal in the area of drug abuse, it is necessary for them to have the sort of resources that allow them to infiltrate that area. Most of them, of course, would take the view that the less pernicious cannabis problem should be decriminalised, because that blocks the courts and provides criminal records for many people who would be considered by all of us, I think, as not being criminals.

The medical fraternity takes another view. They are in direct contact and fear an expansion of this problem. They see the ruined lives and the disease that are associated with alcohol and tobacco and they do not want any more of these pernicious substances available or any more readily available, and I understand that concern. Those people who work in clinics believe in the programs that they are operating. The methadone program and the protocols that are involved with that offer for drug addicts an opportunity to break the cycle of addiction and allow them a chance to reassess their lives and very often move on to rehabilitation. Of course, there is an inherent contradiction in their view because they are using an addictive substance to solve this problem.

At the same time, they are saying that we should not be increasing the availability of heroin for users. The medical fraternity is also very concerned about the problem of the spread of AIDS into the heterosexual community and that is why this suggestion has come about. I suppose the most interesting view is if one puts oneself in the position of the drug dealer, Mr Big or whatever we want to call him. Perhaps it is the most revealing view if one does put oneself in that position. He fears only two things. He fears getting caught and he fears legalisation. Very few of them seem to get caught, it appears, but if there was legalisation or decriminalisation, or whatever way we want to see it, then clearly that would destroy his market and the price advantage that he can presently obtain.

There is concern and fear that legislation to decriminalise or to legalise these substances could lead to a mushrooming and growing number of addicts, and the suggestion that the Government thinks it is okay is one that concerns. But that is not what people are suggesting at all. They are suggesting strictly controlled trials and the availability of these substances only to registered users. What I believe is beyond dispute is that many of the users are driven by desperation to prostitution, robbery, assault and theft. Many of them are driven underground and become completely unproductive.

Many addicts become pushers to support their habit and thereby recruit new users. The money that is generated entrenches organised crime and the possibility and the reality of corruption. We have seen recently in South Australia a very good example of that; and the risk to the spread of AIDS is significant. I think the case for legalisation, decriminalisation or restricted availability in controlled circumstances warrants our attention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise today to inform the House of the critical problem facing nursing homes with the introduction on 1 July 1988 of the Federal Government's new nursing home policy. These problems have arisen despite the fact that this nation has a major problem in relation to care for the aged, and the situation gets worse day by day. Whilst I agree that as far as possible the aged in our community should be supported in their own homes, there certainly comes a time when many of our elderly citizens are no longer able to care for themselves. It is then that suitable hostel or nursing home accommodation should be provided in order to give those people the greatest quality of life and perhaps the greatest expectation of a longer life.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important for that quality of life that those elderly citizens be allowed to remain as far as is possible within their own community, close to loved ones and to friends. This applies in the major metropolitan areas as it does in small communities. Today, however, I particularly want to inform the House of the plight of smaller nursing homes, most of which are in rural and isolated areas of Australia. I will read a letter from the President of the Voluntary Care Association of New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory, a Mr Noel Howard, to the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, Mr Staples:

Following a meeting with the New South Wales State manager of the Department of Community Services and Health on Monday 17 October, I feel I must again write to you concerning the invidious position of small nursing homes.

There is mounting concern in the community and among care providers that the date of 31 March 1989, is rapidly approaching with no indication from Government as to the future of these small facilities.

Whilst the Voluntary Care Association of New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory is aware and appreciative of the fact that your department is preparing a paper on the subject of small nursing homes and their future, this does not assist the residents, relatives, staff, communities, or care providers in overcoming their fears that the facilities may be closed.

Minister, I believe that it would be most appropriate for you to issue a press statement copies of which should be mailed to all small nursing homes throughout the country, giving reassurance to all residents, relatives, staff and care providers that no resident will have their care jeopardised in any way by whatever policies are pursued by your Government.

And the letter goes on. More particularly, I want to address the problem facing the Lilliane Brady Village, located in the mining and pastoral town of Cobar of western New South Wales. Apart from the Lilliane Brady Village, which includes a 14-bed nursing home and nine self-care beds, the only other residential establishment for Cobar senior citizens is the Brennan Centre which, while it is a wonderful facility, does not have self-care utility and no permanent nursing home care is provided.

The Cobar hospital is for acute care patients only, and any other longstay patients have to be transferred to Dubbo which is 300 kilometres, or 3 1/2 hours drive, from Cobar. The Lilliane Brady Village was established in 1982 with over $70,000 being raised from the Cobar and district community in addition to loans from the Cobar Shire Council and funding from the Department of Health. Today all running costs not met by government are met by the Cobar Shire Council or, in effect, by the ratepayers of the Cobar Shire.

As honourable members would know, under the Government's new nursing home scheme which came into effect on 1 July this year, all nursing home residents are now categorised by geriatric assessment teams based on standards established on what is known as a resident classification instrument, or RCI. We in the coalition parties have already expressed strong reservations about this system of setting artificial standards to limit the number of nursing home residents. Unfortunately, our worst fears have now been realised and are being reflected in the difficulties now being faced by the Lilliane Brady Village in Cobar.

In the past, the nursing home has traditionally been deficit funded by the Federal Government and has maintained a high standard of both health and personal care for the elderly. The new funding arrangements for nursing homes have resulted in a massive and ongoing deterioration in funding for the Village. During 1989 the recently announced government funding will result in a reduction of an excess of $110,000. As I said before, the new funding arrangements provide for the categorisation of residents. When the new funding arrangements were announced, the Cobar Shire Council recognised the significant reductions that would be made to the small nursing home due to the introduction of the category payment system.

Cobar Shire Council subsequently deferred transfers to the new system until 1 March 1989. On 1 March 1989, the Department of Community Services and Health funding will be reduced from $92.79 per resident to approximately $62.80 per day, based upon half category four and half category five residents. The Lilliane Brady Village Nursing Home is expected to cost $480,230 to operate in 1989, exclusive of loan repayments and depreciation. The Department of Community Services and Health funding for the Village in 1989 is expected to total $304,000, based upon two months category six at 90 per cent occupancy and 10 months at 90 per cent occupancy of half category four and half category five residents.

Cobar Shire Council is unable to fund the federal responsibility of care of the aged to the level of $176,000. Residents of the village will therefore be required to leave not only family and friends but the region to live in Dubbo to obtain necessary care. On top of this, we know that the Federal Government announced in the 1988-89 Budget that charges for the lodgment and processing of requests for reviews under section 40ae of the National Health Act of nursing home fee determinations would apply.

At its meeting on Thursday, 13 October 1988 the Cobar Shire Council considered the introduction of these measures which provide for a lodgment fee of $500 to be paid by nursing home proprietors for each request made after 23 August 1988. Also an additional fee of $500 is to be paid by a nursing home proprietor for each day or part thereof taken by a nursing home fee review committee to consider after 23 August 1988 a request referred to it by the Minister.

Mr Deputy Speaker, while I understand that both lodgment and processing fees will be refunded in full where a request for a review is wholly or substantially successful, concern is expressed at the manner for determination of genuine appellants. The recent funding initiatives of the Department of Community Services and Health has resulted in a significant transfer of costs to the Cobar Shire Council and the introduction of a lodgment fee and processing fee, along with the matters I have already raised, appears to confirm the perceived Department of Community Services and Health determination to close small nursing homes.

The Lilliane Brady Village is an establishment essential to the people of Cobar and district and while it might be expedient to the Federal Government and the health bureaucrats to close the village as part of an overall plan to downgrade aged care facilities as a cost saving measure throughout Australia, I remind the Government that Australia has an ageing population. Nursing home care cannot simply be switched on and off at the political whim of any government.

Keeping this in mind, it must be said that the Hawke Administration at one stage did not give approval for one nursing home bed in almost 18 months. Nursing home care is needed in Australia today-it is needed in Cobar today-and it will be needed more in the future. Because of the new funding arrangements the Cobar Shire will find it impossible to meet the additional costs placed on it by the Federal Government's new funding arrangements and at about this time today the Cobar Shire Council, at its ordinary monthly meeting, will be making a decision either to close down the Lilliane Brady Village nursing home beds or increase shire rates by 15 per cent in order to meet the cost of its nursing and personal care component alone.

Obviously for a host of reasons the second alternative is impossible and therefore, once again, our elderly citizens will be the losers. My plea on behalf of the residents of Cobar and district is that action will be taken immediately by the Minister to save the Lilliane Brady Nursing Home and others like it throughout Australia that are trying to provide adequate nursing home care for our nation's fragile but valuable elderly citizens.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My grievance today relates to startling allegations that have been made over the last couple of days in the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct in Brisbane, particularly by the former senior National Party Minister, Mr Don Lane. The sorts of practices, the lack of public accountability, and the now obvious misuse of taxpayers' funds by Ministers wrongly claiming from their ministerial allowances, as admitted by Mr Lane, are nothing short of a disgrace and constitute nothing short of a public scandal.

SPEECH.PARA: The Queensland Government for the last 30 years, despite numerous calls from the Opposition, has refused to set up a proper public accounts committee. It has now, after so long, agreed to set up a type of Claytons committee but lacking the necessary teeth to be a success. As a result of the revelations made in the Fitzgerald inquiry over the last day or two, one can understand the reluctance of and see why the Queensland Cabinet has refused to set up this committee. What was revealed in Queensland yesterday by Mr Lane, a former senior Minister and a very powerful figure in the Queensland National Party and, in fact, until recently, well known as Sir Joh's numbers cruncher, is nothing short of extraordinary. I quote from Australian Associated Press reports of yesterday:
Former Queensland Cabinet Minister Don Lane has told Queensland Fitzgerald inquiry that he and other Queensland Ministers had been ripping off the public purse for years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I interrupt the honourable member. I trust that he will be sensible to the rulings that relate to prejudicing the rights of any party to an inquiry. Whilst he may make some passing reference to matters, I would ask him to bear in mind particularly that he should not prejudice the rights of any party to an inquiry presently under way.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am aware of that. I am quoting in fact press reports that are quite public and there is no suggestion of any inquiry at the moment, apart from the Fitzgerald inquiry which, according to my understanding, is only a commission of inquiry and not a royal commission and one that is not at least sub judice. But I do understand what you say, Mr Deputy Speaker. I continue:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Lane made his confession and the allegation against other Ministers after an inquiry analysis of his financial affairs showed he had a large amount of money that could not be accounted for. Mr Lane told the inquiry that the money was not from corruption payments he was alleged to have received but were amounts that were made up so he could falsely claim expenses on his tax returns. He went on to allege that it was common practice for Queensland Cabinet Ministers to use their ministerial expenses improperly to pay for restaurant bills, alcohol, accommodation, travel, car hire, gifts of flowers for their wives and bottles of perfume for the girls in the typing pool.

TALK.START.PARA: —They should resign.

—They should resign, exactly, and I will be calling upon them to do so shortly, as the honourable member for Fisher suggests. This morning some startling allegations were made and questions asked in the Queensland State Parliament with respect to other serious matters. A question was asked of the Minister for Employment, Training and Industrial Affairs, Mr Lester. From information I have received today, the revelations that have been made by Mr Lane are only the tip of the iceberg. There are numerous rumours and stories circulating around Queensland that very senior Ministers have been also misusing their ministerial allowances.

SPEECH.PARA: According to Public Service sources within the Department of the Minister, Vince Lester, another senior National Party Minister and one who aspires to the Premiership, there has been a long term practice in his office for Mr Lester to have a $50 cheque raised, made out to cash. These vouchers would then be acquitted by the Minister, picking the name of a restaurant from the local telephone directory, and then advising his Department through his office that the cash advance had been expended for official purposes, namely, that restaurant. No receipts were ever produced.

Further, I am informed that Mr Lester's former private secretary, who no longer works for him but, in fact, works for a National Party senator here in Canberra, objected to this practice. I am told that she was forced to resign as a result. Mr Lester's former steno-secretary, who previously had been responsible for making out these $50 cheques, was subsequently promoted to the position of private secretary. I have their names but I will not give them out at this point.

In State Parliament today when Mr Lester was asked this question, when the facts were put to him by Mr Neville Warburton, the former Leader of the Opposition, he did not deny the contents of those allegations.

TALK.START.PARA: —He should resign.

—As the honourable member for Hinkler says, he should resign. He simply replied that no objection had been raised to his accounts by the government auditors. What a joke! Ministerial answers are not probed. No mechanism is in place in Queensland at present such as we have in Canberra, with the Public Accounts Committee and with Senate Estimates committees. There are no restrictions on ministerial allowance spending in Queensland. It is virtually unlimited.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of other disturbing reports have recently come to light. One Minister is said to have regularly taken his wife to a seafood restaurant at Ascot, which I understand is a very expensive one, and to have charged it to his ministerial credit card. Another Minister is said to have used his allowance to raise cash to use for betting money on quite a regular basis. Perhaps the most damaging allegations are being made in government circles and from quite reliable sources. Mr Deputy Speaker, I am quite sad to be saying these things; nevertheless, they are true and they are things that have to be brought out at least in this Parliament if they cannot be brought out in the Queensland Parliament. These allegations relate to the highest level of the Queensland Government itself, even at the feet of the Premier. These are serious allegations and they cannot be summarily dismissed.

If Mr Ahern wants to clear the air I ask him to table details of his own ministerial expenses, particularly those that relate to a trip he took to New York in March or April of this year. When allegations were made against former Ministers Don Lane and Russ Hinze, they were forced to step down. When allegations were made against judges of both the Supreme and District Courts, they were asked to step down. Now that allegations have been made against Ministers who served in the Joh Bjelke-Petersen Government, along with Mr Lane, and who include Mr Ahern, why are they not agreeing to step down?

TALK.START.PARA: —Double standards.

—It is a case of double standards and I join and support the strong call made yesterday and today by the Queensland Labor Opposition leader, the undoubted next Premier of Queensland, Mr 58 per cent, as they are starting to call him, Mr Wayne Goss, for the 13 Ministers who served with Mr Lane, including the Premier, to stand down while a full inquiry is held. That is what Mr Ahern required of other Ministers who served in his Government and were named in hearsay evidence at the Fitzgerald inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: Now that direct allegations have been made by a former senior National Party Minister, a person who was a numbers cruncher and a close confidant of the former Premier, I ask this Parliament: What difference is there between Mr Lane, Mr Hinze, the two judges and all of the other 13 Ministers who served in that Government? There is no difference whatsoever, Mr Deputy Speaker. I call upon Mr Ahern to do the noble thing. For some time now Mr Cleanskin, Mr Ahern, the new broom that was going to sweep everything clean, has been trying to let the Queensland public think that he had nothing to do with all of this.

It reminds me in fact of the Nuremberg trials when members of Hitler's armed forces used to say, `But look, we were under orders, we did not know what was going on'. What is the difference? What is the difference in what is occurring in Queensland today. These were Ministers in a government that has now been seen because of public admissions on the part of very senior and important people in the police force, in the community and even in the Government to have in some way been involved in questionable practices.

Some years ago in Queensland a man tried to do everything he possibly could to expose criminal activities in that State. I refer to a very dear personal friend of mine who is now deceased, the late Kevin Hooper. In Hansard on 30 August 1977 he made a number of allegations. He went on to say what was happening and that the massage racket in that city was a cottage industry. This is what Premier Ahern had to say in the Hansard of 1 September 1977:

I believe that he, Kev Hooper, put forward a complete fabrication. He, Kev Hooper, has done this to obtain better headlines in the Press and to prostitute the institution of Parliament. He, Kev Hooper, is engaged in the lowest form of parliamentary life. This member Kev Hooper I believe is a disgrace to the parliament. He, Kev Hooper, is a mudslinger of the worst order. He, Kev Hooper, is parliament's arch enemy.
In fact, he was parliament's best friend. If Mr Ahern has any decency he will step down, he will heed the call of the Opposition Leader and he will do something about what has been happening.

TALK.START.PARA: —All members, on this side of the House at least, would be well aware of the problems afflicting the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation specifically and the science community generally due to a total neglect by the Hawke Government, but I wonder whether the Government itself is realising the implications for Australia's industry and competitiveness on world markets. One would not think so, looking at the transcript of an interview by Kerry O'Brien on the Face to Face program with the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) last Sunday.

SPEECH.PARA: It really is quite laughable except that tragically it is a very serious issue that nobody on the Government side seems to be taking seriously. Mr O'Brien asked the Minister about being summoned to visit the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) the other day. This is what the Minister said about his visit to the Prime Minister:

The Prime Minister indicated that he was sympathetic to what was happening, and recognised that there was a very grave danger of losing the scientific constituency and their friends and their families and indeed a lot of people in what you might broadly describe as the intellectual community.

The cynicism with which this Government approaches any of the problems that afflict Australian society today is bad enough but on this issue it goes beyond mere politics. It is in the country's national interest to pursue a vigorous, innovative scientific policy, none of which criteria are satisfied under this Government's neglect. It is also hilarious when the Minister for Science does not deny the allegation put to him by Mr O'Brien that both the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) and the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) are opposed--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw to the attention of the House a discovery by a constituent of mine, Mr Roley Pleming, who lives in Berkeley Vale, which is within my electorate. Mr Pleming has brought to the attention of many people living in my electorate the beneficial effects of a plant called candelabra, which goes by the botanical name of arborescens. I have part of this plant in my hand.

SPEECH.PARA: The sap from the leaves of this plant, in Mr Pleming's opinion, has proved to be very effective in stopping the pains from sciatica, lumbago, gout, rheumatoid arthritis, tendonitis, arthritis, RSI, migraine headaches, hangovers-for members of the Opposition-burns, sunburns, spurs, bunions, asthma, multiple sclerosis, perforated veins and trigger finger. I am not quite sure how it could fix trigger finger but that is also one of the ailments that it may fix. Also some people suffering from cancer and strokes have also found that the juice from this plant has been of some assistance to them.

Mr Pleming has recommended to people who wish to try the effects of this plant that they split the leaf and put the juice on the affected spot until the pain eases. I have to say that I have not carried out any scientific tests myself on the effects of the juice of this plant but I do know that Mr Pleming has had many good reports.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my electorate of Wakefield I am receiving hundreds of complaints regarding a proposed change in responsibility for repatriation hospitals. Every day another 20 or so letters from concerned veterans and their families arrive. Changes over the last few years by the Hawke Government have convinced my electorate that the veteran is to be brushed under the carpet.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's lack of involvement, thankfully, in active combat over recent years, has enabled the present Government to hope that the decreasing number of veterans will eventually disappear. Even the action of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in condoning the laying of a plaque commemorating those Japanese aircrews lost in action over Australia during World War II has offended some returned men and women. At the same time, we have supposedly responsible people advocating awarding our Olympic athletes a pension in line with that awarded to war veterans.

How much longer have the war widow and the war veteran to put up with these types of insults when they or their close ones were prepared to make the supreme sacrifice? This Government and this country should give a reassurance to veterans and their widows that they are not forgotten. It is time to give our veterans something to celebrate in 1988. Tomorrow, Madam Speaker, is 11 November and an appropriate time to recall that all that veterans seek is predictability and recognition that the spirit of Ben Chifley has not been exorcised from the Hawke Australian Labor Party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to acknowledge the National Women's Art Award which was held on 6 November and is currently still being exhibited at the Centre Gallery in Surfers Paradise until 27 November. The exhibition is the first of its kind in Australia and, in fact, aside from inviting numbers of women from all around Australia to participate, it also took the opportunity to put together an exhibition called `A complimentary caste; a homage to women artists in Queensland, past and present'. In fact, it displayed work from people such as Ann Green who painted in 1897, through the weavers of the 1930s, sculptors, potters, photographers, quilters and others. Because for many, women's art often uses media and subject matter which are less frequently used by men, the national committee behind which Bronwyn Larner was the driving force took the opportunity in this our bicentennial year to acknowledge the very real contribution which women have made to the art in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Betty Churcher was invited to open the exhibition and I certainly was delighted to be there as one of over 500 people to participate in what we hope will become an annual event. Let me just say that the efforts of Irene Amos and also, of course, Fran Considine, the gallery director, do very much for women's art in Australia and in particular in Queensland and I think it important that we in this Parliament acknowledge their work and contribution to Australian art.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the New South Wales Government on its decision to return all the registrations on motor vehicles amounting to approximately $180m a year back to the roads and the bridging of the State. I do this, Madam Speaker, in the face of the legislation that came before the Parliament yesterday. Over the last three years there has not been an increase in actual money value of the funds available from the Commonwealth to all the States and local government for road works generally.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the legislation there is no hope of any increase for another two-year term and some doubt as to the future of the three years remaining of the five-year term after that. The roads of this country are the lifeblood so far as our Australian people are concerned, particularly those on the land and in industry and it is so important that the Government does recognise the importance of transport to production and sales.

I appeal to the Government to re-examine the legislation in the light of the demands and to give a reasonable priority to road funding. The States and local government generally are most disappointed in the action of the Government and undoubtedly they will be pressing the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I drew the attention of the House to the irresponsible attacks made on myself and the Government by Mr B. A. Santamaria in the Australian newspaper and Mr Michael Barnard in the Age newspaper. The attacks arose because of my appointment by the House as a member of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and question my integrity as a member of the Australian Parliament and my loyalty to Australia and the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: I have sent copies of my grievance debate speech to the editors of both newspapers with a request that my comments be published, as I believed that I should be given the right to reply to such unwarranted and irresponsible attacks. On previous occasions the editors have responded that I have plenty of opportunity in the Parliament to raise issues of political importance. However, it is a sad fact that far more people read our national newspapers than listen to the parliamentary broadcasts or read the Hansard.

Whilst the editor of the Age did say that he might consider publishing a letter, I believe that it is deplorable that both editors have seen fit to refuse to publish even an edited version of my rebuttal of the mischievous attacks on my integrity made by their columnists.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to draw the attention of honourable members of this House to the fact that in far western Victoria, in my electorate, there is a little town called Merino. It has a bush nursing hospital which has struggled on, despite the fact that the Government cut the $20 bed subsidy off last year. I am now going to present to the House a petition which contains 247 signatures, all of which were gained around the district of Merino.
—Order! It being 2 p.m, in accordance with sessional order 106a, the time for members' statements has concluded.

—As a courtesy, I inform the House that the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support (Mr Punch) is absent from Question Time today on Government business. Questions normally addressed to him should be directed to the portfolio Minister, the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis).
—What is the Treasurer's estimate of the impact of a rise in mortgage rates to 15 per cent on private dwelling investment?

—I can only draw from the question the inference that the shadow Treasurer is bidding for an answer about reductions in disposable incomes-that is, some impact on living standards-when for weeks the shadow Minister for finance has been out urging a tightening of monetary policy and higher interest rates and when the Opposition has opposed every national wage increase since 1983. Members of the Opposition should get their act together. Either the honourable member believes in a managed change in real unit labour costs, which the Government has presided over since 1983, and a sustainable level of growth in the economy, with the emphasis on `sustainable', or he does not. But the honourable member should not ask me questions which beg for an answer about some impact of mortgages on disposable income when, in fact, his colleague is out there arguing strenuously, week in and week out, for an increase in interest rates.
—Will the Prime Minister outline the Government's reaction to the recent election of Mr Bush as President of the United States?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that Australia can look forward with great confidence to the presidency of Mr Bush. His background as Vice-President to President Reagan, and before that as a successful businessman, congressman and holder of senior posts in the Administration, I believe, will prove extremely valuable in tackling the range of international, economic, security and political issues which the United States and the rest of the world have to face in the next few years. I am very hopeful that under his presidency we will see further advances in arms control, building on the intermediate-range nuclear force agreement achieved between President Reagan and Secretary-General Gorbachev, and that we will see further progress towards removing the threat of nuclear catastrophe. From the discussions I have been able to have previously, I believe that this will be a major goal of the new Administration.

ANSWER.PARA: It is also important to Australia to understand that George Bush himself understands very much the importance of the Asia-Pacific region. In particular, he knows Australia and he knows Australians very well. He regards Australians as good friends and as firm allies of the United States. I note that, like President Reagan, President Bush will face a Democrat majority in the Congress. I can assure the House that the Government will work closely with the new President and will continue to focus the attention of the Congress on matters affecting Australia's trade and other interests. Our views on these issues are already very well known to the President-elect following extensive discussions that I have had with him and that many of my Ministers also have had with him and other members of the Administration. They were, for example, set out very precisely in the address I made to the joint session of Congress earlier this year.

I also note that James Baker has already been named by George Bush as Secretary of State in the new administration. He has impressive credentials for this important task. I know Mr Baker well and I am confident that the Australian Government will be able to have a very close working relationship with him as, it is well known, we were able to have with the present holder of that office, George Shultz, who, I might say, I believe has made an absolutely outstanding contribution during his period as Secretary of State.

I conclude by saying that the very best wishes of the Government as well as, I am sure I can say, of the whole of this Parliament and of all Australians will go with George Bush as he prepares to assume this most important of all positions of political leadership.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek your indulgence, Madam Speaker.
—You have my indulgence.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr HOWARD

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition joins the Prime Minister in conveying congratulations to George Bush. I welcome his election very warmly, and I know that all members of the Liberal and National parties do also. I particularly welcome the fact that he will bring a world view and not just an Atlantic view to the conduct of American foreign policy. I also welcome the fact that he will continue the essential thrust of the Reagan years in world foreign policy leadership.

INTERJECT.PARA: On the question of trade matters, it is an appropriate time for me to say that, whatever our differences may be with the Government on other issues, there is a united Australian view to the United States and other parts of the world in relation to achieving a fair deal, particularly for Australian primary producers. In every respect, I wish George Bush well. I think he brings to the office enormous experience. He is a man I have respected for a long time and I personally am very happy with the result. It is a triumph of the American electorate's faith in mainstream free enterprise, conservative values.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Attorney-General, relates to the ongoing Rothwells affair. It is probably worth pointing out that a week ago the Prime Minister said that the Western Australian Government was handling this in an appropriately prudent manner. Has the Attorney seen the comments made by the Chairman of the Perth Stock Exchange, Mr Poynton, where he suggested that international confidence in Australia would be damaged if the Rothwells affair was not properly dealt with? In view of the serious concerns in the marketplace and the strong indications that the intitial report of the provisional liquidator will go beyond the worst expectations, will the Attorney now honour the Government's legislation obligation under section 291 of the Companies Code and order a full inquiry forthwith?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable gentleman has asked questions before on the basis that this might be a matter which should have been investigated by the Commonwealth even though the matters relate to State administration.
—Why did you not have a Commonwealth investigation into--
—Order! The honourable member for Ryan has asked his question; he will now listen to the answer.

—Thank you, Madam Speaker. Rothwells Ltd, as a matter of interest, is incorporated in the State of Queensland. That, of course, immediately gives legal capacity for that State to have an investigation.

ANSWER.PARA: It is well know that the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) has an overall responsibility for the administration of corporate activity. So the present situation, as I have told the honourable member before, has been the subject of continual investigation and supervision, we understand, by the National Companies and Securities Commission. The Ministerial Council gets reports from the National Companies and Securities Commission as and when the Ministerial Council meets. I do not know whether there has been any detailed report about Rothwells other than the fact that the matter was the subject of continued investigation. It is inappropriate for the honourable gentleman to suggest that something has not been done when, apparently, the matter has been under continual supervision and investigation by the National Companies and Securities Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you want--
—Order! I draw the honourable member's attention to standing order 55. I warn the honourable member for Ryan. He is not heeding the Chair.

—It is an interesting question. The Opposition opposes any national interest in the matter until something goes wrong, and then says to us, `Why aren't you doing it?'. I have no legal responsibility in the matter unless it was made very clear that the honourable gentleman and the Leader of the Opposition started to consider what would be in the national interest from the point of view of legislation.
—A split scheme.

—Oh, yes! None of the States want a split scheme. Why? It is because the States want the privilege, the power and the profit from running the present scheme. If they have the power, if they have the privilege, and as they have the profits, what are they doing about administering the scheme?

ANSWER.PARA: I am not here to criticise the States as such in this case. The matter has been the continual subject of investigation by the National Companies and Securities Commission. Under the Queensland Supreme Court-note, State law-eventually a provisional liquidator was appointed. I am advised that the auditors, Peat Marwick Hungerfords, have been keeping the National Companies and Securities Commission informed and will shortly be handing a report on the financial position of Rothwells to the National Companies and Securities Commission. At least some progress is being made. The Commission is to get a report as to Rothwells' financial position.

The NCSC, under section 291 of the Companies Act, has the power to request that a special investigation be held. No such request has yet been made. It would not be the first time a request for a special investigation had been made. We have a request now to investigate a company which, I think, is closely associated with the State which the honourable member represents. The request for a special investigation was made on the basis that the National Companies and Securities Commission does not have the financial resources to carry out an investigation. That is interesting. Every State has the profit, the liability and the responsibility but the National Companies and Securities Commission is unable to carry out that investigation.

The NCSC is carrying out this investigation. I do not know whether the honourable member is satisfied with that. However, any report will go to the meeting of the Ministerial Council, which will be held on 1 December.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, with your indulgence, I apologise to the House for this late announcement of ministerial arrangements, but it had not been brought to my attention that the Minister for Health and Community Services (Dr Blewett) is absent on Government business. In his absence, questions normally directed to him should be directed to his portfolio colleague the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, Mr Staples.
—Can the Prime Minister inform the House of the outlook for Australia's current account deficit?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. Whilst the July and August current account figures exceeded the equivalent figures for the previous year, the September deficit figure of $990m was more encouraging. In interpreting the current account numbers, we need to be aware of the volatility and the seasonality of the monthly figures. For example, I think all honourable members would know that results so far this financial year have been affected by the low opening stocks for wool and wheat. There is no doubt that exports should improve as the wool clip and the wheat harvest begin to come in.

ANSWER.PARA: When considering the outlook for Australia, we need to look both at the import side and the export side. I think honourable members will appreciate that so far this year import figures have remained relatively flat. As to export volumes, it is appropriate to quote some recent statements by certain leaders of the mining industry. The chief executive of Conzinc Riotinto of Australia Ltd, Mr John Ralph, was recently reported as saying that the fundamentals for the mining industry were the best for 15 years. Mr Ralph said:
We are also furthering capacity expansions committed, or in the feasibility study stage, in coal, copper and diamonds.
Another industry leader, Sir Arvi Parbo, Chairman of Western Mining Corporation, recently said:

In spite of all the technological changes and substitution, the consumption of all the main metals and minerals continues to increase . . . There is every indication that demand will continue to grow.

If we are considering the outlook for Australia, these predictions and analyses by leaders of the mining industry are of considerable comfort for Australia, as I would suggest also is an analysis that appeared in today's press by another leader of the mining industry, Mr Hugh Morgan. Mr Hugh Morgan was talking about the future of Australia also. He made an equally prescient and, I would think, accurate analysis relevant to the future of Australia when he said, speaking about members of the other side of the House--

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on, Madam Speaker.

—This is relevant to the future of Australia. I know that honourable members opposite do not want to hear it because he dobbed every one of them in. He made an analysis of every honourable member sitting opposite. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: At this time the public generally find him-
he was talking about the Leader of the Opposition-
and the present leadership-and I include his parliamentary colleagues-as not being the leadership that they would like to have available to select to lead the nation.

One could not have a more accurate analysis by a leader of the mining industry of the alternative government of this country. Mr Hugh Morgan says that the Opposition is not up to it-the leadership and the whole lot of them. In regard to the future of the current account deficit, it is quite clear that the responsibility for the management of the current account and the external situation of this country-the total economic management-will remain in the years ahead where it should, and that is with the people on this side of the House because the others are hopeless, as indicated by Mr Hugh Morgan.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs aware of the case of Lebanese drug smugglers and their families given two-year temporary residents' permits in Australia which was reported in the 60 Minutes program on 6 November? The report alleges that the decision must have been made at the highest levels. Did the portfolio Minister make the decision? Was that decision influenced by the Prime Minister, the Deputy Prime Minister or any other Minister and if so, who? Was the decision in accordance with departmental advice?

—I am aware of the circumstances surrounding this matter. The decision that was made had nothing to do with the Prime Minister. It was based on advice from the Australian Federal Police who regarded this family as critical to giving evidence in a very important drug case. That was the basis upon which the decision was made.

—I direct my question to the Prime Minister. It relates to former prisoners of war of the Japanese in the Second World War. I preface my question by reminding honourable members that in the Second World War 550,000 troops in all theatres of war served Australia and 19,000 of those were killed. Of the Australians who were taken prisoners of war by the Japanese-some 22,000-only 14,000 returned home. Is the Prime Minister aware that, due to the barbaric conditions and the malnourishment, about half of those 14,000 now survive? Would the Prime Minister agree that this group of Australians suffered more than any other in the defence of their country in the Second World War? The Prime Minister will recall that I wrote to him recently seeking to have a survey or inquiry into the health, future treatment and remuneration of the former prisoners of war. Has the Prime Minister reached a decision on my proposal? If not, will he give consideration to reaching an early decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. Of course, nobody in this House or elsewhere can or will dispute the unbelievable severity of the conditions endured by those who were held captive by the Japanese during the Second World War. I might make the observation that I believe it is true that the honourable member for Reid is now the only remaining member in this Parliament who had first-hand experience of those conditions. Therefore, I and, I think, all honourable members would appreciate the intensity of his concern and commitment to his former comrades. It is in recognition of those severe conditions that the prisoners of war of the Japanese have, in the past, received sympathetic treatment and consideration from the Repatriation Commission, and it is proper that that should be so.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable member has called for a survey. I can tell the House, and particularly the honourable member, that a number of major reviews are currently being undertaken by the Department of Veterans' Affairs which will be of considerable relevance to all ageing veterans, including those ex-prisoners of war to whom the honourable gentleman refers. The more significant of these involve a fundamental review of the Department's treatment program and the development of a corporate plan designed to deliver services better to veterans and their dependants. Beyond that, as I indicated in the discussion with the honourable member subsequent to the letter he sent to me, I have asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to consider the matter which he has raised and to let me know what specific initiatives, if any, might be appropriate in responding to the particular issue raised by the honourable member.

The essence of my reply is that there are these general reviews taking place which will be of benefit to the ex-prisoners of war of the Japanese. In addition to those general views, I have asked the Minister, in the light of the letter from the honourable member to me on this issue, to investigate and to report back to me as to whether there is anything further in particular which should be done, and I will keep in touch with the honourable gentleman in the light of those inquiries. I thank him for this question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I remind the Minister that I asked him a question in regard to the disappearance of Aboriginal artworks, to which the Minister replied that he was unaware of the events that surrounded it and would refer it to one of the six inquiries into Aboriginal administration. Has the Minister now acquainted himself with the events surrounding the disappearance of the artworks? Secondly, is the Minister aware that, of the 353 items that were missing, approximately 200 remain unaccounted for and that it has been estimated that, at today's values, their worth could approach anything up to $1m? Is it true also that, following Question Time on Tuesday, the former Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment contacted senior people in the public administration of the arts and expressed his deep concern about the likely implications if the Opposition pursued this matter? Fourthly, to which inquiry of the six will the Minister refer the matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable gentleman for his question. The actual matters to which he refers are within the framework of my portfolio and not that of my colleague the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs.
—You have to make allowances.

—I forgive the shadow Minister for not understanding that simple fact. The fact is that some artworks which were the property of the Aboriginal Arts Board are missing. In stocktakings undertaken annually prior to June 1987 no significant losses were identified.
—No significant losses?

—Well, we are looking at a large number of items and these matters were the subject of examination by the Auditor-General, and nothing there would bring that fact to the attention of the Australia Council or even to the Aboriginal Arts Board. The results of the stocktakes were incorporated in the annual financial statements of the Council. No adverse comment was made by the Auditor-General concerning these stocktakes. The annual stocktake undertaken in June 1987 revealed 353 items, values at approximately $38,084, which could not be accounted for.

—Of course, I should point out that for most of the relevant period the person who had been Secretary of the Aboriginal Arts Board was the person who has been relied upon by members of the Opposition as their informant for the allegation of corruption-Mr Foley.

—I am not making any allegation about that gentleman. I just simply say this: the person whom those opposite relied on and referred to in terms of their accusations about corruption against my colleague the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs was for almost the whole time in a position where either he knew or he should have or could have known about these matters and disclosed them.

ANSWER.PARA: As soon as this matter was brought to the attention of the Council, it immediately issued and made arrangements for stricter security. It reported the matter to the Australian Federal Police, to my ministerial colleague Senator Richardson, and to the Auditor-General.

As at 9 November, 112 items, valued at some $15,988.96, have been located at the National Gallery of Victoria, although specific identification of these works has not been completed. In some cases some of these items have been identified by the Federal Police. They had been returned quite legitimately to some Aboriginal communities, who had decided that they did not want to keep them and made them available for sale. As of now, work is continuing to locate the balance of 189 items, valued at some $22,095. Three of those items were purchased at $7,600 and the remaining items average out at $78 each. So again not only has the shadow Minister really got the portfolio wrong; he has the sums wrong, he has the items wrong, and the person who is in the best position to advise the honourable gentleman opposite is the person that those opposite called as their witness to substantiate a very generalised allegation of corruption against my colleague and me and against this Government. Do your homework and get it right in future!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of the House to standing order 55.

—My question is also directed to the Minister for the Arts and Territories and Minister Assisting the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. Is the Minister aware of the offensive, anti-Jewish remarks allegedly made by the Imam of the Lakemba Mosque-Sheikh Al Hilaly? Can the Minister say whether these remarks represent the views of the Muslim community in Australia?
—How on earth can you answer that?

—On a point of order, Madam Speaker: I understand the significance of the remarks but I would question whether the Minister is responsible for determining the views of the Muslim community in Australia. He cannot be asked a question of opinion on a matter like that. Nobody agrees with Sheikh Al Hilaly, but I seriously suggest that the question is totally out of order.
—He is asking for information, I would imagine. The Minister is in order.
—He should be in order, and he is not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I direct your attention to the statement made by the Leader of the National Party, who indicated that, although you have just ruled on the matter, I am not in order. I suggest he be asked to withdraw that, as it is a reflection on your ruling.
—The Chair is not quite as touchy.

—I am aware of the remarks that were made by Sheikh Hilaly, and on behalf of the Government I repudiate those remarks. More importantly, if we are to make some judgments about those remarks, then I think we should not look to the views of the Government or of a Minister but, more importantly, to the views expressed by leaders of the Islamic community around Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: I am pleased to say that very shortly after those remarks were made, Australian Muslims and their leadership not only made it perfectly clear that they did not support the views of Sheikh Hilaly, but also distanced themselves from those remarks; and in several telegrams and letters to the Government the following points have emerged. In a telegram to the Prime Minister, Dr Hague, the President of the Australian Federation of Islamic Councils (AFIC), Australia's largest established Muslim organisation, said the Federation:
will have nothing to do with unwarranted remarks that might hurt the feelings of fellow Australians of any religion or race.
AFIC is committed to the enhancement of a multicultural Australia under your leadership where the views and faiths of all Australians, irrespective of their origin, must be respected.

Professor El Eriam, the former President of AFIC, who represented Muslims at the opening of the new Parliament House, says that he `repudiates any statements which are likely to cause discord or dissonance in our peaceful nation'. Dr Ahmed Shboel, a member of the Advisory Council on Multicultural Affairs, said that he is `personally shocked at the statement attributed to Sheikh Hilaly'. He said:
It's utterly unacceptable and is anathema to the principle of Islamic tolerance and the ideals of our multicultural society.
Finally, the press itself has reported that the National Federation of Islamic Societies `rejects and condemns' the Sheikh's remarks.

It is perfectly clear that racism of any sort-particularly anti-Semitism, which is an international scourge-has no place in a multicultural society such as ours. Of course, the Government will continue to pursue the policy of multiculturalism; and it welcomes the support that has been given and expressed on behalf of the Islamic community of Australia.

Those statements ought to be noted, not only by the House but by all Australians. They show that those of the Islamic faith who have come to Australia are not prepared to countenance remarks which attack the very basis and the very ethos of multiculturalism and on both a spiritual basis, in terms of their Islamic religion and in terms of their perceptions and their willingness to be part of a broader Australian society, they have not only distanced themselves from those comments but also seriously condemned them. I believe those statements are enormously significant and ought to be taken into account by all members of the House and by the Australian community in general.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Can the Minister explain to the House why there has been a massive increase, in his Government's terms in office, in the number of people claiming to be Aborigines receiving special benefits? I shall quote these percentage increases for each State: in Tasmania, there has been a 150 per cent increase in people claiming to be Aborigines; Victoria, a 108 per cent increase; New South Wales, a 66 per cent increase; the Australian Capital Territory, a 50 per cent increase; South Australia, a 45 per cent increase; Queensland, a 37 per cent increase; Western Australia, a 22 per cent increase; and the Northern Territory, a 19 per cent increase. I would like the Minister to explain to the House why it is that we have seen these massive increases.

—In answer to the honourable member's question dealing with the increased numbers of Aboriginal people recorded on government documents in each State, I would suggest there could be a number of reasons. One reason could be that people are proud to be Aboriginal; and it could be because censuses have been conducted more accurately than they have been in the past.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Is the Minister aware of deep concern in the ex-service community about the intention to integrate repatriation general hospitals into the State system? Will the Minister inform the House of the consultative machinery which has been set in place, as well as the guarantees that have been given to the ex-service community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Grey for his question. It is a very important question, and one in which I hope all honourable members would be very interested. I am aware of concern in some veterans' communities, especially in South Australia in the electorates of the honourable member for Grey and the honourable member for Hawker. One might ask why the concern is being felt. I can assure the House that the reason for that concern has not come from this side of the House but from the other side of the House. The concern has come from the shadow Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the honourable member for Farrer; a senator in another place, and the honourable member for Adelaide. What they have reverted to is the typical old tactic of the Opposition-scaremongering; scaring those aged and infirm veterans and war widows by running around the countryside saying that the Government is not looking after veterans.

—Opposition members are not interested in what the Government has to say about veterans. When we tell the House the truth, they start jumping around. What they have been doing is absolutely contemptible, scaring those aged and infirm people, as well as war widows, by saying that they will be badly treated in relation to the integration of repatriation hospitals into the State hospital system.

ANSWER.PARA: The debate about integration has been around for some 15 years. It was not this side of the House that started it; it was the other side of the House. We continue on. It is a very important issue and one that must be dealt with, one we must come to grips with. The Prime Minister and I have given guarantees to the veterans' community, guarantees that are ironclad. If the veterans' community has any problems whatsoever in relation to integration and the rationalisation of the repatriation hospital systems, we will deal with those problems.
The Government has formed committees with the involvement of the veterans' community--

TALK.START.PARA: —Opposition members are not interested in knowing anything about it. In relation to the consultative committees concerning the integration of the repatriation hospitals, the Returned Services League is represented, the Australian Veterans and Defence Service Council is represented, Legacy is represented-all the veterans' communities are represented. Any of the problems they have and any of the fears stirred up by the scaremongering tactics of the Opposition will be dealt with. The integration of the repatriation hospital systems will not take place until all of the concerns of the veterans' community are dealt with. That is an unequivocal guarantee that is given by this side of the House. It is about time the members of the Opposition got on with doing the job of supporting integration. We have one policy of four pages from the Opposition relating to the veterans.
—What about--
—Order! The honourable member for Flinders will cease interjecting.

—Madam Speaker, the honourable member for Flinders whinges to you all the time. He is a typical whinger in the Opposition. Nevertheless, the honourable member for Farrer can speak to me at any time about integration without running around this country scaring those people who deserve better treatment, as the honourable member for Reid and the Prime Minister said today. We look after the veterans. We are proud of our record in the veteran community. What did the Opposition do for the veteran community in all the 23 years or more that it was in government? It did nothing.

—Will the Minister for Transport and Communications confirm or deny that an early commencement will be made to the proposed Badgerys Creek airport? If so, when is work expected to commence? Will international aircraft be expected to use Badgerys Creek? Will appropriate ground transport be developed between the airport and the city?

—The House will be aware that, some time ago, the Government decided that there should be a second airport in the Sydney region at Badgerys Creek. Indeed, a land acquisition program has been in place for the last couple of years and $15m is allocated in the Budget this year for further land acquisition. So the long term policy is quite clear. However, the assessment of the more immediate airport needs of the Sydney region is a matter of some concern to the Government. We have established a joint task force with the New South Wales Government which will be reporting to us in a few days on the airport needs of the Sydney region. Following receipt of that task force report the Government will decide what further steps need to be taken to address those assessed airport needs and what increase, if any, needs to take place in the pace of the development of Badgerys Creek.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Housing and Aged Care. I refer the Minister to the activities of State National Party members of parliament in Queensland announcing and presenting cheques in relation to the home and community care program (HACC), particularly meals on wheels, as well as funding for accommodation projects for the elderly. Is it not correct that the bulk of these moneys come from the Hawke Federal Government? Will the Minister take up this matter with his State counterparts in the health, aged and housing areas to ensure that, when announcements, presentations and project openings are made, due credit is given to the Federal Government for its funding role in all these areas? Will the Minister advise the House what action he can take regarding these unfair practices?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Funding and administrative procedures are issues associated with joint programs between the Commonwealth and State governments. Unfortunately, at the moment the Queensland Government, probably in its desperation, has started a practice of giving cheques for quarterly payments-not simply making an announcement at the time under the home and community care program-to National Party members for distribution to organisations. This is a sad but true story of the sort of cheap abuse of our philosophy and what has generally been the case in Australian political and governmental circles in respect of joint projects. In addition, in this specific case it is an abuse of the spirit of the HACC agreement. I understand that, on occasions, cheques have even stayed in the offices of National Party members and have not been properly handed over to the organisations. Normally, honourable members with an understanding of community organisations would realise the importance of getting these funds through on time.

ANSWER.PARA: The sad part about this is that last year the Commonwealth Government contributed over 60 per cent of funds to the home and community care program in Queensland. In fact, this year it will provide more than that-about 62 per cent. Unfortunately, the Queensland Government does not have the same commitment to the home and community care program as the Commonwealth Government as the Commonwealth Government has offered 20 per cent for growth indexation. Last year it provided only 8.84 per cent. This failure of the Queensland Government to index by 20 per cent last year has meant a loss to the Queensland community of approximately $3m in joint funds. Because of the Queensland Government's failure to commit itself to the home and community care program, those people in the Queensland communities who are caring for the frail aged and young disabled have lost about $436,000 which would have been their share of the Commonwealth Government's unmatched moneys. The Queensland community has not only lost this money but also has been forced, at the behest of the Queensland Government, to take part in its stupid political games. From today's papers it seems that the Queensland Ministers are quite good at spending money on self-promotion. It is a shame that they did not spend more money and did not put more effort into looking after Queensland's frail aged and disabled.

I wish to advise the House that I did properly attend a public meeting convened by the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Pratt) on Sunday morning, 30 October, and at all times adopted a constructive approach to the complex issues involved, in sharp contrast to this Government imposing a $5,000 levy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

—In a letter to the editor in today's Bundaberg News Mail, a former alderman of the Bundaberg City Council, Mr Aaron, accused me of raising matters dealing with the sale of the Bundaberg rifle range as part of a smear campaign against the Council. On 22 September 1988 the Council of which Mr Aaron was a member requested that I undertake investigations into the sale of the rifle range. I might add that this resolution occurred two days after aldermen of the Council had met with officers from the Department of Administrative Services who were carrying out an internal investigation.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of discrepancy in the public statements, of the Council as well as information supplied to me, I detailed information to the House. Attempts were made by people on the Bundaberg City Council to mislead the Opposition spokesman, Senator Boswell, as shown by his questions in Senate Estimates Committee hearings. His response, as well as a response from Alderman Lohse in the News Mail of 4 October, shows that, with respect to Council interest in the site, aldermen have been untruthful and other misled.
