DEBATE.TITLE: ADMINISTRATION AND CARE OF SERVICE MEN AND WOMEN

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The deliberate neglect displayed by the Government in the administration and care of Australia's servicemen and women as shown in the Report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, Personnel Wastage in the Australian Defence Force.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade entitled Personnel Wastage in the Australian Defence Force was tabled. It is appropriate that this report, this thick volume, has been tabled today, the day before Armistice Day when we remember the sacrifice that has been made in the past, as the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) reminded us, by Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel. It is a damning indictment of the Government's administration of the Defence Force and the present level of Defence Force capability in this country. In particular, it is a condemnation of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) and his four-year policy of deliberate neglect and starving of funds for the Defence Force personnel of this country in favour of some of his toys, as he describes them; some of the big ticket items.
—Where is the boy wonder?

—Where is the Minister? That is a good question. He has been posturing in fine clothes for four years as the Minister for Defence, and today his pants fell down. He has a glib tongue but he is short on any understanding of defence issues. He has shown in those four years that he has no concern for the people he commands. He has no understanding of the vital importance of service men and women in the Defence Force. He is a man obsessed with his big ticket toys, as he calls them; he has no understanding of the relationship involving defence equipment, personnel, training and facilities. He is the architect of what is now a toothless White Paper, made toothless by the low funding that defence has been given by this Government. This year 2.4 per cent of gross domestic product-the lowest proportion of GDP since 1950-will be allocated to defence. He does not understand the effect personnel wastage has on the capabilities of the Australian Defence Force.

SPEECH.PARA: I suggest that this is the end of the Minister's prime ministerial ambitions, because he will be known as the man who relegated the service men and women of this country to second-class citizen status and the man who has presided for four years over the dismemberment of the Australian Defence Force-a dismemberment that will take at least 10 years to put right. He is a failed Minister for Defence, joining a growing list of failed Ministers in this Government. He will be remembered as the Minister who has put Australia's security at risk. It is not as though he does not know. Two years ago, in a very detailed report from the Chief of the Defence Force, he was told exactly what effect this personnel wastage is having on the Australian Defence Force.

For four years this Minister has presided over this deliberate policy of neglect of personnel in favour of the purchase of items. The Opposition has been constant in its criticism of the effect this is having on the Australian Defence Force. In late 1987 the Opposition decided to take the matter out of the hands of the Government, because it was not acting, and place it in the hands of this Parliament by asking the Senate to direct the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee to have a look at it. Today we have the results of its labours.

I congratulate the Committee on producing a thorough and honest report and thank the Chairman and members of the Committee, all those who made submissions and all those who appeared as witnesses-except, of course, the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly), who appeared before the Committee and made a typical attempt to cover up what was really happening in the Australian Defence Force. There were 226 submissions, 4,000 pages of evidence and a visit to numerous bases, which shows the level of concern in the community about this issue. The report totally supports the Opposition's claims about the state of the Australian Defence Force. The report also, I might say, gives the Opposition a bit of a serve for neglect in some areas, and that is fair enough. But the Government can no longer ignore this major problem. This defence report has highlighted the problem areas, and the Government must act.

I want to make special mention of the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. In August 1987, shortly after she took up this job, she said, `Frankly, I think the whole issue is incredibly exaggerated'. I suspect that she still does not understand the extent of the problem. She has been reflecting Minister Beazley's views, which have been ignorant and misguided. At various times she has blamed this wastage on the trainees, the number of women in the Services, the Vietnam hump-or the Vietnam god, of course-the airlines' poaching, demographic changes and recruits on full time duty. Even the Opposition's comments are supposed to have caused the problem as well. The fault lies in everything but the deliberate policy of Minister Beazley of running down defence personnel.

The Minister has been asked to act by an all-party committee. The Minister's actions to date have been pathetic. The report notes that point. It states that the Minister's actions have been reactive and applied in a random fashion. For example, the pilot retention bonus has caused far more problems than it set out to solve. This Minister has joined the list of failed Ministers.

The report notes that people are the most important ingredient in any defence effort. In 1983 we lost 6,500 people from the Australian Defence Force. In 1987 the number was 9,000. In the first six months of this year the number was 5,000, so it will be 10,000 this year. The loss of pilots has been well documented. In particular, these enormous losses have been of people who have not reached pensionable age, so all the younger, better members of the Australian Defence Force are the ones who are leaving. The Minister has consistently stated that there are shortages in some areas. The report condemns the Minister for saying so, because the shortages are right across the board. They include trainees, officers in all the Services, Army non-commissioned officers, Navy engineers, Navy warfare officers, technical sailors, submariners, signal officers, Army tradesmen, Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) engineers, pilots, technical airmen and flight engineers. The list goes on and on. The report states:
The extent and magnitude of wastage is such that it will adversely affect the ADF for at least the next decade.

All service leaders have acknowledged that point to the Committee and have also told the Minister. RAAF units are not operational. Army has a limited capacity in the field. The report makes particular mention of morale in the ADF. Low morale spreads like a cancer. Morale is low because of Government neglect, because of lack of self-esteem, because people feel they are not required, because of the long hours of work-55 hours a week on average at the last survey-and, as one witness said, because more and more is being asked of loyal and committed people with little or no giving back. Job satisfaction is nil. As witnesses said, `It is abysmal; career planning is abysmal; there are continual crises-it is moribund'.

In relation to equipment deficiencies, as the report rightly notes, in 1988 soldiers, sailors and airmen are shopping in secondhand stores to purchase boots, combat clothing and ammunition. People stationed at Holsworthy recently bought their own paint to make their barracks habitable. The report notes that the Minister has given no recognition to the fact that this is a separate profession of arms. Training deficiencies are well listed.

The Defence Force retirement and death benefits scheme needs to be reviewed. Pay and conditions of service are abysmal. Every time there is a legitimate pay claim before the Tribunal, the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel says it is not warranted. The one person to whom they look to support their case is the one who is knocking them. There are cuts in operating expenses. I come to the question of Russell Offices. The report states:
. . . the Government's continuing refusal to promote more harmonious and efficient working relationships between the broad military and civilian component . . . remains . . . a mystery.

This is not the first time that this Committee has mentioned this point. In its last report relating to the management of the ADF it said exactly the same thing. It said civilians were in the ascendancy. It said that the Minister for Defence was not taking note of his military advice. It said, `For God's sake, fix it up'. Minister Beazley said that the last report was a lot of nonsense. The witnesses who gave evidence before this Committee, time and time again were asked about working conditions and the relationship between the military personnel and civilians at Russell Offices. Many of them said, `I would rather resign than work at Russell'-and so they did. Nothing has been done about that situation. The Minister has constantly bypassed military advice. Whenever there is an important job to be done the Minister hooks in a few civilian cronies to do the job, because he has a fundamental dislike and distrust of service personnel.

The report takes particular note of manpower levels and recommends that action be taken to provide satisfactory levels of staffing. General O'Donnell said, `We have a 38,000 man task but only a 32,000 man army'. General Jeffery, of the First Division, after last year's Diamond Dollar exercise, said `I'm supposed to be able to take to the field for 12 months, but where are the men? At best we might last between four to six weeks'.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mrs Kelly

TALK.START.PARA: —He didn't say those things-- Mr WHITE-The Minister thinks this is a joke. She has been sitting at the table giggling and trying to fill in for the Minister for Defence, who is not here. He has been passing the buck to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel for at least 12 months and he has not been passing it successfully. He is not going to pass this one. The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel might have some responsibility for this area but the ultimate responsibility rests with the Minister for Defence.

INTERJECT.PARA: Admiral Hudson, Chief of Naval Staff, has advised a shortage of 1,200 men. I am un- aware of what the Chief of Air Staff thinks. Every time he is asked he says that the Air Force does not have a problem. However, in the last week or so he has echoed the statements of the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel and is now saying that there might be a problem. The report condemns the Minister's activities regarding looking after families. It recommends the production of a White Paper on families. That is how important the Committee thinks this issue is, and I agree with it. All the Minister has done is to make some minor cosmetic changes. The list goes on and on. The cost of training because of this wastage is enormous. The experienced levels have dropped to disastrous levels, so that many of the units in the Australian Defence Force are no longer operational.

This is a most serious indictment of any government department by any joint parliamentary committee report that has been tabled in this House. All of the things which have been said by the Opposition, the Returned Services League, the Defence Welfare Association and the Armed Forces Federation are true and are now confirmed by this report. Most of the recommendations in the report could be carried out at reasonably low cost. The Government must act on this report. The first thing it should do is to clear out two useless Ministers who have presided over this disintegration and appoint someone capable of doing the job.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs KELLY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance has come about as a result of a parliamentary committee report tabled in this House only a few hours ago. The report, which is over 400 pages long and encompasses almost 50 recommendations, I believe, is to be commended, and I do so as the Minister responsible for implementing many of the recommendations. I was absolutely appalled by the Opposition's performance during this matter of public importance. The shadow Minister for Defence, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), in his speech merely raised all the old points and did not pick up any of the constructive points raised in this very constructive report. Instead, he quoted from I do not know what. The points that were made in this report are quite congratulatory of my personal efforts and the efforts of this Government in the area of the Australian Defence Force's conditions. Instead of noting those comments, the shadow Minister for Defence used this opportunity to introduce party politics into debate on this very constructive bipartisan report a few hours after it was tabled in this House. This report deserves much better treatment than to have it debated in that way four hours after it was tabled.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to thank all the members of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade for their contributions because there is no doubt that many of the recommendations are very constructive. Unlike the shadow Minister, I do not intend to make quick decisions in relation to this report four hours after it has been tabled. Instead, I intend to have a look at it in detail and make a constructive and considered report to this House. I was again disappointed by the Opposition's absolute lack of constructive policies to deal with what is considered and acknowledged by me and by the Government to be a problem. Obviously, that has been endorsed by the Committee's report.

We get from the Opposition time and time again negative comments that affect the morale of the Defence Force. Opposition members should ask members of the Defence Force bases what they think of the shadow Minister. Service people will tell them that the shadow Minister is very negative and that he still lives in the 1950s. It is a joke to compare him with the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) in the same breath. What an absolute joke. Opposition members should ask any single person on our bases what he or she thinks of the Minister for Defence. Service people will tell the honourable member that he is the best Minister for Defence this country has ever had. Why? It is because he has made them proud to be members of the Australian Defence Force. He has given them the defence White Paper, which sets the parameters for defence into the next decade.

What did the Opposition ever do when it was in government? What does it do now in opposition? What is the Opposition policy? What does it stand for? Nothing. All the Opposition does is get up in this Parliament and complain, whinge and gripe. The Opposition gripes about the Minister for Defence and it gripes about me. Of course now the Opposition is using the opportunity of the presentation of a bipartisan, well-constructed report to this Parliament to raise the same old issues again. It introduces not one new or constructive idea about what to do about the report. Opposition members just get up and whinge and say, `There is a problem'. We know there is a problem. The difference between the Government and the Opposition is that the Government is getting on with the issues and resolving them. That is acknowledged in the Committee report.
I want to thank the Committee's Chairman and the members of the Committee for their very constructive comments. For example, paragraph 56 refers to the work that the Government has done:

The Committee notes that in the past year the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, the ADF and the Department have taken a number of initiatives which appear constructive, but which may not as yet have had time to impact on separation rates.

We are seeing a change in those separation figures. I do not want to raise expectations in relation to them but I want to make a few points on the figures for the last couple of months. Indications are-they are only indications at this stage-that they have bottomed out and that the situation is improving, particularly in the category which had been of concern to us; that is, officer resignation levels. The initial figures for the last few months indicate some improvement in that field. But I do not want to follow that through any further at this stage, because I think it is better to wait until we get endorsement of further months.

We have been dealing quite constructively with conditions of service. I just want to take honourable members through some of the things that have been done in the last few months. There have been substantial improvements in pay and conditions of service. There has been prompt and full flow-on of the national wage case. There have been substantial and specific increases in service allowance, field allowance, submarine allowance, seagoing allowance and disturbance allowance. The flying allowance, as honourable members know, is up by 75 per cent.

Obviously, it is not just money that is the problem. This is one of the things highlighted by the Joint Parliamentary Committee's report. The report highlighted the complexity of the problem. That is something that the Opposition has not come to terms with. There are so many issues that contribute to this problem. They have all been raised in this Committee report. A lot of the problems relate to families and family expectations; there is no doubt about that. That is why this Government has given priority to dealing with family issues. In relation to that, we have set up an elaborate family support system. We now have formal mechanisms for the spouses to be able to put their views to the chiefs and also to me.

TALK.START.PARA: —More committees.

—They are not about more committees. They are about letting us know and getting action. When the Opposition was in government it took no notice of Defence Force spouses. The Opposition was totally dismissive of their attitudes and most Opposition members still are. We see the Defence Force as a family. The families must be considered. That is what we are doing and that is what we are addressing.

SPEECH.PARA: There are issues that relate to the family, including specific ones such as education. We have dealt with that issue. I take note of the point that the Committee has made about the education allowance. Mobility is a problem. It will always be a problem. But we are trying to ease that problem by a new three-year posting policy, with back to back postings if possible. I have been dealing with State governments, as is acknowledged in the Committee recommendations. I am trying to get better conditions for the people who have to cross State boundaries all the time. Single members of the Defence Force have also been helped. It is critical that we give consideration to the single members of the Defence Force because 50 per cent of members of the Defence Force are single. We have had better removal entitlements, better accommodation and better entitlement to disturbance allowance.

The key area where we have seen dramatic progress is in housing. When the Opposition was in government it deprived the Defence Force of decent living conditions. We have spent at least $2 for every $1 that was ever spent under the Opposition. One of the reasons we have got such a backlog with housing is the Opposition's years of neglect. We have established a proper mechanism for getting housing maintenance done. We have bought houses all over Australia. We have considerably improved our housing stocks. We have not solved the problem-I acknowledge that-but we are making progress. Everyone out there on the Defence Force bases would give us credit for making progress. Let me tell honourable members that we have a long way to go after all the Opposition's years of neglect.

But attention to families and conditions of service is not enough. One needs to look at other issues too. One of the key issues is job satisfaction. The shadow Minister referred to it principally as the Russell syndrome. There is a lot to be said about the problems associated with moving people from operational commands to Russell. This is an issue that is being very seriously examined and dealt with in the administration of defence in each of the services. We have increased the devolution of responsibility. Devolution of financial responsibility is one of the big initiatives this year. It is critical. Obviously it is taking time to filter down to the units. But devolution of financial responsibility, moving responsibility to the operational unit, is the key to job satisfaction. In respect of open-ended engagements, open reporting systems and more responsive crew management, I acknowledge that, as is indicated in the Committee report, we have got further to go. I thank the Committee for its very constructive points in that area. Improved communication through the system is another area. I also welcome the recommendations that the Committee has made, particularly in relation to improving the public relations image of the Defence Force in this country.

I just want to make a brief point about the pilots' bonus because that was referred to by the shadow Minister. The pilots' bonus was never intended by itself to fix the pilots' problems. It is one part of a package. It is a commitment of this Government to deal with what we see as a critical problem. If we had not brought in the pilots' bonus, I know what we would be talking about today: it would be the need for a pilots' bonus. We brought it in. We have had a take-up rate of just over 50 per cent. That is what I expected from the beginning. There was consultation about that bonus.

A visiting American general was discussing it with us this morning. He said that his main criticism is that the American Congress has taken too long to introduce it. We have acted. Pilots can see that we are committed to dealing with the problem. We did not need a detailed parliamentary committee report before we acted. We decided we would make the bonus part of our package to encourage pilots to stay in the Defence Force. It is only one part of the package. It was never intended by itself to be the total solution to the problem. There are many other aspects that have to be dealt with regarding pilot retention rates. One approach with which I am particularly pleased is the aircrew specialisation program which will be introduced next year. These are very important initiatives.

I endorse the comment in the report that this is a complex issue. We are taking action to resolve the issue. As I said, it looks as though the problem is bottoming out. I believe that morale in the Defence Force has improved dramatically in the last six months, but it is not helped by the constant negative comments from the Opposition. That point was endorsed by the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Cross) in his comments in Parliament this morning when he said that personnel wastage has been the subject of considerable media attention and that the extent of that attention may even have contributed to the wastage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you blaming us?

—I am blaming the Opposition for its constant negative approach. The Defence Force of this country is a defence force of which we can be proud. This Government has provided leadership in dealing with its many problems. I am the first to acknowledge that the Defence Force still has them and that many personnel have a very hard life. But, instead of having positive points coming from the Opposition that can add to the morale of the Defence Force, we have negative comments. If Opposition members were members of the Defence Force, how would they feel if they were told that everybody is leaving? One would start to wonder what one was doing there. That is the sort of attitude that the Opposition is encouraging. The shadow Minister for defence is beating up the whole issue. Today's example is typical. A constructive report has been brought down by a parliamentary committee, yet he makes the same old negative comments in this Parliament which add nothing to the debate. I congratulate the Committee for its very constructive report. I will be reporting to the Parliament in a short time on those very constructive recommendations. I deplore the Opposition's cheap political tactics of making negative comments about a defence force of which this country is very proud and to which this Government is very committed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just had from the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) a total abrogation of her responsibility, of her ministerial oath and of the role of the Government in looking after the defence forces of this nation. She attempted to blame the Opposition for the situation arrived at after five years of Labor Government whereby the resignation rate, the wastage rate or whatever one wants to call it had become such a factor in the defence forces of this country that it was necessary to produce a special parliamentary report. I reject the Minister's criticisms. I will return to them shortly.

SPEECH.PARA: The previous coalition Government took a number of courageous decisions, in contrast to what the Minister has had to say. For example, it created Norforce, the North-West Mobile Force. It made bold decentralisation moves against considerable odds, such as to the Albury-Wodonga military area from Melbourne. It built up the Townsville area, and so forth. So the Opposition rejects utterly any responsibility for the situation which has now been arrived at. We have a bipartisan report from the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade entitled Personnel wastage in the Australian Defence Force-bipartisan except for the useless dissenting report of Senator Vallentine that is not worth commenting on in any detail. We heard the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) refer to the following comment in the report:
The extent and magnitude of wastage in some of those areas is such that it will adversely affect the ADF for at least the next decade.

That is like putting up a sign around our coastlines which says to any enemy heading towards Australia, `Don't come now: come back in 1998. We might be ready for you then'. We have heard officially in the context of this report that we are not ready to defend our country for at least another decade as a consequence of the personnel wastage. The report further states:

In sum the effects of wastage . . . amount to a loss of operational capability. It is manifestly obvious that the prevailing excessive level of personnel wastage is damaging the organisational health of the ADF. Wastage is undermining the experience and competence levels of personnel.
It goes on to say:
At the psychological level, morale has fallen and the potential has been created for institutional and community polarisation.

The truth is now out as to where we have arrived in terms of the state of our defence forces, in terms of their morale, in terms of their conditions and even in terms of their re-equipment which has come about as a consequence of the role played by not only the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, who is at the table, but also by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). In this regard I reiterate the point that these two Ministers have now joined the long list of Ministers who have failed in the administration of their portfolios. They have failed in the same way as have the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West), the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), and the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples). They are all in that list together. The Defence Minister has a lot to answer for in terms of our defence forces, their morale and conditions as so carefully laid out in this report.

Let me examine two aspects relating to these two Ministers. As the honourable member for McPherson indicated, the Minister for Defence openly admits that he is all about re-equipment, to the disadvantage and the downgrading of manpower resources, priorities and policies. We are now paying the price for that approach by this rapid and record rate of resignations. Let me turn to the Minister at the table. She is known around some of the Australian Army, Royal Australian Navy and Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) units as the `cocooned Minister for Defence Science and Personnel'. That all came about following that famous visit to Townsville. One afternoon during the visit the Minister went to meet the spouses of personnel, which was not unreasonable. Some off-duty serving personnel turned up. Do honourable members know what happened after that? We had to have cocooned guidelines for future visits by this Minister to any Army, Navy or Air Force unit in Australia. There had to be a special set of guidelines to ensure that the Minister was protected, taken away from hearing any direct criticism.

I will give the Minister credit for having travelled far and wide to meet armed forces units but she has done so in a cocoon, a cocoon officially laid out in guidelines approved and drawn up by the armed forces. So the true digger is unable to get across to the Minister in the course of those liaison visits.

When I went to Shoalwater Bay two months ago, I sat down for one hour with Delta Company 6RAR. It was open slather-questions and answers-on a hilltop in the Shoalwater Bay exercise area. I learned a great deal from that about what the personnel are thinking at this time. I will tell the House what they are thinking and what stage they have reached. They have run out of trust. They have a total lack of trust in the Government-in the Parliament, by degrees but in the Government in particular-and in what they denote as the system. Why do they have that lack of trust? As was accurately pointed out by the honourable member for McPherson, the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson) and others, the difficulties have been created by the huge windback that has occurred in the five years of Labor government. It has created difficulties in the Defence Force retirement and death benefits scheme. It has created difficulties in housing. Some attempt has been made to overcome the problems but they have not yet been rectified. It has created difficulties in the pay scales and the remuneration problems have gone on far too long without being rectified. It has created difficulties, as we learned yesterday, in the rations.

Do honourable members know what this Government has done to our defence forces in recent times? It has said that grilling steak is far too good for our soldiers, sailors and airmen. They are to come back to mince and chuck steak. Grilling steak is to be taken off the menu, along with a series of fresh vegetables and the like. I will not dwell on that detailed aspect of what is clearly an horrific administrative order which, hopefully, will be rescinded. But it is symptomatic of the approach of this Government. Soldiers, sailors and airmen no longer trust the system and are, as a consequence, voting with their feet and leaving the Services in large numbers, as identified and recognised in the Cross report.

There has been a huge downgrading of the level of experience in our Navy, Army and Air Force. Because of this lack of trust so many have departed the scene. As a consequence the Government is up for even more costs because it will have to train hundreds of new recruits to try to make up for the experience wastage rate. Clearly, the difference cannot be made up. In a sense-dare I refer to it?-the situation is not dissimilar from the situation of certain mining industries, such as the gold industry, rapidly mining high grade ore rather than proceeding on a more systematic basis. The high grade ore of manpower in the Navy, Army and Air Force is leaving in huge numbers. The low grade ore of new recruits, who need years to get up to the same level of proficiency, are coming in, but not in sufficient numbers.

There is an element of danger in all this-real danger in peacetime. Because there is such a lack of experience at various levels and in a large number of units, the peacetime fatality rate of our armed forces is increasing in an alarming way. I refer to the submarine tragedy of last year. I refer to the incident involving the armoured personnel carrier in Victoria last month. I refer to the RAAF statistics mentioned by the honourable member for Casey earlier today when the report was tabled. Leaving aside wartime for the moment, we are not even making a go of it in peacetime. Lives are being put at risk in peacetime as a consequence of the equation which now obtains.

I say to the House that the Government must act, and must act now, on the Cross report. Not to put too much of a point on it, our defence forces are at the crossroads in terms of their future. Unless action is taken, the whole of our Navy, Army and Air Force will be gutted. There will be no turnaround, not even within 10 years. We cannot turn the clock back so we should look to the future. We should reject all the mistakes that have been made in the past. The Government has to get it right this time or it will pay an enormous price. This arrogant, out of touch, X-rated Government must act on defence this time around. It has the blueprint. It is now or never. The soldiers are looking for the right signal, and I am not confident that this Government will give it. It is for that reason that we have brought forward this matter of public importance today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cross Mr M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak on this subject for the second time today. This morning it was my privilege to present the report by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, entitled Personal wastage in the Australian Defence Force, which was debated in the House. I had hoped that this debate would have taken place when the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) had made a response to the report. It is an objective report. It has tried to be fair. It has made some criticisms of a range of matters affecting the Australian Defence Force because it reflects the evidence that we took from members of the Australian Defence Force. We would have been failing in our responsibility to those men and women, who spent a good deal of time talking to us about their concerns and problems, if we had not registered those concerns and problems.

SPEECH.PARA: I congratulate the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) on the generous way in which she has made an interim response to that report in what she has just said. It would have been no pleasant task to have received a report on a matter as complex as this. The problems have not just come out of the woodwork. They have been around for years. Some have been extremely difficult to solve because they relate to societal changes. I thank the Minister for her generous response.

I would also like to reply to some of the criticisms that have been made of her. I have had the opportunity to be present with the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel amongst Defence people I know at places such as Enoggera and elsewhere. She has responded to those people in an absolutely marvellous way. She is a great communicator. On a number of occasions I have seen her sitting down with former service men and women, and serving men and women discussing their problems with them.

When the Tange report came down in 1973 I was one of the people who were keen to have a Minister for defence personnel appointed because I was aware of the workload carried by the then Minister for Defence and member for Bass, Mr Barnard. I was delighted when, for the first time, this Labor Government appointed a Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. If the Opposition is so interested in Defence personnel why, in its long period of government, did it never appoint a Minister with that responsibility?

I ought to say a few things about the criticisms in the report. The armed forces have adapted to changing circumstances over the years. Pilot wastage in the forces reflects the demands of civil and international aviation. We have been through a period when international air travel was at a fairly low ebb. Now, particularly with Australia's Bicentennial and World Expo 88, there is a great demand for pilots in Australia for our domestic airlines, for our international airline, Qantas Airways Ltd, and for other international airlines.

Over time the Defence Force has felt that its problems were cyclical, that one addresses the problems of the day and eventually the system works out all right. The thrust of our report is that we have to deal with and accommodate the changes that have taken place in society. Visiting the various Defence establishments, one noticed the extent to which education was advanced, particularly the education of secondary school children. Everybody today is concerned about the education of their secondary school sons and daughters. That is not a new problem. We discussed it in the Whitlam Government days. I remember discussing it with the father of the Minister for Defence, who was then the Minister for Education.

No Federal Government has gone down the track of trying to sort out those problems. In recent times, with the encouragement of the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), on behalf of this Government, has placed on the agenda of the State education Ministers the matter of a common core curriculum across the nation and that of a common school entry age. Tell me that that is something that has just come out of the woodwork. It was always put into the too hard basket because it did not involve only the Commonwealth. It involves discussions with the States. We all understand the sensitivities involved in trying to get the States to agree on such matters. I would like to see much more done in the way of education allowances and other provisions in the Defence Force budget. There is no doubt that we lose many talented people because of the secondary education problem in defence.

I was interested, and a little amazed, to hear the Opposition introduce housing into this discussion. In the Defence Force, it takes some time to get a new and innovative project up and running. After the election of the Labor Government in 1983 we looked at the problems that obviously existed in the area of Defence housing. Studies were undertaken. An interdepartmental committee was set up. A report came back. It went to the Department of Defence. A model was eventually developed and trialled. Legislative support was given to that model last year and provision was made for it in the Budget.

Perhaps it takes more time than any of us would wish to get those things in place, but consider what has happened. Everybody who understands the Defence Force knows that the old system of putting defence personnel into welfare housing has failed. Everybody knows that that decision by the Menzies Government in 1953 has resulted in defence personnel living in depressed areas throughout Australia. I am not reflecting on the people who live there. I accept that there is a great deal of importance to public housing and that there should be more of it, but we want a better type of housing.

Let us examine what the Government has done in the last couple of years since that decision has been in place and reflect on the previous Government. I asked a question of the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel which was answered on 22 August. I asked her what had been spent on defence housing over the past 10 years. Let me go back and look at the figures under the previous Government. The figure for 1979-80 is $4m. The figure for 1980-81 is $5.3m. For 1981-82 it is $16.7m. One can then look at what has happened in the last couple of years. We have been rolling along at more than $50m. Last year it was $270m, and this year it is $250m. We now have a structure in place; it now has a budget; it is operating in a decentralised way. But the problem is so vast that it will take many years to solve.

I have the honour of representing Enoggera, and anyone serving at Enoggera would know that some of the old houses have been pulled down and new townhouses are being erected. One would also be aware of the update of the singles service accommodation at a place like that. At other places it has not happened yet, but the Government is now spending each year, more than 20 times what the Opposition spent for many years in its term in office. These are the sorts of problems with which the Government has had to contend.

I should like to say a couple of things about some of the comments that were made. The shadow Minister, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), mentioned big ticket toys. I did not notice which of them he would like to see cut out of the Budget, but the Joint Committee believes that all of that capital works program and all of the money spent on facilities is money well spent. The Government would like to see more money spent on personnel; we suggested some ways in which we believe it could be done.

The comment was again made in this House that the best have left, and that is a disgraceful reflection on the people who have stayed. We had evidence about that and we asked people about that, and some very good people have left. But it does nothing for the morale of the Defence Force and it does nothing to help those people who are staying there, working hard and long hours and carrying important responsibilities to be told that they are the dregs; they are the people who are left behind when the best have left. The shadow Minister and other members of the Opposition should be ashamed of themselves for saying that the best have left. Thank heavens we know that that is not true. They talk about units no longer being operational. We have problems-they are serious problems-but this report addresses those problems.

The Minister has indicated that she will come back in a timely way. Let us have this debate once again when we have the Government's response. A great deal has been done under this Government and this Minister and we give them credit for that. What we are really saying is that more has to be done. We have to persuade the people that operate the Treasury purse strings in this nation to be more sympathetic in matters like the ones we are discussing.

DEBATE.TITLE: LAW AND JUSTICE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Lionel Bowen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill amends several Acts within the Attorney-General's portfolio and a related Act administered by the Minister for Housing and Aged Care. The Bill contains amendments of a minor policy nature. Other amendments tidy up, correct or update existing legislation. None of the amendments concerns major new policy proposals or sensitive policy issues. None have any significant financial impact. The amendments to the Law Officers Act will have a slight financial impact. They provide for a pension for a Solicitor-General based on a judge's pension, deferred until age 60 and discounted both for shorter term of service and the difference between age at cessation of office and 60 years. The removal of the current entitlement of a lump sum equal to twice annual salary at the end of a seven-year appointment, represents an offset against the cost of the new pension. The proposed amendments are explained in the explanatory memorandum circulated with the Bill. I propose to confine my comments to the more noteworthy amendments.
Amendments to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975

Amendments to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act will provide for term appointments as an alternative to the existing situation of appointments to age 70 in the case of full-time Deputy Presidents and to age 65 in the case of full-time senior members. The maximum term of such appointments would be seven-years, but reappointment could be made. At present the option of term appointment is only available for part time Deputy Presidents, part-time senior members and ordinary members. The inclusion of term appointments as an alternative to tenured appointments for full-time Deputy Presidents and senior members will provide greater flexibility in staffing the Tribunal, primarily by enabling appointment of members on a short term basis to handle particular backlogs or initial peaks in work when new jurisdictions are conferred on the Tribunal. The amendments are also expected to result in a widening of the pool of potential appointees to include those who might not wish to consider a career appointment.

A consequential amendment to section 16 of the Act will exclude the application of the Judges' Pensions Act 1968 to term appointees. At present, the Judges' Pensions Act applies to a full time Deputy President as if he or she were a judge. Part time Deputy Presidents are excluded, and the amendment means that full time Deputy Presidents who are term appointees will also be excluded. Other amendments to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act will ensure that in proceedings before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the States and the Northern Territory will have the same entitlement as the Commonwealth to claim public interest privilege in respect of documents subpoenaed by the Tribunal and questions asked in the course of a proceeding which relate to Cabinet documents or the deliberations of Cabinet, or otherwise support a claim of public interest privilege.
Amendments to the Australian Federal Police Act 1979

One amendment to the Australian Federal Police Act will give greater flexibility in administration, as the Commissioner, and not the Minister, will be empowered to determine the number of officers in the various rank levels of the Australian Federal Police. Other amendments, based on provisions in the Public Service Act will ensure that all persons eligible for appointment have a reasonable opportunity to apply for appointment to the Australian Federal Police. They will ensure equity and fairness in appointments, promotions and transfers, apply the merit principle and prohibit patronage, favouritism, and discrimination on various specified grounds as well as unlawful or any other unjustified discrimination. Also provision is made for review of non-appealable promotion decisions by the Merit Protection and Review Agency.
Amendments to the Customs Act 1901

An amendment to the Customs Act will specifically abrogate the privilege against self-incrimination in respect of a statement furnished to the Official Trustee in Bankruptcy pursuant to a court order.

However, evidence obtained as a direct or indirect consequence of furnishing such a statement to the Official Trustee will not be admissible in civil or criminal proceedings, other than a proceeding in respect of falsity of the statement, or a proceeding for the recovery of a pecuniary penalty. In the latter case it will be admissible only for the purpose of facilitating the assessment of the amount of the penalty. This places information contained in such a statement in the same position as information obtained pursuant to a court-ordered examination of the person.
Amendments to the Director of Public Prosecutions Act 1983
An amendment to the Director of Public Prosecutions Act will remove any doubt that may exist that the Director has the right to seek review of a bail decision.
Amendments to the Family Law Act 1975

An amendment will make a minor jurisdictional change in relation to the application of the Family Law Act in the Northern Territory. It will remove jurisdiction from the Family Court of Australia, in matters arising under a law of the Northern Territory, thereby treating the Northern Territory in the same way as a State.

Other amendments to the Family Law Act will ensure that a lawyer appointed by the court as a separate representative for a child, in proceedings concerning the child's welfare, has adequate and effective powers to obtain a report by a psychologist or psychiatrist for use in the proceedings. The repeal of subsection 78(3) of the Act will enable the court, in appropriate cases, to make orders that are binding on third parties as well as the parties to a marriage.

Many family law property disputes involve adjudication of the rights of the parties to a marriage as between themselves and third parties, such as banks. As the Act presently stands, third parties may intervene in proceedings under the Act pursuant to section 92, but may not be bound by any order of the court as a consequence of subsection 78(3). The present lack of power to make binding determinations about the existence and extent of the rights and liabilities of third parties can be frustrating for both the court and the parties as well as adding to the expense of proceedings. For example even if a court concludes that particular property does not belong to either party to the marriage but to a third party, the court cannot, because of subsection 78(3), make any declaration or order in favour of the third party.

The repeal of subsection 78(3) will also ensure that the Commonwealth and State cross-vesting legislation which came into force on 1 July 1988 has full effect in relation to the Family Court by enabling that court to determine the rights and liabilities of third parties in proceedings before it where it is appropriate and convenient for it to do so. This amendment gives effect to a recommendation of the Law Reform Commission in its report on matrimonial property and to comments by the Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia and the Chief Justice of the Family Court of Australia.
Amendments to the Law Officers Act 1964

Currently, unless a Solicitor-General completes 10 years service he or she is not entitled to a judicial pension. However, under provisions in the Law Officers Act, a Solicitor-General who has completed seven years service-the normal term of appointment-receives a lump sum payment equal to twice annual salary. This provision was intended to assist a Solicitor-General who is not reappointed at the end of that term to re-establish himself or herself in private practice. While, the sum may be adequate for that purpose, it does not adequately cater for the Solicitor-General's security or that of his or her family if the Solicitor-General dies or become incapacitated after ceasing to hold office.

Accordingly, the Law Officers Act is to be amended to provide for a deferred pension for the Solicitor-General, payable at age 60, after completing seven years service, or on prior death or invalidity, based on similar criteria for a judicial pension. The pension at age 60 is to be discounted by 2.5 per cent per year for the difference between the age on cessation of office and age 60.
Amendments to the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987

The Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act was amended by the Crimes Legislation Amendment Act (No. 2) 1988, to insert new foreign law testimonial immunity provisions intended to preserve the foreign testimonial immunity of witnesses who come to Australia to give evidence, and to confer similar immunity on persons who give evidence in Australia at the request of foreign countries. This Bill amends the Act to make it clear that such immunity will not apply in any case where its application would be inconsistent with the applicable Mutual Assistance Treaty.
Amendments to the National Crime Authority Act 1984

Amendments to the National Crime Authority Act will streamline the method of appointing members to the National Crime Authority by allowing recommendations to be made within three months before or after the occurrence of a vacancy. At present, recommendations for appointment of members can be made only after the actual occurrence of a vacancy.
Amendments to the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987

There are several amendments to the Proceeds of Crime Act most of which have been requested by the Inspector-General in Bankruptcy and the Director of Public Prosecutions in the light of practical experience with the Act. Some amendments provide protection to bona fide third parties whose property interests are affected by registered foreign forfeiture orders, broadly similar to the protection provided in relation to domestic forfeiture orders. There are also a number of machinery amendments that are necessary having regard to experience with the Act to date, dealing with such matters as the meaning of the term `effective control of property', permitting the court to make composite restraining orders covering both known property of the defendant as well as property acquired after the making of the order and abrogating the privilege against self-incrimination with respect to court-ordered statements furnished to the Official Trustee in Bankruptcy. An indemnity, similar to that contained in the amendments to the Customs Act, is included. The opportunity has been taken to generally improve the wording of a number of existing provisions.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Tuckey) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Holding, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to the provisions of the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer: Australia can then ratify the Protocol. Also, the legislation will put in place measures whereby the emissions to air of substances that deplete the shield of ozone gas in the upper atmosphere will be substantially reduced beyond the minimum requirements of the Protocol, thereby safeguarding to the maximum practicable extent human health and the environment.

Protection of the ozone layer is one of the Government's highest environmental priorities. While the Montreal Protocol requires a 50 per cent reduction in the use of ozone depleting substances over 10 years, the proposals contained in the Bill should enable Australia to achieve those reductions in half that time.

Honourable members are undoubtedly aware that small amounts of ozone gas in the upper atmosphere shield living things on earth from the harmful ultraviolet radiation present in sunlight. Emissions to air of some synthetic chemicals-certain chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) and halons are the main ones-can break down this ozone shield, with serious implications for human health and the environment. CFCs are also powerful greenhouse gases and would be worthy of control on this account even if there were no concern about ultraviolet radiation.

Emissions of CFCs arise from their use in about 20 per cent of aerosol sprays, in refrigeration and air conditioning, in some plastic foams, in some dry cleaning machinery and as degreasing solvents in the electronics and other industries. Halons are used in specialised fire protection. Most industries, notably aerosol filling and foam packaging, are already converting to ozone-safe alternatives.

The main body of scientific advice shows that there has been a global decrease in stratospheric ozone of between 2 and 3 per cent over the last 9 years, approximately half of which is not attributable to natural causes. The seasonal decrease in stratospheric ozone over Antarctica is now well known. In 1977 the `ozone hole' was the worst ever-with around a 50 per cent reduction from normal levels of ozone. Although this year's rate of depletion is not nearly so strong, there is, nonetheless strong evidence that links the presence of CFCs to this phenomenon. The unique meteorology during winter and spring over Antarctica sets up an isolated air mass, the polar vortex, which is accompanied by very low temperatures. The low temperatures lead to the formation of stratospheric clouds which appear to greatly increase the potency of CFCs to destroy ozone.

Protection of the ozone layer is an environmental issue of world importance which requires urgent action. The implications for Australia arising from ozone depletion are especially important in terms of a possible increase in the already high incidence of skin cancers, possible damage to primary industries, and our interest in preservation of the Antarctic environment.

In 1987 Australia became a party to the Vienna Convention for the Protection of the Ozone Layer. In June 1988 Australia signed the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer. The Protocol which is due to take effect from 1 January 1989 establishes a requirement to limit the domestic supply of the specified CFCs according to a tightening program which will freeze supply at the 1986 level, with effect from mid-1989; reduce supply by 20 per cent from 1993; and reduce supply by a further 30 per cent from 1998. The Protocol also requires that the supply of halon gases be frozen at the 1986 level, with effect from 1990. The commencement date for the first control action for both the CFCs and halons will be delayed if the Protocol does not enter into force on 1 January 1989.

The Protocol also provides for periodic reviews of its control requirements based upon scientific, technical and economic considerations. The first review is to be completed by 1990. Recognising that the latest scientific findings indicate that chlorofluorocarbons are responsible for the Antarctic ozone hole and are also implicated in the small global losses already identified, it is likely that the Protocol will be significantly strengthened after the review is complete.

The provisions of the Bill have been the subject of extensive liaison between my Department and industries which manufacture, import and use CFCs and halons. For example, in May this year Senator Richardson met with industry representatives. As a result of that meeting, a series of action plans were produced and the Bill's provisions reflect the recommendations of those plans. Liaison has also been maintained through an interdepartmental working group on ozone and with the industry group, the Association of Fluorocarbon Consumers and Manufacturers. State governments and consumer and conservation groups have also been consulted. I am advised that industry supports the proposals in the Bill.

The Bill provides for a system of licences and tradeable quotas for the production, import and export of scheduled substances, and controls on the applications of scheduled substances so as to limit, so far as is practicable, the emissions of these substances to the air. The licence and quota provisions relate to Australia's obligations under the protocol. Licences will be granted to persons who produced, imported or exported scheduled substances during the year 1986. Quota will be granted to the same persons according to their market share in 1986. Once they have their quota, they will be free to buy and sell their share of quota on the open market. Total quota on issue will be adjusted according to the provisions of the protocol.

The second category of restrictions gives effect to Government's determination to take all reasonable steps to exceed the minimum requirements laid down in the protocol. These controls on applications include:

prohibition from 31 December 1989 of the manufacture or import of aerosol sprays containing scheduled substances, except for some limited essential uses where there is no practicable alternative; for example,
a limited range of medical, veterinary, defence, industrial safety or public safety purposes
applications where CFC-powered aerosols are the only practicable way to meet legal requirements
the calibration of warning, measuring or scientific equipment.
(It is Government's intention that an expert committee will be set up and consulted when considering applications for exemptions under this provision.)
prohibition from 31 January 1989 of the manufacture or import of `do-it-yourself' kits for recharging automotive air-conditioning systems
prohibition from 1 July 1989 of the manufacture or import of disposable containers, five kilograms or less, of scheduled substances for recharging air-conditioning and refrigeration systems
prohibition from 31 December 1989 of the manufacture or import of extruded polystyrene packaging produced with or containing a scheduled substance
prohibition from 31 December 1989 of the manufacture or import of extruded polystyrene insulation produced with or containing a scheduled substance
prohibition from the date of effect of this proposed Act of the manufacture or import of dry cleaning equipment which uses a scheduled substance.

But these controls are only the beginning. It is the Government's firm intention to continue with the joint industry-government working group so as to develop practical measures to further reduce Australia's consumption of scheduled substances. Additionally, a representative of the environment movement will be appointed to the working group to ensure that environment interests are kept abreast of developments and to ensure their views are taken into account in future action plans to further limit applications of these substances. The Protocol generally has no controls on exports and in fact allows production to be increased by up to 15 per cent under certain circumstances. However, the Government proposes that exports first be frozen and then gradually reduced by 5 per cent a year. If this was not done, industry could simply convert Production for domestic consumption into exports.

The Bill has no continuing financial implications as fees will be levied on each kilogram of scheduled substance manufactured or imported to recoup the costs of administering the legislation. Until the scheme is operational three positions have been funded at a cost of $185,000 for the first year within my Department.

Australia has always been at the forefront of international action on this issue and I believe this Bill continues to show the way to the rest of the world. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
