DEBATE.TITLE: COMMUNITY SERVICES AND HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Staples, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr STAPLES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Housing and Aged Care)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

I bring before the House a Bill to amend a number of areas affecting human services within the Community Services and Health Portfolio. This Bill seeks changes under the first home owners scheme to better ensure that assistance is properly targeted at those in need and is not used, for example, for investment purposes. It also tightens eligibility to Medicare entitlements to exclude a range of people such as visa overstayers, illegal immigrants and the like. This is in recognition that Medicare is primarily a health insurance system for Australian residents. As well, from 1 January 1989, Medicare benefits will not be available for overseas medical treatment. Unfortunately, many people have previously travelled overseas without comprehensive travel insurance on the incorrect assumption that Medicare would cover any hospital and medical costs they incurred. This change removes any such confusion. Instead the Government will concentrate on extending its network of reciprocal health care agreements.

The Bill will overcome a recent problem which has arisen in Victoria where some private health insurance funds have threatened to cease payment of hospital benefits for certain long-stay nursing home type patients. These patients have been paying contributions to their health funds for many years and have a right to expect that whey they are admitted to hospital their health fund will contribute towards their hospital charges. This change reinforces the Government's belief that the funds have both a moral and a legal obligation to continue the long-established practice of payment of benefits for nursing home type patients.

The legislation also establishes the framework for the new Medicare hospital funding arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States and Territories. These arrangements not only guarantee eligibility of all Australians to free public hospital treatment, but also will help improve access and throughput for Medicare patients. In addition, the Bill honours Government commitments to provide for a limited number of exempt nursing home beds, and to increase availability and access to respite care services in nursing homes and hostels as part of its aged reforms, and imposes lodgment and processing fees for appeals against nursing home fees determinations.

This Bill firstly seeks to amend the First Home Owners Act 1983. The proposed amendments to that Act authorise the recovery of assistance paid on the basis of an applicant's intention to reside in a dwelling, but where that intention was not realised. The amendments will provide that where a person has not resided in a dwelling and no longer intends to reside in that dwelling, the Secretary shall direct that the person be deemed not to be a prescribed person for the purposes of the Act. The amendments further provide that once such a direction is made, the assistance which has been paid becomes recoverable. The amendments will enhance the Secretary's ability to prevent assistance being paid in relation to homes which are not owner-occupied.

In addition, in cases where only one of two or more owners ever occupies the dwelling, the moneys paid under the first application may be recovered or offset against the remaining entitlement. This leaves the party who never occupied the dwelling free to reapply in relation to another dwelling. This aspect will be of assistance to couples who separate prior to one party occupying the dwelling. There are no financial implications arising from these amendments. A further amendment involves the definition of an eligible person in relation to Medicare entitlements.

For some time now the Government has been reviewing the key elements of Medicare eligibility. The major focus of the review centred upon the principal eligibility issue-that is, who should have access to the Australian health care system. Since its inception in February 1984, Medicare eligibility has been conferred on all Australian residents. An Australian resident is generally defined in the Health Insurance Act 1973 as a person who resides in Australia, including a person domiciled in Australia, but not including diplomatic-consular staff, or their families.

The effect of the existing definition is that in addition to conferring eligibility on bona fide Australian residents, that is, persons who have a legal entitlement to reside in Australia, it also unintentionally permits access to a range of categories of other people on whom Medicare eligibility should not be conferred-for example, visa overstayers, illegal immigrants and the like. The proposed new definition limits Medicare access to persons who have a legal entitlement to remain permanently in Australia.

The change of eligibility for Medicare benefits made by this amendment is consistent with the changes of the eligibility for social security benefits and veterans' entitlements that were made by the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Act 1987.

In addition to the principal definition, there remains in the Act a discretionary power available to the Minister for Community Services and health to confer medicare eligibility upon individuals or classes of persons in exceptional or unusual circumstances. Consistent with that discretionary power and with other measures being taken administratively, and the repeal of section 21 of the Act relating to the payment of benefits for overseas treatment, it is the Government's intention from the date of effect of this amendment that non-residents of Australia, whether they be Australian citizens residing abroad or long term visitors from overseas, shall henceforth be excluded from Medicare eligibility. Only people who actually reside in Australia legally should have access to Medicare. This proposed amendment is not expected to achieve immediate savings. Moderate savings in Medicare benefits are, however, expected in the future. The Bill also repeals section 21 of the Health Insurance Act 1973.

Since the inception of Medicare in 1984, Australian residents have been able to claim Medicare benefits in respect of the cost of medical services incurred overseas. Where there is an equivalent item in the Medicare benefits schedule, such medical services have attracted benefits at the Australian schedule fee rate. No financial assistance is available in respect of hospital costs incurred overseas. The average Medicare benefit paid in respect of medical services rendered overseas represents approximately 40 per cent of the actual cost of the service provided. Australian travellers are thus required to pay about 60 per cent of the cost of the medical services and, if hospitalised, they are responsible for 100 per cent of these costs. In some countries, the Medicare benefit is only a small proportion of the costs.

The Government has decided to discontinue the payment of Medicare benefits for medical treatment received overseas which in practice is often very little more than a token payment against very high costs, and to extend the network or reciprocal health care agreements with other countries. Such agreements provide Australian residents with access to both medical and hospital treatment on the same basis as residents of the host country. Reciprocal agreements are therefore a more appropriate and effective means of providing health care cover for Australian travellers abroad.

Australia is currently party to agreements with the United Kingdom, New Zealand, Malta and Italy. Agreements with Sweden and Portugal are close to being finalised and I expect them to be operational in the near future. Negotiations are also under way with several other European countries.

It is of great concern to me and to my ministerial colleagues that many Australians undertake overseas travel without making appropriate arrangements concerning comprehensive travel insurance which includes a health insurance component in the event of illness overseas. Indeed, less than 50 per cent of Australians travelling abroad take out adequate insurance with health insurance cover. Health costs overseas are often high, particularly in the United States of America where hospital charges in excess of $2,000 a day are not unusual. Thus, a 10- to 15-day stay in hospital can result in a devastating outlay of $20,000 to $30,000 for the patient. Very often people who incur these costs have no insurance whatsoever. The Government is unable to assist, and nor should it. It is the responsibility of the individual to purchase appropriate travel insurance cover, just as it is to make arrangements covering all other aspects of overseas travel. The former availability of Medicare benefits provided what was at times quite a false impression in the minds of travellers that they were adequately protected against such costs.

Henceforth, from 1 January 1989 medical benefits will not be available for overseas medical treatment, and the Government will focus its efforts on further developing reciprocal arrangements with countries which have health care systems which are compatible with, and comparable to, Medicare. This amendment is expected to save approximately $5m a year in Medicare benefits from 1 January 1989.

The Bill also seeks to ensure that nursing home type patients who are accommodated in hospitals are entitled to receive benefits if they are privately insured. Recent actions by some health insurance funds in Victoria have threatened longstanding and well understood arrangements that patients who have private health insurance who exceed 35 days in an approved hospital and are not classified as acute patients receive health insurance benefits appropriate to long stay nursing home type patients. The Government is not prepared to allow the uncertainty which this has created to continue for these patients, who have contributed to those funds over many years. It is the Government's intention to ensure that these long stay patients continue to receive hospital benefits at the nursing home type patient level, which is appropriate to the type of care they receive.

This principle was established by amendments to legislation in 1979, following general agreement between Commonwealth and State Health Ministers that long term patients accommodated in hospitals who no longer require the same level of care and attention as acute care patients were to be reclassified as nursing home type patients. In recognition of this a lower health insurance fund benefit level was determined. The proposed amendment in the Bill will ensure that registered health benefits organisations continue the payment of benefits to persons who are long stay nursing home type patients in approved hospitals.

A further purpose of the Bill is to establish the framework for the new Medicare hospital funding arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States and Territories. Of course, the cornerstone of the Federal Government's contribution to the improvement of Australia's health care delivery system has been the introduction of Medicare, our universal health insurance scheme which is now nationally and internationally recognised for its social and economic successes. Medicare is providing access to health care for two million Australians who were previously outside both the private health insurance arrangements and government-funded cover for pensioners, the unemployed and low income earners. This has been accomplished at no additional cost to the community. Not surprisingly, Medicare's social and economical advantages to Australia are reflected in the level of community support for the health insurance system.

One area in which substantial future enhancement is now being undertaken is the Medicare public hospital funding arrangements, under which the Commonwealth is entering into new five-year agreements with the States and Territories from 1988-89 to 1992-93. In this the first year of the agreements, the Commonwealth will provide specific public hospital funding of $3,063m distributed on a per capita basis, consisting of a base grant of $3,007m, a special $15m component to help meet the additional treatment costs of AIDS patients, and an incentive package of $41m to encourage more efficient use of public hospital resources.

The proposed amendments to the heads of agreement under schedule 2 of the Health Insurance Act allow definition of the purpose for which funding is provided, allow States and Territories flexibility in the use of resources to provide improved access of Medicare patients to public hospital services, and provide for the Commonwealth to make financial adjustments where States or Territories do not meet agreement conditions. The Government is confident that this major increase in the hospital Medicare grant, with its much improved growth index, combined with the additional incentive package and measures to ensure equality of access to public hospitals for both public and private patients, will ensure a significant improvement in State public hospital services. The package is designed to ensure that the Medicare objectives of access, equity, universality, simplicity and cost containment are met.

The Bill also gives effect to a decision made in the context of the 1988-89 Budget, when the Government announced that it had decided to introduce lodgment and processing charges for the review of nursing home fee determinations under the National Health Act. Section 40ae of the National Health Act permits nursing home proprietors to request the Minister to review nursing home fee determinations. The legislation requires the request in the first instance to be investigated by a nursing homes fees review committee of inquiry. These committees are established in each State to assist the Minister's investigations by providing a detailed professional and independent review of fee determinations, where proprietors are unable to reach agreement with the Minister's delegate on the level at which fees are set.

The Government has become concerned at the escalation in the number of requests for review received since 1 July 1987, the date from which the Government's aged care reforms were introduced. The number of requests for review has risen from an average of about 20 a year to a total of about 600 in 1987-88. The industry has indicated that the increase in the number of requests is largely an orchestrated form of protest against aspects of the nursing home reforms. The process of review is a thorough one involving the gathering and analysis of complex information. The length of time for each review varies but on average consumes almost 100 hours of Public Service time. In the past, the cost of a review, estimated at about $4,000, has been met entirely by taxpayers. There is a statutory obligation on the Minister to consider these requests for review. However, to address the current extraordinary volume of appeals will involve the diversion of significant departmental resources from implementing other necessary Government reforms in aged care, some of which have been requested by industry associations, to handle many non-genuine appeals.

There is no way of distinguishing between protest or vexatious appeals and those which are genuine. It is in the interests of the taxpayer and nursing home proprietors with genuine grievances to free up the nursing homes fees review mechanisms by ensuring that only those cases which are genuine become the subject of review and that those appeals are expeditiously handled. There is a further need to prevent the situation from worsening by avoiding future protest or vexatious appeals against fee determinations. The Government considers the introduction of a lodgment fee of $500 and an additional processing fee of $500 for each half-day a committee meets to consider an appeal will achieve those objectives. Administration of these arrangements, for which provision is made in clause 29, will be facilitated by fees being deducted from payments due to a nursing home under part 5a of the National Health Act on authorisation by the proprietor. To safeguard the position of genuine appellants both lodgment and processing fees will be refunded in full where a request for review is wholly or substantially successful. Provision is also made for the lodgment fee to be refunded in full to a proprietor who withdraws a request within 84 days following a decision by the Secretary.

As indicated previously, the Government is committed to the provision of respite care services as part of its strategy of responding positively to the needs of the aged and to the needs of the often forgotten husbands, wives, relatives and friends who care or assist in the caring for aged persons in their own homes. Respite care is essential to assist aged persons to live for as long as possible in the community. The Government's program of reforming aged care seeks to increase the availability and accessibility of respite care services in nursing homes and hostels. The long term objective is to provide two respite care places per thousand persons in both hostels and nursing homes with an additional 4,000 places available by 1995. Clause 42 of this Bill allows regulations, which are subject to disallowance by the Parliament, to be made which allow the formulation and implementation of a scheme for providing respite care in nursing homes. The scheme being developed, and which is to be defined in the regulations, is expected to be implemented in the second half of the 1988-89 financial year.

Honourable members also will be aware that the government has introduced a major reform program in aged residential care to overcome serious criticisms of the nursing home program which have been made by representatives of the industry, aged people, unions, Commonwealth parliamentary committees and other representative bodies. The reform program has been phased in to ensure that the process of adjustment is smooth and avoids disruption of the care of the 110,000 frail aged residents and the employment of the thousands of people providing that care.

The reforms to the nursing home funding arrangements introduced on 1 July 1987 and 1 July 1988 will result in non-government nursing homes for the aged being phased to a standard fee and standard benefit arrangement by July 1991. The standard fees and benefits will embody funding for uniform nursing and personal care staffing levels linked to service needs of residents and a standard aggregated module for infrastructure costs.

Currently, approximately 26 per cent of residents across Australia are required to contribute more than the minimum statutory contribution towards the fees set by the Commonwealth. The minimum statutory contribution is equivalent to 87.5 per cent of the sum of the maximum single rate pension and rental assistance. Under the arrangements introduced on 1 July 1988 these additional contributions will be gradually eliminated so that by July 1991 no resident will be required to contribute more than the minimum statutory contribution.

Previously, in introducing the amendments to the National Health Act to enable the implementation of the reforms to the nursing home funding arrangements from 1 July 1988, including the phasing out of the excess amounts over the minimum statutory contribution, the Government advised that the only exception would be in relation to residents of exempt homes. It was also foreshadowed that, in these sittings, legislation would be introduced to enable the exempt nursing homes arrangement to be implemented.

The Bill also amends the National Health Act 1953 to enable the introduction of an exempt nursing homes arrangement, under which a number of non-government nursing homes for the aged will be permitted to charge their residents fees which are higher than the maximum that would otherwise apply. The amount of Commonwealth daily benefit payable under this arrangement will be reduced by a minimum of 50c in the dollar for each dollar by which the fee charged exceeds the fee otherwise payable.

The exempt nursing homes arrangement will provide scope for a small proportion of residents, who so desire, voluntarily to buy a higher level of accommodation and services than that provided by non-exempt homes. It will also provide flexibility for service providers who wish to cater for these residents to generate additional income to fund the additional costs that will be involved. It is proposed that only a small proportion of nursing homes in each State-comprising initially up to 6 per cent of beds-be granted exempt status. The Bill provides, in clause 23, for the Minister to determine the maximum number of nursing home beds that may have exempt bed status in a State or Territory.

Clause 24 of the Bill inserts a new provision in the National Health Act empowering the Minister to grant exempt status to a nursing home for a specific period following consideration of a proprietor's application for such status. Among the matters that the Minister is required to consider in deciding whether to grant exempt home status are:
the level of the additional fee that the proprietor proposes to charge;
the extent of the benefit discounting that the proprietor is prepared to forgo with the minimum 50 per cent of the additional fee; and
whether the granting of exempt status would unreasonably deny access to nursing home care to financially disadvantaged persons.

A nursing home granted exempt status will not be permitted to charge, for a period of at least 12 months, more than the additional fee specified in the proprietor's application for exempt status. The proportion of benefit discounting specified in the proprietor's application will remain constant throughout the period of exemption granted by the Minister. The Bill further provides in clause 27 that the proprietor of an exempt nursing home may vary the additional fee only once in every 12 months and that the redetermined fee requires the Commonwealth's approval.

Under clause 28 the rights of existing residents of a nursing home which is granted exempt status are protected. Existing residents will be given a period of six months within which to decide whether they wish to participate as exempt residents and consequently be subject to the additional fee. If an existing resident decides not to participate then, for a period of two years after the home is granted exempt status, the resident is to be charged no more that what would have been payable had the home not been granted exempt status.

The Government is also concerned to ensure that existing residents who elect to participate in the scheme make that election freely and the Bill contains provisions to place a firm onus on the proprietor to establish that fact. Clause 33 of the Bill empowers the Minister to revoke a home's exempt status if it violates the conditions attached to that status. It is estimated that when the system has been fully implemented, savings in Commonwealth benefits of $10m a year will accrue. I commend the Bill to the House. I now present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr N.A. Brown) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: BROADCASTING LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988[COGNATE BILLS:BROADCASTING (LIMITED LICENCES) FEES BILL 1988BROADCASTING (RETRANSMISSION PERMITS AND TEMPORARY TRANSMISSION PERMITS) FEES BILL 1988BROADCASTING (NATIONAL METROPOLITAN RADIO PLAN) BILL 1988RADIO LICENCE FEES (NATIONAL METROPOLITAN RADIO PLAN) BILL 1988]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 September, on motion by Mr Willis:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling the honourable member for Richmond, I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate this order of the day concurrently with orders of the day Nos 3 to 6. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, as you have mentioned, this is a cognate debate. The Opposition has no objection to that because we recognise the mechanical nature of some of the Bills. Notwithstanding the fact that there are policy implications with respect to some of them and, in one Bill-that is, the Broadcasting (National Metropolitan Radio Plan) Bill 1988-we will move a second reading motion amendment which states our position on the Government's approach to this piece of legislation. As you said, Mr Deputy Speaker, we are debating a number of Bills: the Broadcasting Legislation Amendment Bill, the Broadcasting (Limited Licences) Fees Bill, the Broadcasting (Retransmission Permits and Temporary Transmission Permits) Fees Bill, the Broadcasting (National Metropolitan Radio Plan) Bill, and the Radio Licence Fees (National Metropolitan Radio Plan) Bill. This package of legislation provides more evidence of the Government's confusion and its piecemeal approach to policy development and legislation for communications in Australia. Whilst the Opposition is not opposing any of these Bills, we feel it is incumbent upon us to highlight some of the areas where there is community and industry concern about the Government's approach.

SPEECH.PARA: The Broadcasting (National Metropolitan Radio Plan) Bill 1988 and the Radio Licence Fees (National Metropolitan Radio Plan) Bill 1988 have attracted some comment from the industry. These Bills are the first stage of the Government's plan to provide an additional four commercial FM radio licences in capital cities throughout Australia. The initial proposal at this stage is for commercial AM radio licensees to transfer to the FM band and their AM frequencies will be used to provide a parliamentary broadcasting service and a service for print-handicapped people throughout Australia.

There has been some debate in this place earlier today about the broadcasting of Parliament. I would like to take this opportunity to say that the Government has taken a very cavalier approach to the broadcasting of Parliament. It has accepted statements made by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC). As far as I am aware, there has been no independent corroborating evidence to support the views expressed by that body or its Chairman. It is understandable that the ABC, in its relentless pursuit of ratings, irrespective of what that means to the philosophy of alternative broadcasting and the standard of programs-that includes news and so-called current affairs-is keen to do away with the inconvenience of being required to broadcast the proceedings of the national Parliament.

Legislation of this Parliament provided that the proceedings should be broadcast at least to the capital cities of Australia, for one very good reason; that is, the people of this country should be able to hear the unedited debates of their representatives in Parliament, have an alternative source of news and access to the proceedings of this Parliament, and not have to rely on edited reporting which is a necessity if it is simply part of a news or current affairs reporting service provided as part of a total and comprehensive broadcasting facility.

The great difficulty that I and many other members on this side of the House have with the approach of the ABC to broadcasting Parliament at present is that it will deny access to parliamentary broadcasts to those people who are non-residents of the capital cities and who were lucky enough to pick up that broadcast as a result of the transmission strength of the previously used ABC transmitter. The ABC proposes to put its metropolitan broadcast on a more powerful transmitter. That will spill over into regional areas. It will put the parliamentary broadcast on to its so-called stand-by transmitters which are of considerably less power. Their capacity to disseminate the signal beyond the boundaries of the metropolitan areas is considerably limited.

It would have been entirely possible to maintain the parliamentary broadcasting on the stronger frequency. It would have provided a service to the capital cities, as is required by the legislation. It would have gone further and provided that service to some regional and country areas throughout Australia. Using the standby transmitters for the purposes of broadcasting the metropolitan signal still would have provided access to that signal to metropolitan residents. But, of course, this Government, reflecting its continued commitment to arrogance, is not prepared to extend access to the parliamentary broadcasts to people who live outside the capital cities. Let me say that I think that is a great pity because--

TALK.START.PARA: —I just call the honourable member for Richmond to order for a moment. The decisions on parliamentary broadcast, in fact, are decisions of the broadcasting committee of the Parliament chaired by Madam Speaker with Mr President as deputy. I suggest to the honourable member for Richmond that he make it clear in his remarks whether he is talking about Government policy in broadcasting or decisions of the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I can understand the confusion but let me assure you that I am not in any way--
—I am not confused, but I do not want there to be any confusion in your mind.

—What I am trying to say is that, because it is Government legislation that the ABC is required to broadcast under, the Government should take an active interest in the policy of the ABC when it comes to broadcasting the Parliament. I am well aware of what Madam Speaker has said. I am not ware of what transpired at the Committee meetings, of course, and I should not be.

SPEECH.PARA: I am just stating a view: in my opinion, the government of the day, with its statutory broadcasting corporation, has the opportunity to exert policy directive and it should. That issue is only part of these Bills and that was going to be the conclusion of my remarks. I will not pursue the debate any further on that matter. It is a view that I hold very strongly. It is simply further evidence of one level of service being available for people who live in capital cities and another level of service for people who live in non-capital city areas throughout Australia.

When we come to the other provisions of this Bill we see that the Government is proposing to extend the ABC service in capital cities and provide access in cities such as Adelaide to the JJJ popular music format of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. I simply draw the House's attention to the fact that the Government is again reflecting its priorities; that is, a continuation of extending a public broadcasting service to capital cities, where there is already considerable choice in entertainment available through radio. If we move to regional centres the choice available from the ABC is extremely limited. The Government may say that it has a plan and that it is going to introduce new frequencies to regional Australia. But I simply say to the Government that its priority is doing the capital cities first. Capital cities already have considerably enhanced services over those available to regional Australia and the Government is enhancing those services further. I question the priorities of this Government.

Let me just make a reference to my particular region of New South Wales. We have an area from the Queensland border down to perhaps south of Coffs Harbour with a population equivalent of Tasmania. That region of people has access to one ABC radio signal. It takes a mix of programming from Radio National through to regional services and, of course, from the second service. Residents of a capital city, under the normal circumstances, have access to ABC National, the second network, ABC Fine Music and in some capital cities JJJ. The Government is proposing to extend that JJJ service to other capital cities. Yet people who live on the far north coast still have access to one hybrid ABC signal only. They are being told that things will change; they just have to live a bit longer and the Government will finally get around to reprogramming and reorganising the spectrum so that there can be an extension of services. The Government has been saying that for a long time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing has happened in the last 20 years.

—It has been saying that for a long time. This is the sixth year it has been in government. It rings a little hollow when the ABC itself starts running advertisements on its own behalf saying, `The ABC service costs the Australian taxpayer 8c a day. Isn't it worth it?' I am not going to enter into the merits of that debate but let me say that if it costs 8c a day for a taxpayer in the city to get ABC television plus a full range of ABC radio services, why are taxpayers on the far north coast of New South Wales and in other regional areas paying 8c a day for one service? Where is the equity in that? If the true function of the ABC is to provide a community service to Australians, why does it not provide that community service? Or have we totally walked away from that and are we now relentlessly chasing the commercial networks in their pursuit of ratings? That is something that this Government seems a little confused about. It is the same sort of confusion, of course, that is evident in other aspects of its communications policy.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, aspects of this proposed so-called national metropolitan radio plan have drawn some comments from the industry. Because this particular Bill is designed to facilitate the provision of additional commercial radio services on the FM band throughout Australia, it is relevant to understand the economic background in which this legislation is brought in. In 1986-87, 50 of Australia's 130 commercial radio stations lost money. In 1987-88 the figure jumped to about 70. When more than half of Australia's radio stations are trading in the red, we wonder what sort of enthusiasm and economic sup- port there will be for the Government's proposal to invite existing AM operators to tender to acquire FM licences. There is some speculation about what sort of support there will be within the industry.

There was a report in the Business Review Weekly on 9 September that talked about the Hawke Government's plan to auction AM-FM conversion licences to the highest bidder. The Hawke Government expects them to sell for between $12m and $15m each in Sydney, $8m to $10m in Brisbane and Perth, less than $8m in Adelaide and $15 to $20m in Melbourne. The report went on to say:
AM operators recognise the financial stress such prices will create (to convert from AM to FM will cost a station a comparatively low $1 million).
Some of the established industry figures are already expressing their public concern. One said:
I'm happy we now have the option to convert to FM, but with 50% of radio stations losing money not many AM operators will be able to afford it. It's a case of damned if you do, damned if you don't.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be interesting to see whether 2KY makes a bid.

—The honourable member for Fadden has made reference to the Australian Labor Party owned radio station 2KY in Sydney. It remains to be seen what that station does. In the past it has been an embarrassment to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) because of statements made by one of its personalities on the issue of immigration and race. It will also be interesting to see what the attitude of that station is and its financial position with respect to this Government's legislation. The honourable member for Fadden might be having something further to say about that.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me go on to quote further from this article in the Business Review Weekly. It quotes a Mr Glenn Wheatley, head of Hoyts Media. Hoyts Media is notable because it actually went ahead and bought a string of radio stations in advance-might I say in anticipation-of this Government actually changing its legislative approach to radio ownership in Australia. That station was very lucky.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just coincidence?
—It probably had a crystal ball or maybe it thought it was on a winning streak or it might have got a nod or a wink from somewhere. Let me advise the House of just what Mr Wheatley said:

SPEECH.PARA: It's ill-conceived and insufficiently thought through . . . The Government sees it as a way to make money.

I wonder whether that radio station will realise quite as much money as it anticipated. It would be interesting to hear the comments of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) on the report in this article about the anticipated price that the Government will get for these licences when they go to tender.

What must be highlighted is that there is considerable space on the FM band in most capital cities throughout Australia. I am a long way from being a technical expert on this issue, but it is my understanding that in most capital cities there are about 22 spaces on the FM frequency, maybe fewer in some places. I would be interested if the Minister at some stage would provide me with that detailed technical information. I think it should be available not only to this House but also to the public. The public is entitled to an explanation as to why the Government does not have a comprehensive plan.

We have two types of radio signal in Australia-FM and AM. For some years-and the previous Government was part of this policy-community access or public broadcasting licences were issued for the FM frequency. We have a number of those operating quite successfully throughout Australia and providing a niche broadcasting facility for special interest groups and local communities.

There is a very strong argument that the FM band is probably the best band for high quality music and commercial broadcasting and that perhaps the AM band should be used for this public access facility. Given the number of spaces that are apparently available on the FM band, why can the Government not come to grips with it on a total basis and say, `Our objective is to move the high quality music of the ABC, where appropriate, and commercial broadcasting in general to the FM band'. For most purposes, the AM frequency is more than adequate for the type of broadcasting undertaken by community services and they should be moved. If the whole lot were moved, the community would get a better standard of service.

If the Government wants to extract an economic rent it can do it by way of licence fees, but it does not have a commitment to a total approach to broadcasting policy in Australia. The whole thing is done piecemeal. Even this legislation has been in the pipeline for a long time. In fact, the precursor to this legislation chopped and changed about four times. It was announced in the Budget and by the time the Bill actually hit the House the Government had changed its mind twice on it. It is an issue which should be addressed.

Another issue that should be addressed in terms of this legislation is the philosophy that underlies the extension of a publicly funded and ABC sponsored broadcasting facility-that is, JJJ-to Adelaide where there is already operating, again publicly sponsored, a popular music broadcasting facility through the public access community broadcasting facility. So the Government is actually facilitating the establishment of a broadcasting station which will compete with an already established government sponsored broadcasting facility. There is no argument, of course, with the desirability of providing specialised music for young people in Australia. In fact, I find listening to JJJ broadcasts quite refreshing at times. It is not necessarily my music of choice after a stressful day, but on some occasions JJJ is quite refreshing and worth listening to. Again, this proposal highlights the lack of a comprehensive approach and a fully thought through approach of this Government to broadcasting policy at large.

There is some justification for criticising the Government for lack of consultation. The particular broadcasting station in question in Adelaide has, I believe, publicly voiced its concern at the lack of consultation and the lack of time in terms of warning of this proposal so that it can prepare and change its operations in order to compete. It is something which I think the Government should recognise when it develops its proposals in this area.

The other Bills that I have not spoken about at length are quite interesting. They do such diverse things as clarify the legality of rebroadcasting radio transmissions on telephones to people who are stuck in queues. I am sure that all of us in the modern world find when ringing anything from an airline to someone in this building that if we are put on hold we get something that is rebroadcast. It is just part of the technology of our society. There can be no argument with clarifying the legality of that sort of issue. For that reason, the Opposition has no objection to those Bills. In conclusion, I highlight again that the Government is adopting a fairly piecemeal approach and an unconsultative approach to the development and implementation of its broadcasting policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the honourable member for Richmond have an amendment that he seeks to deal with?

—There is an amendment, but it relates to the Broadcasting (National Metropolitan Radio Plan) Bill and I am advised that I am in a position to formally move that amendment only when the second reading of that Bill is before the House which, under the provisions of the Government's guillotine, will not be until about 6.10 this evening.
—From the point of view of the debate, the Chair is happy to let the honourable member include the amendment as part of his speech.
—With your indulgence, Mr Deputy Speaker, I advise the House that I will formally move at a later time:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House (a) is of the opinion that insufficient time has been allowed for proper scrutiny of the contents of the legislation and (b) expresses its concern with the extension of JJJ FM without adequate consultation with other publicly funded radio networks'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the previous speaker, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), said, this debate covers quite a few pieces of legislation on broadcasting and a wide range of subjects. Firstly, I will talk briefly about the parliamentary broadcasting issue and the comments made by the honourable member for Richmond, who attempted to blame the Government for certain decisions the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) and the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings have made. It is ironic that the honourable member for Richmond should suggest in this House that the Government should be interfering with ABC management decisions as Opposition members have come into this House in the past and alleged that the Government had interfered with management decisions and should not be doing so. They cannot have it both ways. The ABC has requested that certain things be done regarding parliamentary broadcasting. I agree that it is ludicrous to have one of the most popular stations in Melbourne-and I am speaking as a Melburnian-3LO, which has a high rating, being interrupted by parliamentary broadcasts. It is an absurd situation. However, when the Broadcasting Committee of this Parliament responds to that situation and makes certain decisions, the Opposition suggest that those decisions should be overridden. That should not be the case. The Broadcasting Committee is an independent committee of which, I think, you are a member, Mr Deputy Speaker. I was a member at one stage. Whilst we may not always agree with every decision that the Broadcasting Committee makes, it is an independent committee of members from both sides of the House. It is ironic that the honourable member for Richmond did not address the legislation. For most of the time he talked about other things that were not related to the legislation. At one point he was really talking about stage two of the FM radio plan for which legislation is proposed in the autumn session. We will probably hear the same speech again in four or five months' time.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation before the House relates basically to tendering for two FM stations by AM broadcasters, with the two highest bidders taking those two new FM stations in the metropolitan area. That is, I think, an acceptable situation. It is different from regional arrangements we have had previously. I opposed the decision which was originally announced by the previous Minister for Transport and Communications and, fortunately, we eventually won the day. But this legislation is appropriate. Not all AM broadcasters will tender. I suggest that some of the talkback stations and the racing station would not benefit at all in going to FM. But three or four music stations may see a great benefit. The logic of the plan is to push most of the music stations onto the FM band. We will, therefore, have a variety of stations on the FM band-from talkback radio to sport. Parliamentary broadcasters and radio for the print-handicapped will be on the AM band.

The Government should be congratulated for doing something constructive with the two AM stations that will be left vacant. One of the two AM stations will be used for parliamentary broadcasts. The honourable member for Richmond did not really refer to the fact that we are allocating a prime spot on the AM band to the ABC for parliamentary broadcasts. Another thing that was never mentioned in the previous speech was the fact that we are allocating a prime station for the print-handicapped-a very worthwhile cause-who have been asking for a station for some years. The Government has found a way of achieving that in this package of Bills.

The station for the print-handicapped will operate in the near future. The print-handicapped will have one of the AM stations and the parliamentary broadcasts will be transferred to one of the metropolitan AM stations which broadcasts already. The station that will broadcast parliamentary proceedings will have a similar range to that of the ABC station at present.

As I have said, it is ironic that the honourable member for Richmond spoke at such length but did not really talk much about the legislation. He fronted up with criticism of the overall plan. Basically it was criticism of stage 2 of the plan by the Managing Director of Hoyts Media Ltd, Mr Wheatley. Heaven knows, there would not be much self-interest in that, would there? Not much! At the latest count, I think Hoyts Media owned about 13 stations in its group. The maximum number of stations it is allowed to own is sixteen. That is all part of a plan that had been discussed for quite some time. Hoyts knew, when it bought that group, that at that time-it was approximately 12 months ago-the Government was contemplating expanding ownership in the radio area, which it did. It doubled the maximum number of stations allowed to be owned from eight to 16, which brought Hoyts, and anyone else for that matter, who wanted to expand their ownership, under the legislation.

Proposals centring upon this legislation have been discussed for quite some time. It is not new. Mr Wheatley has been screaming, `We do not want any more competition'. I do not believe that he is fair dinkum in his criticisms because he must have known that there would be more competitors at some stage. Looking through recent editions of the Australian Financial Review I see that Hoyts Media-Hoyts Entertainment has a large interest in Hoyts Media-has a few financial problems. Its profitability is not as good as it should be and its gearing is a little higher than it would like. All this relates to the honourable member's criticism of this legislation. It is ludicrous to come in here and quote one person who has criticised the legislation, and say that he has no self-interest in it. What a lot of nonsense! Of course there is self-interest in it. We would all like to have no competition but there is going to be competition. The Government has found a constructive way to provide for that competition with this program for new FM licences and the delegation of the old AM band.

There are a number of Bills before the House. I would have liked to have touched on the ABC. There are quite a few changes in relation to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation which affect its employees. They are generally very good changes. They provide more flexibility to the ABC and give it more powers to borrow, with the permission of the Department of the Treasury and the Department of Finance, and with the Commonwealth guaranteeing that borrowing. We are noticing that flexibility in some respects now, especially with ABC radio programming. I mention radio 3AR and 3LO in Melbourne. Radio 3LO-shall we say, the more popular of the two stations-is rating very highly. It is a formidable competitor of the commercial networks.

I support all the Bills that are before the House. They make up a credible and important package which the Government has thought through. They are part of a package of radio and television decisions, of which there have been many-there have had to be many-over the last few years. There will be more changes in this area, particularly in television, in the years ahead. Whoever is in government will have to tackle those changes from time to time in the quickly evolving telecommunications world. This is a very well thought through package of proposals for FM and AM radio bands. I believe that it will be a great success. We will possibly see two music stations go on to the FM band and the AM licences go to two very important areas such as parliamentary broadcasts and radio for the print-handicapped. I support the legislation before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating five Bills, all of which are under the guillotine: the Broadcasting Legislation Amendment Bill, the Broadcasting (Limited Licences) Fees Bill, the Broadcasting (Retransmission Permits and Temporary Transmission Permits) Fees Bill, the Broadcasting (National Metropolitan Radio Plan) Bill and the Radio Licence Fees (National Metropolitan Radio Plan) Bill. We are debating five Bills, some of which represent some of the most significant legislation to come before this House and yet we are restricted in the time in which we can debate them. It does this House no credit that we are facing this situation this afternoon.

SPEECH.PARA: Some aspects of these Bills are most significant. I say that because what we are doing today is effecting a major change in the face of commercial broadcasting in Australia. In the history of FM radio this place, this Government and previous governments do not have much to be proud of. The FM band, since it first came into operation in a very shady sort of set-up under the old Wireless Telegraphy Act when the Whitlam Labor Government was in power, has been squandered. The Wireless Telegraphy Act was used to get certain types of radio stations on the air. Since then we have seen some legitimate broadcasting go on to the FM band. We have also seen a complete squandering of the FM band because of the nature of some of the stations that have been granted licences on the band. The development of the FM band has been slipshod. It has not been treated terribly professionally. Now we are trying to do something about it. The way we are tackling the problem is not going to do us much credit, once again.

It has been mentioned this afternoon that the FM radio band is the ideal band for musical broadcasting. That is correct. But we have no guarantees that we will get any specialist use of this band at this stage. We have heard not one iota from the Government on, for example, what will happen in terms of the future of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) AM networks and their translation to the FM band. Nothing has been said about that at all. While we can sit here and talk about the prospect of two of the existing AM operators going on the FM band, the ABC would seem to be completely in the dark as to what its future might be in terms of its present AM operations.

It is true that, as the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) said, we have in Australia a situation in which a number of our radio stations-better than 50 per cent of the commercial stations-have been operating at a loss over the last year. We have been through the most tremendous upheaval in radio broadcasting in recent years. A large number of stations has been purchased. We have seen the formation of a number of super-networks. As I said at the beginning of my contribution, this legislation will ensure that the whole face of commercial radio and broadcasting generally in Australia will never be the same again.

Again it is rather a pity that one of the fallouts from this Bill will obviously be that a number of existing radio stations will go broke and will probably have to hand back their radio licences, because that is what it is all about. It is a fact that, because of the very nature of the FM broadcasting band and the fact that the commercial stations have been allowed onto it, a disproportionate amount of the advertising revenue spent on radio has gone to the FM radio stations. Consequently, over the past few years there has been a major drain of revenue and profits out of the existing AM operators. That is a pity, because one of the great things about the development of AM radio in Australia is the fact that we have led the world in our creativity, that we have built up some of the finest broadcasting stations in the world. But in the past few years we have been prepared to let a lot of that go for the sake of a couple of jukeboxes on the AM band. I wonder whether we will allow ourselves to just throw away all that expertise and all that know-how and dedication by the radio pioneers of Australia, and not take full advantage of what could be had if we had played the FM radio band properly. In many respects it is a great pity that many of those pioneers of radio broadcasting stations will literally go down the plughole because we have not tackled the FM radio band properly.

I agree with the honourable member for Richmond that one of the things we should have done a long time ago was ensure that the band was completely clear so that we could have had an orderly translation of all the existing AM stations onto the FM frequency. It is true that we could have in excess of 20 FM stations in most of the capital cities of Australia, if we really wanted it that way. It is amazing to go to the United States and flip around the FM band. There are in excess of 50 FM stations to be picked up in Los Angeles. While we have some technical problems with the FM band here, it is absolutely amazing to me that the Department has been examining the FM band, to my knowledge, for a minimum of 15 years, and in those 15 years we do not seem to have developed the capacity to work out exactly what we want to do with it. And that really is a disgrace. I apologise for being so critical about this area, but we have a lot to answer for in terms of the attitude this country has taken to the whole broadcasting industry during the past decade and a half.

What are we going to see? We will see, in the first stage, bids going in from existing AM operators for an FM station. It would be fairly obvious just which station. It would be fairly obvious just which stations will have the financial clout and the financial capacity to obtain those licences. One can probably count on one's left hand the number of bids that may be anywhere near successful. I would suggest that that figure could probably be reduced from, perhaps, five bidders to just two bidders that will have the financial clout and capacity to get to a stage where they would be successful in one of those bids.

To back up my story, stage two of the plan, which we understand will come in early next year, will dilute the present radio situation even more. A lot of new bidders will be coming in-and that is probably well and good-but it will mean less and less revenue available because there is disproportionately less advertising revenue going into the whole radio area at the moment than there has been in the past; and this will lead to a situation in which many of the operators will go out of business.

My suggestion would always have been that, certainly in the case of the metropolitan areas, the translation from AM to FM should have gone ahead and freed up the AM band completely. On that AM band one has a great capacity now to do a number of things. We have heard about the parliamentary network which, rightly or wrongly, will be established on the frequency of one of these AM stations that will presently go over to FM. We have also learned of developments in radio for the print handicapped. I congratulate the Government on its efforts to ensure that the radio for the print handicapped in the metropolitan areas around Australia has the capacity to broadcast on a decent frequency and with decent power. The service being provided by those radio stations, certainly in Brisbane on radio 4RPH, is making a real contribution not only to those people with sight and other problems but also to the standards of radio, by virtue of some of the programs being played. The biggest difficulty for radio for the print handicapped is that it has been stuck down around the 1520 mark on the dial, and that does not allow for good transmission. Therefore, it has had weak power; so these aspects of it are good. Low powered community stations may be able to be used, perhaps not on the FM band but over on the AM band. If all those metropolitan stations were cleared off the AM band, one could enhance many of the services that are presently inadequate in some of the country areas. But obviously, like Topsy, we will just let the whole thing grow willy-nilly, and still we do not have a completely satisfactory resolution in the whole area of FM radio in Australia. As I said, I think that is a pity.

Because of the limited time given for the debate, my time has just about expired. As with the previous speaker, I also would have liked to have examined the prospect of what the ABC could do with the loan guarantees from the Government. It is something about which I am not completely happy, and I certainly hope that Government members or, indeed, the Minister in his reply will be able to give a fuller explanation of some of the implications of the guarantee that the Government will give to the ABC so that we have some indication of exactly how it will be used, where it will be used, whether it is to be used in the guarantee of loans for the purchase of more buildings, or whether or not we will have a dedication for the improvement in the nature and quality of the programs of the ABC. That may come out a little late in the debate.

I will stop where I began, by saying that in the Broadcasting (National Metropolitan Radio Plan) Bill honourable members will see a major revolution in the radio industry in Australia, and we parliamentarians should be pretty aware that there will be some major fallout in the next few years, with a number of stations handing back their licences. We should be prepared for that and perhaps we should not be too proud of some of the legislation brought into this place in the past 15 years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Saunderson Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to make a few points in relation to some of the major changes to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) and also in relation to the national plan for metropolitan radio. I must say I am a bit intrigued by the remarks of the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull), who spoke about what should have been done and what the Government had done wrong and where we should be going. I make one point: the Opposition parties have been in office for some 30 years since the Second World War, and virtually nothing was done by them in the area of broadcasting.
—What did the Whitlam Government do?

—The Whitlam Government was in office for three years during that period, and it concentrated on a whole range of social problems that had developed in the previous 23 years. It did not have the opportunity of dealing with this question, although I might say that it did move towards the introduction of a number of areas of public radio and public broadcasting. It did make some reforms.

SPEECH.PARA: On the question of how the AM and FM frequency bands should be used, for instance, the honourable member for Fadden said that the FM band should have been cleared years ago. That is correct. But who was in power for the majority of that period of years? Which government did nothing about this issue? Which government did nothing about ownership levels? Which government did nothing at all about increasing the range of alternative services? All I can say is that since 1983 this Government has tackled a whole range of problems that were left unanswered and which resulted in a deterioration in and a lack of, services, particularly in rural areas, for many years. This Government has tackled those questions.

We have seen a whole range of changes in television. We have seen aggregation in rural areas. In the area of radio licences new licences have been issued, and there has been a change in ownership rules. Concerning the question of national planning, the Government should be applauded for what it has done in relation to the expansion of FM services. Firstly, that expansion will give the opportunity to some existing AM licensees of transferring to the FM frequency. I think there is no-one in this House who does not recognise that an enormous degree of concern has been expressed by existing licensees about the difference in competitiveness between the AM band and the FM band. Existing AM licensees have expressed an enormous desire to have the opportunity to move to the FM frequency. In my view-and I think the Government has made the right decision-it is not sensible to allow all existing AM licensees to transfer over to the FM frequency. The AM frequency band is a useful one and should continue to be used. We should not diminish the amount of choice that will be ultimately possible simply because some people want to transmit on only one frequency system.

In allowing two existing licensees on the AM band to bid and to have the opportunity to transfer, the Government will overcome two other problems that have existed. One concerns assistance to that very necessary service, radio for the print handicapped (RPH). That is an area where the Government ought to be congratulated by the community at large. Here is a service which caters for those people who, for various reasons-whether they by physically handicapped or have other problems-are unable to read, enabling them to gain information and other services via the radio. Unfortunately, until very recently the service was forced not only to operate in areas of the frequency spectrum that were not easily obtainable by many listeners, but also to transmit on low power. With the transfer of that AM licence to the FM band, one of the existing AM frequencies and the equipment will become available for radio for the print handicapped stations. This will make them more accessible and will provide them with more powerful transmitters, which will enable more people to enjoy the service they provide.

The other AM licence will be used for the broadcasting of Parliament. Since the ABC has been experimenting with the transfer of the Parliamentary broadcast to other frequencies, it has been able to provide better scheduling of programs on its national radio stations. The trial process has meant that some people have not been able to receive parliamentary broadcasts satisfactorily. That will be overcome with the release of the second AM licence, which will then allow for wider broadcasting.

In terms of changes to the ABC and its powers, I think the Government has done quite a good job in providing support to the ABC, in encouraging it to become more responsive to community needs; and in encouraging it to improve its overall performance. I am not necessarily unhappy with the new powers that we are providing them with, including the capacity to act more as a corporation free from constraint. But I do have some reservations about the use of its borrowing capacity to finance some of its projects. In particular, I would be concerned if the ABC, having been given these new powers, utilised them simply to overcome problems and difficulties that they had in the past while they were under scrutiny. For instance, in Melbourne, the ABC has had property at East Burwood for some time, which has been available to the corporation to provide new premises and buildings for its radio and television services. Because of some middle management concerns, particularly in radio, that project has not progressed for some 12 to 14 years. Radio Australia was moved out quite some time ago, and it enjoys the provision of good facilities in a modern building at East Burwood. But the radio people have continued to enjoy very poor service in terms of the building environment and working conditions, because some people have simply not wanted to travel from the inner suburban areas to East Burwood.

Spurious arguments have been raised as to why radio service would be damaged if this project were to go ahead. There is no doubt that the ABC could provide better working conditions for its staff, it could modernise its equipment far more cheaply, and it could reduce the overall maintenance and running costs of its radio services in Melbourne if it were to transfer to, and provide new services at, East Burwood. The fact that it owns the land and the fact that the project has been part of its plans for many years are things that I hope would not be altered simply because the ABC is now in a position to borrow money by issuing bonds to finance projects, and so forth. Because it could do that, it would ultimately look to more expensive projects simply to satisfy some of the desires of the middle management, as well as producers and so forth. It would be a backward step for the ABC not to integrate its services at East Burwood.

Because of the process by which the Government is moving towards increasing services on the FM band, as well as providing necessary services such as RPH on the AM band, the Government ought to be congratulated-with the reservation I have expressed with regard to the ABC. I add one more criticism. I recently had a letter from a constituent complaining about the fact that he was now having difficulty in receiving parliamentary broadcasts. I was most disappointed to find that the response from the person in the ABC was to simply blame this Government for it. It is my understanding that that was done at the request of the ABC itself-a request by ABC management-which wanted to institute a better service for its listeners on the national broadcasting system. Given the shortness of the debate, my time is running out, so I will not linger on the other matters that I wanted to raise. I support the legislation the Government is proceeding with.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to these amendments I would like to say, firstly, how important this legislation is to the electorate of Maranoa and particularly the people of Queensland. Changes are being made, mainly from AM to FM radio in metropolitan Brisbane, and also to the financing and staffing arrangements of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC). The Corporation will be able to borrow funds commercially with the approval of the Treasury. Obviously this is important for the Corporation as it wishes to extend its operations around Australia. The national Parliament, through the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, controls the licensing of radio and television stations and applies a fee mainly to police the frequencies that are allocated to radio and television in the broadcasting spectrum. People cannot start broadcasting when they feel like it. They have to apply for a licence and they have to be slotted into the spectrum so that their radio broadcast will be heard. Approximately $80m in revenue is being collected from these fees.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, these new arrangements will affect our parliamentary broadcasts. Unfortunately the new arrangements will disadvantage isolated Australians, as usual. Australians living in metropolitan areas will be able to get parliamentary broadcasts on an FM frequency. Today Madam Speaker announced in the House that there has been a transfer of parliamentary broadcasts from the existing high-powered broadcasting stations to the stand-by stations around Australia controlled by the ABC. Those of us who live in isolated Australia, like I and my constituents in Western Queensland do, were able to pick up parliamentary broadcasts. People are always very interested in what I in particular have to say on radio. Unfortunately, now it will be much harder for them to hear those broadcasts.

As far as I am concerned we, as parliamentarians, ought to be looking very closely at extending the system into inland Australia via the satellite. I suggested to the ABC management that was here a couple of days ago that the FM channels on the satellite could be used. I do not see why the ABC cannot broadcast an edited version of the day's proceedings via the satellite so that people living in isolated areas would be able to pick up the broadcasts of the proceedings of this Parliament. In our democracy it is very important for all Australians to have an opportunity to listen to the broadcasts, not just the privileged millions who live in metropolitan Sydney and in other big cities. Those people have an enormous range of television, radio and FM stations to listen to, whereas when we move further inland we get fewer stations. In some parts of my electorate people still cannot listen to the ABC, particularly in the middle of the day. As the day heats up the stations cannot be heard.

I congratulate those people in the Department of Transport and Communications who have recently been involved in establishing an ABC radio translator at Charleville and the near completion of an extension of that translator at a small place called Cunnamulla in south-west Queensland. For the first time people living in that country town will be able to hear ABC radio. Beyond Cunnamulla, and further inland towards Birdsville, one cannot get any ABC radio at all during the day. Obviously, at night there is an awful lot of skip and massive radio interference. People are able to pick up radio in those parts of Australia at night but during the day they cannot pick up market reports, parliamentary broadcasts and the other interesting things that they wish to hear.

The honourable member for Aston (Mr Saunderson) more or less lambasted the Opposition parties for not doing anything when we were in government. That is not true. The previous Fraser Government put that satellite program into place. About $350m of taxpayers' money has been spent on that program. That has been of tremendous help to people living in isolated areas. We now get ABC television via the satellite and AM and FM radio channels are available through the satellite. We are now receiving commercial signals for the first time. I would just like to point out to honourable members on the Government side that legislation has gone through this chamber dealing with the rationalisation and amalgamation of television stations along the coast of Queensland and other States but nothing seems to have happened. The idea was to give viewers in rural Australia, and particularly those viewers in the more isolated areas, a second channel.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Maranoa is proceeding beyond the amendments with which we are dealing. He is now talking about television coverage.

—I am sorry about that, Mr Deputy Chairman. I will get back to the radio broadcasts. My main concern has been that, under the new arrangement, we have not been getting the parliamentary broadcasts. I think it is understood that the translators the ABC were using were very powerful and these translators had a long penetration. The stations established in the capital cities were using these frequencies to broadcast parliamentary proceedings. They have now switched from that channel to the stand-by transmitters which are nowhere near as powerful. Many Australians who now go to the polls, who support us and who pay their taxes are not able to receive this broadcast. I think that is a disgrace and it is something at which this Government should be looking. The Government should not just be putting more parliamentary broadcasts on the FM network because FM has a very limited signal. It is like UHF radio. The latest citizens band radio that is used are line of sight radio, in the same way as a television signal are line of sight. That is why aerials are put on the top of a large hill. It is the same in the case of FM radio. A hill or a high antenna are needed to get a big spread. One does not get a large coverage with FM; it goes into the town or into the country for five, 10 or 20 kilometres and then the broadcast finishes and one does not receive it. An FM station in Toowoomba goes out just to the edge of my electorate. A local FM community station is also operating in Roma and business people have applied to set one up in Dalby. Although we welcome the opportunity to put in these broadcasters, people must understand that they have a very limited range. Australia is a large place and these broadcasters just do not give a very big coverage. Although the FM signal is a high frequency signal and it is much clearer and better than the AM signal, it is very difficult for those who live further out in isolated areas and in much smaller towns. It is just not economic to run one of these stations there. About 5,000 people are needed to warrant the operation of one of these stations. Many townships in Australia are not big enough to operate an FM station.
—Order! The time allotted for the committee stage of the Bill has expired. The question is that the amendments be agreed to.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that the Bill, as amended, be agreed to, and that the Bill be reported with amendments.

INTERJECT.PARA: Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.
