That the Bill be now read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the opportunity to speak on the Broadcasting Legislation Amendment Bill because it is certainly a Bill of great importance to everyone in Australia, and of course that includes those people who are fortunate enough to live in the balmy, equable climate of Cowper. It is interesting to note that the advent of FM stations has really produced a tremendous change in radio. I believe that the introduction of FM radio stations has marked a great move forward for good in terms of entertainment, instruction, and cultural understanding and appreciation of people in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: My electorate of Cowper is well served by the stations it has, but there is a need to improve. We have two existing FM stations, 2CHY and 2BBB. Radio 2CHY FM began broadcasting via landline as a student radio station in 1973. It was the brainchild of an officer of the Salvation Army. In January 1983 it began official FM broadcasts, after receiving a community broadcasting licence several months before. It is interesting that this particular student radio station draws on the efforts of students from the five high schools in the area, and up to 120 schoolchildren a year work at the station in one capacity or another. In fact, hundreds of youngsters have had great benefit from their time at the station and many have gone on to careers with commercial stations in regional or capital centres.

Radio 2BBB, situated at Bellingen, is also an FM station, and began broadcasting in 1983. It is run by the Bellingen Community Communications Cooperative. It plays all styles of music, and also has a strong community news and information profile. As with 2CHY, 120 volunteers-not children this time, but adult members of the community-are involved in running the station. There are no full time employees. People come from all over the Bellingen Shire to put in their very worthwhile work at the station. It broadcasts, on average, for about 18 hours a day, longer at the weekends, and it does a great job. Those two FM stations are indicative of the great work that can be done within a community by FM stations.

I want to refer briefly to the two other stations, which are not yet licensed. One is Radio Nambucca which is not as well advanced as the other station, Radio Hastings. Radio Nambucca is already doing its share of broadcasting with 2BBB and the people associated with it are getting some very worthwhile experience. Radio Nambucca originally was quoted a hearing licence date of 1992, but I am pleased to note that it was recently advised by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) that the hearing will be held sometime in 1990. I understand it is happy with that. The other group is the Hastings Community FM Radio Association Incorporated. I recently wrote to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) on behalf of this group. The point that I made in that representation, and that the Hastings Community FM Radio Association has made in its submission to the Minister, is that, even with the Department's changed policy regarding tandem hearings, while Hastings is listed on the current timetable for 1991 a commercial FM licence hearing will be conducted by the ABT in about mid-1989 for the Kempsey region. That region covers the Kempsey-Hastings area.

While the community station certainly will not be contesting the commercial FM licence, I contend that it is only sensible, and would be very efficient, to hold a tandem licence hearing while the ABT is in the area, particularly since the Department has a policy to encourage tandem hearings. Community radio in Hastings is ready to go to air and is prepared for the hearing. It can see no reason why it should wait until 1991. I take this opportunity to commend to the Minister the proposition that a tandem hearing for the commercial FM station in the Hastings-Kempsey area and for Radio Hastings FM would be a very sensible and economic way of handling both applications.

We are also served by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) through 2KPTR, based at Kempsey with other studios as Taree. I take this opportunity of paying tribute to the personnel associated with the ABC regional service in my area. They are hard working, efficient and very dedicated, and do an excellent job of providing programming which is of interest to a great many people.

The two commercial stations, 2MC based in Port Macquarie and 2CS based in Coffs Harbour, are also first-rate local radio stations and deserve high praise, which they do get from the communities they serve.

I also point out that the ABC had indicated that it would provide an FM station for Coffs Harbour. The land had been bought but I understand now that, because of a change in planning, the land originally purchased for the FM station was sold some time ago. That is rather disappointing, especially when the ABC had demonstrated such flourish about having a national FM network which included a transmitter to be sited in the Coffs Harbour region. It is very disappointing indeed and I hope that at some time in the future funding will permit the reallocation or priority to that-although, as I say, it is disappointing that, as a result of taking a very short term view, the land has been sold.

The honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) made reference in his speech to 2JJJ FM. I add my praise for that station. I believe it is a tremendous station for serving the music interests of young Australians. Perhaps I should declare an interest, because one of my sons has recently been appointed manager of that station. But I liked it before then and certainly that does not influence my appreciation of what that station has done for the young people of Australia. I also note with a great deal of interest that it is about to extend its coverage to other capital cities. I would just like to throw in this thought, or fly a kite, if you like: As the honourable member for Richmond said, it might be a duplication to have JJJ in Adelaide but the North Coast of New South Wales might be considered an appropriate place to install a JJJ transmitter. The number of young people we have is quite high, we have the highest growth area in Australia, and there is no doubt in my mind that it would be a valuable addition to the radio service on the north coast of New South Wales if a JJJ station could be provided.

Parliamentary broadcasts have received quite a deal of attention, and I am rather interested in a letter I received from the Managing Director of the ABC, Mr David Hill, dated 26 October 1988. In it he said:
There is no provision in the Act requiring the ABC to broadcast Parliament in, say, the Mid-North Coast of New South Wales.
I think that is a regrettable attitude. The fact that there is no provision in the Parliamentary Proceedings Broadcasting Act is no reason why people should not be served. Mr Hill also said:
Over the years, the ABC received many complaints from listeners in capital cities about the loss of regular programs when Parliament was sitting. Country listeners also complained . . .
I think that is rather unbalanced. I cannot really believe that the ABC has only received complaints about Parliament being on.

Bill read a second time.

Debate resumed from 2 November, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House (a) is of the opinion that insufficient time has been allowed for proper scrutiny of the contents of the legislation and (b) expresses its concern with the extension of JJJ FM without adequate consultation with other publicly funded radio networks'.

This amendment which the honourable member for Richmond has circulated draws attention to two factors that are of concern to the Opposition. The first is that the Government has not provided sufficient time for proper scrutiny of the contents of this legislation. In not providing sufficient time the Government is not showing the right kind of respect for the institution of parliament. The reality is that if legislation is to be introduced it is only reasonable that the Parliament should have time to consider that legislation before it is debated. The Bills that we were debating cognately are complex Bills. Once their details have been seen by honourable members, they require consultation with industry and discussion with the community in general, particularly on areas as sensitive as the national metropolitan radio plan, which is of interest and affects so many people around the country. It is of no tribute to the Government, its attitudes to the community and to Parliament, that it has not allowed for proper scrutiny of the contents of the legislation.

The second part of the amendment proposed by the honourable member for Richmond, which I have moved on his behalf, relates to concern about the extension of 2JJJ FM without adequate consultation with other publicly funded radio networks. In my State of South Australia there is one very successful FM radio station-there are other FM radio stations-which has the highest ratings in South Australia on both the FM and AM bands, called SAFM. The market that JJJFM would wish to carve out for itself in South Australia is a very similar market to that which at the moment is held by SAFM. My concern is that JJJFM is part of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), is a publicly funded radio station and is therefore not part of the private enterprise system. Whilst I am a strong advocate of the principle of competition, I think that the ABC has a different function than just existing to provide competition.

Too much of the debate about the ABC in both the radio and television fields has lost sight of what the true objectives of the ABC ought to be. I do not think this Parliament has given that matter the consideration that it should be given. If the ABC is simply to be a body which competes with the commercial sector to maximise its ratings, there is no question that it is not performing a significant public interest role. That, it would appear to me, is what is happening here in the extension of the role of JJJFM. If, on the other hand, the ABC is to provide a public service, is to get an example in raising standards and is to be a pacesetter, that is altogether another matter.

It is interesting to look at the contrast between what the Australian Government is doing and what has occurred in the United Kingdom in recent years. There was the case many years ago when I was a student in Britain-this dates me a bit because it was a long time ago-when the British Broadcasting Corporation set up pop radio station, BBC Radio 1. I make no apology for the fact that it was the only radio station I ever listened to when I was a student. It was certainly a popular station, but it competed directly with the private sector rather than providing a unique, if you like, culturally superior service to what the market might naturally provide. I note that the present British Government has come to the conclusion that just providing competition should not be the role of the BBC. Consequently, it has moved to ensure that the BBC divests itself of Radio 1 and that that radio station becomes part of the competitive private sector. That, of course, is why we have some concern about the ABC expanding these sorts of operations throughout the nation.

As I said, I have some concerns about the implications for stations such as SAFM in South Australia. I do not believe-nor does that station-that there has been adequate consultation; nor has there been adequate consultation with other radio networks. That is a matter of regret to members on this side of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few comments about the Opposition's second reading motion amendment. The Government, of course, opposes this amendment absolutely. I do not understand the first part of it which states that insufficient time has been allowed for proper scrutiny of the contents of the legislation. The legislation was introduced a week ago. All the normal conventions regarding the introduction of Bills and the period of time that the Opposition has to consider their contents, including the opportunity to discuss them at a party meeting, have been met. There has been no undue haste in putting this legislation before the House. Many Bills go through in that time frame.

SPEECH.PARA: A further point relates to the extension of JJJFM to Adelaide and other places. It seems that Adelaide is the cause of concern. The Opposition seems to be in an acute state of division over this aspect. A couple of speakers have said that JJJFM is a very worthwhile station to listen to. Indeed, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), who spoke first in this debate, was praising JJJ while indicating a second reading amendment expressing concern about its extension. The concern seems to be that in Adelaide there is a public radio station-it is not so heavily publicly funded-which has rock music as its basic content and that JJJ would cut across it. Let me say that the people who run that station have indicated that concern to me. I must say that I do not feel a great sense of concern about that.

In Sydney, for instance, where JJJ has operated for quite some time both on the AM and more recently on the FM band, there are other rock stations, including public radio stations which have a rock music base, and they all exist reasonably well. I am sure that in a city the size of Adelaide there is room for more than one such station. I would have thought that the extension of JJJ would have been welcomed by the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), who presumably, as one of the younger members of the parliament, should be concerned to see a service like this provided to the people of Adelaide.

I will now mention a couple of other factors that have been brought up in this debate which relate to the Broadcasting Legislation Amendment Bill. Some concern has been expressed about parliamentary broadcasts. This Bill tries to provide for the arrangements for the permanent frequency for parliamentary broadcasts by enabling two AM stations in each capital city to be moved off the AM band onto FM bands. They will vacate two frequencies, one of which will be used for radio for the print handicapped, and one for parliamentary broadcasts as a permanent network. That is a very desirable and sensible move.

I must say that in running through the comments that have been made in this debate about the change in parliamentary broadcasting procedures has been the assumption that there is a public out there that is desperate to hear Parliament and that there will be mass concern if the public cannot hear it. All of the evidence points the other way. In wanting to have Parliament broadcast we should not be so selfish as to think that it is only Parliament which is important. There are other people in the community who wish to hear the programs which Radio National provides, which are not provided by any other station. There are no commercial stations providing the kinds of programs that Radio National provides. There is a substantial audience for that kind of program. I understand about 6 per cent of the radio audience listens to Radio National. Overwhelmingly, the evidence is that those people do not want to have Parliament on Radio National.

Of course, it is important that we have some parliamentary broadcast. There is an Act of parliament requiring it. The Act requires it for the capital cities and Newcastle, and other cities may be added by regulation. One such city has been added, and that is Canberra. Any other areas which receive the parliamentary broadcast do so fortuitously simply by the power of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation extending from the capital city out into the country areas. Parliamentary broadcasts have never been on the ABC regional network. With the temporary arrangements and Parliament moving to the standby transmitters, the vast majority of the audience who could previously have tuned to the parliamentary broadcast will be able to do so. Some people in country areas who previously had fortuitously been able to receive it will no longer be able to do so. That is a pity.

On the other hand, one must look at the other side of the equation, and that is that a much larger number of people, in my view, who are normal Radio National listeners will be greatly pleased that they will be able to hear the programs they like to hear at the normal time that they come on and not have them interrupted by parliamentary broadcasts in which they are not interested. While the ABC has been doing testing over the recent weeks, Parliament has been broadcast on the standby transmitters and on some days and evenings has been taken off Radio National. There has been a testing period in which the ABC has invited comments from people about the change in arrangements. Overwhelmingly, the comments that have come to the ABC have been strongly in favour of that change. Overwhelmingly, those people are saying, `Thank goodness Parliament is no longer on Radio National. We want to be able to hear the programs that we normally listen to at the normal times and not have them interrupted by parliament'.

Of course, there is a group of people who want to listen to Parliament. Those people will, by and large, be able to hear it on the new parliamentary network. Unfortunately, there will be some people who will miss out. Once we are able to relocate stations from the AM band to the FM band by the arrangements in this legislation and put the parliamentary broadcast on the new AM frequencies, not on the ABC standby transmitters, it may well be that we will be able to provide a more powerful transmission and one which will go further than is the case with the standby transmitters in some of the capital cities at present. I might also add in that respect that in Perth the coverage of the standby transmitter is greater than that of Radio National. More people in the Perth region and in the Western Australian countryside can hear Parliament on the standby transmitter than has been the case with broadcasts on Radio National.

It should also be understood that the ABC has agreed, at my suggestion, that there should be some form of summary of Parliament on Radio National each week. It has agreed to a half-hour broadcast to be run on Friday night and Saturday morning. It would be a summary of events in Parliament of that week involving excerpts from parliamentary debates and Question Time. It would highlight the important issues that have come up in Parliament that week. That will provide a good service and importantly-I say this to members of the National Party of Australia-it will also go on to the second regional network.

This Government has taken the decision to establish a second regional radio network so that we can have two ABC frequencies around the country. In so doing, we will gradually extend a form of parliamentary broadcast, the weekly summary, to the whole nation. The people in remote areas have never before had that kind of service. But they will have it through the summary. They will have for the first time a program that will give some assessment of what went on in Parliament, with some excerpts of parliamentary proceedings of the previous week available to them. That is a very important development. I hope that the Parliament will see that there is much merit in the changed system. We cannot simply disregard the rights of others who wish to hear the normal Radio National programs which are not available anywhere else in the spectrum. One cannot get similar programs elsewhere. It is important that we bear in mind their needs and that the great majority of people who want to listen to Parliament will still be able to do so.

Finally, may I say in relation to the tendering process that there seemed to be some concern by the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), on the one hand, that we were going to be exploitative by charging terrible prices for people who wished to go from the AM band to the FM band. On the other hand, he was saying that there were lots of frequencies available and that we should have a lot more people on the FM band. The reality is that a limited number of FM licences have been granted so far. Some of those stations have been sold for very substantial amounts of money indeed. There is no need for what is obviously a valuable commodity, that is, an FM licence, to be given away cheaply. We should give it away at a price that the market will bear. That is what the tender process that is instituted in this legislation brings about so that the people of Australia, who are the owners of that commodity, can get a proper price for it and not give it to someone to make a substantial profit out of it for their own purposes. It is really something that is for the national good. The Government, I repeat, rejects the second reading amendment and advocates support for the Bill.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Naval Defence Amendment Bill will enable civilians who are employed at Garden Island in the Office of Defence Production (ODP) to be transferred to a new company, which is to be established next year, called Australian Defence Industries Pty Ltd. The Opposition approves of the establishment of this new company. We support the Bill because it will enable staff to be transferred to that company so that they can be productively employed. We hope that they will be. It will make what is now the Office of Defence Production much more competitive in the civilian market, and, hopefully, it will be successful.

SPEECH.PARA: It is strange that, on a day when the Cross report on personnel wastage in the Australian Defence Force is tabled in this House-a report which tips an absolute bucket on the Government for its neglect of Defence Force personnel-we have the Government saying, through this Bill, that it will look after its civilian employees, which it should do. It says that it will negotiate with the unions about the transfer of staff to the new company and that it will make every effort to ensure that the transfer is effected expeditiously. The 70,000 uniformed men and women of the Defence Force do not have the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) to speak for them; they do not have any union to speak for them. I am not advocating that they should. It is the Government's responsibility to look after its own employees. The report condemns and damns the Government and is an indictment of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) and his side-kick, the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly), for their treatment of Defence Force personnel.

Having said that, I congratulate the Government on the way it has approached the task of introducing efficient methods into the Office of Defence Production. Over the last few years it has reduced civilian numbers by some 5,000. It has reduced the number through efficiencies it has introduced and by way of sales-for example, of the Williamstown Naval Dockyard. That is all going in the right direction, and that is good. However, some of the claims made by the Minister for Defence in relation to efficiencies in the Department of Defence are highly suspect. The Williamstown Naval Dockyard reportedly was sold for $100m, yet the Budget Papers indicate revenue from the sale as only $66m. There is a discrepancy which may be easily explained; but I certainly do not understand it, and nor does anybody else to whom I have spoken.

The Minister also claims that $100m can be saved each year in the logistics area. Where are these savings? It is a bit hard to understand these reported savings when, in a press statement and an announcement throughout the Army less than three weeks ago, the Chief of the General Staff announced that operating expenses were to be cut back by 10 per cent. The Minister also claims that the ODP has increased productivity by 30 per cent. I find that very difficult to estimate on any rational grounds.

While I applaud the reductions and efficiencies the Government has made in the Office of Defence Production, there is a limit to the reduction in the number of civilians. If the Government goes too far, obviously it will be asking service men and women to take up the slack. It has been demonstrated today that the uniformed part of the Department of Defence, the Australian Defence Force, is on the bones of its backside as far as personnel are concerned. I hope very much that while the Government continues to cut back civilian appointments it is not suggesting that servicemen should take up the slack of those jobs when civilians who do not have to undergo the same degree of training could easily do them.

While we are on the subject of civilians in the Department of Defence, I must mention the shameful episode of the employees who were made redundant when the Government Aircraft Factories were absorbed into Aerospace Technologies of Australia in October 1987. In February 1988, some five months later, it was revealed that 150 of those redundant employees were being paid for sitting around in Melbourne with absolutely nothing to do. It was not until June 1988 that all those 150 people had been found jobs. I applaud the Government's attitude in trying to get increased efficiency in Government owned enterprises. It is very difficult when we look at cases such as the one I just mentioned, in which 150 people or more sitting around and being paid to do nothing and at the same time the Government has cut back on uniformed personnel in the Australian Defence Force to the tune of some 3,000 in the last three or four years.

When servicemen are asked how they feel about being asked to do more work and to work longer hours while their pay and conditions deteriorate and they are asked, `Do you know that there are 150 civilian employees of the Department of Defence in the Melbourne area getting full pay to play cards'?, they nearly go off their brains. They know about it all right. They look upon it as a complete abrogation of the responsibility of the Department of Defence and the Minister towards them.

I want to say a few words about Garden Island Dockyard. In the past Garden Island and the Williamstown Naval Dockyard have been absolutely notorious for the intransi- gence of some of the unions there, for rorts, thuggery, low productivity, restrictive work practices and all that is bad about the union scene. I will come back to Garden Island in a moment. There have been some very great improvements there. I want to compare what has happened at Garden Island with what is happening at Williamstown. Williamstown Naval Dockyard was sold to a company called the Australian Marine Engineering Corporation (AMEC) earlier this year. When AMEC took it over there were 1,300 employees and 27 unions. Productivity was at an all time low. Demarcation disputes were rife. There was a whole series of work categories and pay levels. AMEC, with the help of the ACTU and a number of unions, has reduced its work force to 400, instead of 1,300. Productivity is up. AMEC has reduced the number of unions from 27 to 3. There are now two work categories-trades and non-trades. The pay levels have been reduced to four. If an employee wants to move from a lower pay level to a higher one all he has to do is to increase his range of skills-at the company's expense-through training courses.

What has happened at Williamstown is remarkable. I give credit to the management of Williamstown-particularly the manager, Dr John White-to his staff, and to the unions and the ACTU which have been involved in the transformation of what was a notorious black hole in Australian industry. That black hole has now been transformed into what is probably one of the most productive industrial enterprises in Australia. There is a new spirit at Williamstown. When one goes there, people are cheerful, happy and anxious to get on with the job. That is because it has gone from being a government-owned enterprise to private enterprise. We cannot do that with every government enterprise. I am not suggesting that it should be done in the case of Garden Island. But one cannot help but compare what has happened in the past at Garden Island with what is happening now at Williamstown. At Garden Island there has been great improvement. I give credit to Admiral Berlyn, the manager, and his team. Some unions are cooperating to the fullest at Garden Island, as is the ACTU. But it still has a long way to go.

The Federated Ironworkers Association, which is represented in South Australia, generally has been helpful, as the Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan) who is at the table would probably know, in connection with the eventual construction of the new submarine. I ask the union why it is taking such an intransigent position with regard to the new Australian Defence Industries. I quote from the Pacific Defence Reporter, November 1988. A letter written by John Ryan, the national research officer of the Federated Ironworkers Association, Sydney, states:

Although the Government has given six months notice of the intended change to its own operations, together with a commitment to consult with unions on the change, it would be unrealistic to expect that such a significant change affecting over 8,500 workers will be achieved without any industrial disputation.

I am not sure what he means by that. He seems to be waving a red flag unnecessarily. I would have thought that it would have been better to say, `We will see if we can achieve significant change without industrial disputation'. What the union has to realise is that, in the end, there is the possibility of more jobs, higher productivity and, in particular, defence exports. One has to ask why, if it can be done at Williamstown and South Australia, it cannot be done at Garden Island. Productivity at Garden Island is up by some 15 per cent. Work force numbers are down but productivity is up. In the future it will have to consider the trades and non-trades categories. It will have to get more flexibility into the work force so that it is not plagued all the time with demarcation disputes. That applies not only to the blue collar work force but also to the white collar force.

In relation to Garden Island, I mention the shameful episodes-shameful as far as this Government is concerned-of HMS Invincible in 1983 and HMS Edinburgh this year. The story about both of those ships, which needed repair in Australia but were turned away by the Government, is somewhat confusing. I am not blaming the work force at Garden Island. My understanding is that the workers were prepared to do the job. The problem was that the Government was not prepared to allow the ships to dock. This Government refused two ships belonging to Britain-in 1983, and again this year-in need of repair to have those repairs undertaken in Australia. In both cases the repairs should have been done at Garden Island. We should have offered to do them. We should not have been forced reluctantly to make a decision, which eventually was to refuse. They were disgraceful episodes. Still very vivid in the mind of most Australians is the sight of Ark Royal bouncing around Port Phillip Bay for two or three days because the Seamen's Union of Australia would not dock the ship.
We support this Bill. We look forward to seeing the new company which will be formed next year playing a constructive and productive part in Australian industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Naval Defence Amendment Bill is an important Bill. It continues the Government's changes with regard to defence and the defence industry. The previous speaker, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), has mentioned the privatisation of Williamstown Naval Dockyard and the great changes that have taken place there. This Bill takes things a step forward in regard to Garden Island. It involves the transfer of the 10 defence factories at the Garden Island dockyard to the newly established company, Australian Defence Industries, which is a company wholly owned by the Australian Government. It is important legislation because Australian Defence Industries will be looking after the employment of Garden Island workers and the defence factories.

SPEECH.PARA: The changes that have taken place in the defence industry over the last few years are remarkable. The Government has made major changes. It sold the Williamstown Naval Dockyard to the Australian Marine Engineering Corporation (AMEC). Having been a recent visitor to Williamstown, I fully concur with what the previous speaker, the Opposition spokesman in this area, said. I am glad that he spoke so highly of Williamstown. Things have changed dramatically there. I saw a piece of equipment there worth millions of dollars-a large paint instrument. Certain parts of ships were put into it and it would take between six and 10 weeks for those parts to come out the other end. That equipment is now used in such a way that the parts go through in five days. That might seem incredible, but it is absolutely true. It shows the cooperation there has been between the Government, the defence industries and private enterprise. It can be done. This Bill is concerned with a company wholly owned by the Australian Government, Australian Defence Industries. This Bill enables the transfer of the Garden Island employees to that company.

In talking about Williamstown and a whole range of changes in the defence industries, the Opposition has talked about all the things that we should and should not be doing. The Opposition had 30 years on this side of the House and it did not do anything. I remember, in my earlier days in this House, the Defence Minister, Mr Killen, coming in here and saying that he had made X amount of changes to Williamstown and how it was all going to be wonderful. But it never was. It took this Government to make the important decisions regarding changes to the defence industries.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight the House is considering the Naval Defence Amendment Bill 1988 and, as my colleague the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) indicated before the suspension of the sitting, the Opposition is not opposed to the Bill, which is basically a step in the right direction. In fact, the debate is running approximately half an hour ahead of the guillotine schedule proposed by the Government. I welcome this and would make the point that it will at least allow some other important Bills, such as the Defence Service Home Loans Amendment Bill, known as the Westpac-ing legislation, to be introduced slightly earlier than was otherwise anticipated. I know a lot of people have an interest in that defence legislation as some people have an interest in this Naval Defence Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill relates to making an amendment to the Naval Defence Act of 1910, to enable persons employed at Garden Island Dockyard to be transferred to Australian Defence Industries Pty Ltd. It is a step along the path of boosting productivity in defence production, to provide privatisation of a kind in relation to that defence production and to move Garden Island in the same way as Williamstown was moved. As such, the Opposition welcomes the measure.

I might add that I last visited Garden Island some two months ago on an important and historic occasion, and I had a good look around Garden Island. The exact purpose of the visit was to see for myself the scope of two modest plaques erected in Garden Island, the subject of this Bill, to a conning tower of a Japanese midget submarine. I will not dwell on this, because it is somewhat peripheral to the Bill, other than to say that the two plaques are just that-they are extremely modest plaques to commemorate those who lost their lives on those midget submarines. They are not that far from yet another major memorial-to those who lost their lives on HMAS Kuttabul sunk by those midget submarines. The pity about that saga is that apparently there had not been a great deal of consultation. If the people who were concerned about that special matter had had the opportunity to see what was involved and to see the small size of the two plaques which have been erected on that conning tower, they could have made their own judgments. I do not believe the operators of those midget submarines can be blamed for the huge Japanese war effort of World War II, as some would have us believe.

Of course, hundreds of plaques are erected to Australian service personnel in countries around the world, even in countries which do not share very happy relations with Australia, but those plaques are still maintained because of the nature of what they commemorate. I refer even to war graves in places like Libya, Bangladesh and Burma. So it is of more than passing interest that, as the House considers this essentially Garden Island legislation I make the point that I did front up, perhaps at some risk in terms of the veterans constituency. But I do not walk away from a situation such as was existing at that time in relation to those two modest plaques, and I was just sorry that there was no Government representative at the occasion and that the Navy was left to carry the can, which it did very well.

Turning specifically to the Bill, I should like to comment on clause 4, which in many ways goes to the heart of this small two-page Bill. I will not delay the House unduly, but I refer to subclause 4 (3), which reads:

For the purpose of facilitating a transfer of persons to the employment of a Commonwealth authority, the Commonwealth authority may, notwithstanding anything in any other law (other than an industrial award), determine special terms or conditions of employment that are to apply in relation to the persons (other than terms and conditions with respect to superannuation).''.

I should like to make two points only. Firstly, I reiterate my concern about drafting phraseology in legislation today, which makes it very hard for members of the public to understand so much that is going on with the governments of this country. I know there are legal reasons why the phraseology has to be carefully constructed, but in one other sense Canberra, the bureaucrats, the parliamentarians and the Government Ministers ought to be deeply conscious that there is an increasing gulf between mainstream Australia-the people of Dean Street, Albury or Harding Street, Deniliquin-and the people working in this magnificent new parliamentary building in Canberra. As a member representing an electorate which actually covers an area quite close to Canberra, I am conscious of the need to break down that gulf.

In the context of this Bill, we have yet another clause which, although it covers what it seeks to do in a correct and legal sense, contains such language. I do not argue against that, except to make another appeal that, under the Acts Interpretation Act, under legislation generally and under the modus operandi of government, we ought to be much more conscious of the need to use plain English, to quote the plain English insurance policies of the National Roads and Motorists Association, rather than using the gobbledegook which can flow from the bureaucracy and which, if the parliament is not mindful, will mean even more complicated legislation when it is not necessary.

Just in passing, I mention, for example, that famous question put from the Chair: `The question is that the words proposed to be omitted stand part of the question'. All that is saying is: the question is that the amendment be agreed to or rejected. So why not say it like that-without tearing up too many of the conventions which I know are dear to the hearts of the Clerks, to myself and to others? But returning to the actual wording in the last clause of the Bill, I ask the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), through the Minister representing him at the table, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), for an assurance that, by virtue of that clause, there will not be a perpetration of the rorts and inefficient work practices which so dominated Garden Island and all its operations and which have been the subject of comments by other honourable members.

On a cursory reading of the clause it would seem that it does give an ultimate degree of great flexibility to the arrangements which will pertain. If the clause results in so much flexibility as to perpetrate those horrific rorts which have dominated Garden Island for so long, that, of course, defeats the purpose of what the Government is about in bringing the Bill before the House. I highlight that point. I believe that the Government will advise the House that that is not the purpose of this clause but, because of certain circumstances, it may be that there will not be an answer in this House on this Bill. If that is the case, perhaps it can be taken up in the Senate debate by way of response at an appropriate stage. As the honourable member for McPherson indicated, the Opposition is not opposed to the Bill. It is a step in the right direction. The Opposition hopes it will provide a great and needed boost to productivity, especially in our dockyards and our docks right around Australia. Hopefully, the legislation will enjoy a quick passage through the Parliament, so that the transfers covered by the Bill will be able to be implemented.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
