SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bills we are at last debating tonight are the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5), the Income Tax Rates Amendment Bill and the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2). The coalition parties will not be opposing the Bills. However, we will be moving committee stage amendments to oppose the removal of the tax exemption for gold mining income.

SPEECH.PARA: The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) is a very large Bill covering changes to a great variety of areas dealing with the imposition of tax. In a typical example of the way in which legislation comes before Parliament under this Government, and of the contempt with which this Government holds the parliamentary processes, barely a week has passed since these Bills were introduced. That can frequently happen. But when one of these three Bills, with at least 13 changes to the income tax laws, was introduced in a package of eight Bills last Thursday night, it is almost ludicrous to think that a thoroughgoing analysis of such a complex Bill, and of the other two Bills being debated with it tonight, can be done in such a short space of time. Given this Government's poor record of slipshod and ill-considered drafting in the past, there is a likelihood that there will be numerous unintended consequences flowing from these Bills.
However, let me turn to a case that is not an unintended consequence, that is, the decision to tax the goldmining industry. On 26 June 1987 the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) said:
We are totally opposed to the introduction of a gold tax.
He went on:
A gold tax would jeopardise the future of many existing mines and prevent the opening of new ones. Exploration and the level of investment in this important sector would also decline rapidly.

We have a particular concern about the effect a gold tax would have on our balance of payments. Australia's level of overseas debt and the appalling deficit in our overseas trade account make it imperative that we encourage one of the main industries contributing positively to reducing the deficit.
Then he added:
The Liberal Party has a firm commitment on this matter. We are opposed to the introduction of a gold tax.
So, clearly with such firm commitments being put down only last year, I can say to honourable members that the Opposition will not break those commitments on this matter.

It is interesting to contrast our statements with those of the Government. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the then Minister for Resources and Energy , Senator Evans, made similar statements on 16 November 1986; there is hardly a contrast. When announcing the Government's decision to maintain the income tax exemption for goldmining, Senator Evans said:

The Government has concluded that the importance of encouraging active exploration and development, and of maximising production and the consequent export income generated by the goldmining industry, outweighed the arguments in favour of removing the industry's long-standing exemption.

Furthermore, on 7 July 1987, no less a person than the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) gave the goldmining industry and the Australian public an undertaking that he would `not introduce a gold tax during the next three-year term of the Labor Government'. What has changed other than the effluxion of time? What has changed since the Government made these statements? The reality is, nothing. We still face the same balance of payments constraint and we still face a huge foreign debt. Apparently, the Government has discovered the concept of level playing fields since the last election and I will have more to say about level playing fields later. So the Opposition opposes the Government's removal of the tax exemption for goldmining income. The Government is introducing legislation which it may not even be able to implement in the next term of government, for it may not be the government.

This brings me to one of the most important problems with this legislation. The Government has introduced a large degree of uncertainty into the goldmining industry and into the economy in general. Put simply, as the Leader of the Opposition said in June 1987:
We-
that is, the Opposition-
recognise the need to provide a climate of certainty for investment.

The Government, as is evident from its past record of changes in rules and regulations with regard to tax, simply does not understand the role of certainty with regard to investment decision-making. Just witness the Treasurer's disastrous removal and his subsequent reinstatement of negative gearing for housing. How can an industry make plans for the future when the Government canvasses large changes in tax arrangements-changes in arrangements in this instance that it may not even be in power to deliver? There is already evidence that, following the Treasurer's May economic statement when he first canvassed the removing of the gold tax exemption, serious disruptions have occurred in the gold industry.

By announcing the introduction of a gold tax so many years in advance the Government has provided a huge, and frankly artificial, incentive for miners to exploit the richer ore and neglect lower grade ore-get it out while they can before the tax comes on. Such a situation is almost unprecedented and will certainly lead to an inefficient use of the nation's gold resources. Moreover, many goldminers have been forced to revise their investment strategy in anticipation of Labor's gold tax.

It is clear that the removal of the tax exemption for goldmining will force many marginal mines out of business. Some of these mines are operated by large companies and some by smaller organisations, many of which are unincorporated enterprises. In short, the Government's decision to remove the tax exemption will lead to a winding down of activity in gold mining. This additional element of uncertainty in the decision-making process of miners comes at a time when Australia faces a difficult balance of payments and foreign debt situation.

Last year, gold was the third largest export behind coal and wool. It represents around 6 per cent of total merchandise exports. In other words, the Government's decision to levy a gold tax comes at the very time when we can least afford to have one of our major export industries thrown into chaos. Of course, the Government has argued that the tax exemption for goldmining should be removed to place gold on a `level playing field' with other industries in Australia. I would like to make two points here. Firstly, there are two ways of levelling the playing field. Secondly, there are two playing fields: one at a point in time and one over time. These are important conceptual points that the Government has simply failed to address when introducing this legislation.

If we take the first point, there are two ways of levelling the playing field. Obviously, the tax on gold can be raised to the level of the tax on other activities-this is the easy option and the one preferred by this Treasurer who, incidentally, is the highest taxing Treasurer since the war-or one could get serious and start cutting some of the Government's expenditure programs, as called for not only by the Opposition but also by Senator Walsh, the Minister for Finance, and reduce the overall tax burden. This would permit the Government to bring the taxes on other activities more in line with that on gold. The Government can raise the tax on gold or it can reduce taxes on other activities. The Government, and especially the Treasurer, are big on raising taxes but they are not so big on cutting expenditure.

Honourable members might remember that the selfsame Finance Minister I just mentioned talked only last year of the 200 programs that he and his Department had slated for large expenditure cuts. We have heard little more since then apart from his annual post-Budget resume of the economy when he normally warns of the dire consequences of not having followed his advice. He mused again, after this Budget, that the Government may well have to engage in further frantic fiscal activity to reduce expenditure. Apart from Senator Walsh, this Government simply focuses on raising more revenue.

The second point I made also concerns level playing fields. The Government has directed its arguments to levelling the playing field at a point in time. It simply does not address the important point of levelling the playing field over time. The removal of the tax exemption for goldmining will introduce yet another tax on the income from savings and investment. In short, it will consolidate the bias in Australia's tax system against both savings and investment and in favour of current consumption. With our balance of payments constraint and our huge foreign debt Australia certainly needs more savings, not less. From a macro-economic point of view, we need a tax system which does not discriminate so heavily against savings and investment. Because of the undertaking that I read and because of the additional factors we will, therefore, be opposing the removal of the tax exemption for goldmining income. In the committee stage I will be moving amendments to that effect.

There are two other aspects of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) that I will mention out of the range of amendments that are contained within that piece of legislation. The Bill will make amendments to section 10b of the Income Tax Assessment Act to reduce the rate of deduction for investment in Australian films from 120 per cent to 100 per cent. We are told that future Government assistance to the film industry will be given primarily through the Australian Film Finance Corporation, oft referred to as the Film Bank, which has been established as a wholly government owned company to fund qualifying Australian films. This bland statement hides the months of uncertainty that preceded this decision. The Government's treatment of the Australian film industry has been greatly disruptive and particularly insensitive. As I noted before, the Government simply does not appreciate the need for certainty and consistency of business operations and certainly business operators.

The Government's key role as far as business is concerned is to create a stable environment in which savings and investment decisions can be made. Its turn around on negative gearing and innumerable taxation laws amendment Bills are just part of this sorry story. This Government has created uncertainty in the gold industry and it has created uncertainty in the film industry. To some people the film industry is a minor industry. It is not to me. It has been of enormous importance in terms of the subliminal promotion of this nation. It may well be that the Government can argue justifiably for changes in the tax deductability arrangements, but the uncertainty created both in regard to that measure and in regard to the creation and operation of the so-called Film Bank is yet another uncertainty for those operating in the private sector. They are operating in a high tax environment.

The Keating-Hawke Government, the highest taxing government since the war, unquestionably is more interested in raising revenue than in encouraging savings and investment. The taxation of the goldmining industry and other measures in the Bill such as the reduction in the tax deduction for the film industry will all go to increasing taxation revenue by over $7 billion, or 10 per cent, this financial year. The total tax in 1988-89 is estimated to be $82 billion-an enormous amount. Of course it is coming from people and corporations participating within the Australian community. A large proportion of it is in fact accounted for by what has become known as bracket creep, tax creep, as taxpayers move into higher and higher tax brackets. The Government is plundering this bracket creep, plundering the wage packets particularly of low and middle income earners. It is estimated that, since 1985-86, $7 billion has been ripped off taxpayers through the insidious effects of bracket creep and that taxation by stealth is expected to grow to $10 billion by the time the long overdue tax cuts are delivered in July next year. It is a cruel attack, a most extensive attack, on the living standards of Australians-probably the most extensive and the cruellest attack on low to middle income earning Australians in the history of this country. And it deserves condemnation.

As I have noted before, the extent of the effect on low and middle income earners is quite staggering. By 1 July next year, when the Prime Minister says those long overdue tax cuts will come in, a person on average weekly earnings with a spouse and two dependent children will require a tax cut of $56 a week to restore his or her disposable income to what it was in March of 1983, when the Keating-Hawke Government came to power.

The last points I want to raise on Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) concern the changes affecting employee share acquisition schemes. The Bill gives effect to the proposal announced in the May statement to exclude from income tax up to $200 of discounts on shares or rights acquired by employees under certain employee share acquisition schemes. Honourable members should note that the Government is simply taking up an Opposition proposal. It is simply parroting part of a private member's Bill introduced into the Senate earlier this year by the Opposition, through Senator Chaney. As such, we have no objection to these amendments. What the Government does not admit is that it is not adequate to stop at these relatively minor amendments. To obtain the maximum benefits from such a scheme far greater flexibility in the labour market is required. Labour market reform, which is needed for the effective restructuring of the economy, is simply not forthcoming from this tired and discredited Government. It is a government, particularly in this arena, which is hamstrung by its close affiliations with the union bosses. In contrast, the Opposition has a comprehensive industrial relations policy which, when implemented, will contribute greatly to improving the flexibility and efficiency of the labour market and therefore the productivity of the Australian economy.

I want finally to comment quite quickly but directly on the other two Bills being dealt with, the Income Tax Rates Amendment Bill and the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2). Consumers should note that the sales tax Bill will put into effect measures announced in the Budget; namely, to facilitate the imposition of 20 per cent sales tax on goods used by retailers to wrap or secure goods for marketing, to facilitate the imposition of a 10 per cent sales tax on thick shake mixes and ice creams, and to facilitate the taxing at the rate of 10 per cent of accessories to takeaway food containers, such as spoons and serviettes. These are further increases in taxation which I fear will fall disproportionately on the poor and the elderly, and of course on children.

TALK.START.PARA: —What? Paper serviettes?

—Of course, with all the takeaway food. It is being treated in the same way as food consumed in restaurants. The tax is moving from zero to 10 per cent and, if the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) does not think that many of the elderly and many children eat takeaway food, he is nearly as far removed from the real world as the Treasurer.

SPEECH.PARA: In contrast, the Income Tax Rates Amendment Bill will reduce the company tax rate from 49c in the dollar to 39c. However, companies, their owners and their customers are not as lucky as that reduction would make one think. On the other side of the equation, the removal of various accelerated depreciation provisions and other tax concessions will take the edge off the changes. The Government's own figures show that within four years the company tax rate cut will decrease revenue by $1,700m a year while the so-called base broadening measures, for which we can read in the words `tax increases', will increase revenue by $2,785m a year. Therefore, by the end of the day the Government will be collecting $1,085m a year more in revenue. So much for tax reform. After all, tax reform to this Government means nothing but tax increases. It must realise the crippling effect the huge tax burden is having on the incentive to both work and invest in Australia today. Tax cuts funded by expenditure cuts are needed to stop the assault on the living standards of Australians, especially those on low and middle incomes. The Opposition recognises this. The Government, in its arrogance, ignores it at its peril.

In conclusion, I simply reiterate what I said at the outset: we will not be opposing the Bills, but I am moving a second reading amendment and will be moving amendments at the committee stage to oppose the removal of the tax exemption for goldmining income. I now move to the second reading motion:
That all words after ``That'' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
``whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House notes that:
(1) This is the highest taxing government in the post-war history of Australia;
(2) through the insidious effects of `bracket creep' an estimated $7 billion has been ripped off Australian taxpayers since 1985-86;

(3) despite the additional revenue gained through `bracket creep', the Government continues to attempt to raise more tax revenue by imposing new taxation on the gold mining industry despite a firm and unequivocal commitment by the Prime Minister prior to the last election not to do so; and
(4) the Keating/Hawke Government should be condemned for its indefensible action in breaking its pledge not to impose a tax on the gold mining industry''.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek your indulgence to make a brief statement. There is a minor error on page 21 of the explanatory memorandum presented to the House on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5). The error appears in the paragraph entitled `Introductory note to clauses 9, 10, 16 and 17'. The reference to clause 13 in line 5 of the paragraph should be a reference to clause 26.
—The Opposition notes the explanation. It is typical of the sloppy drafting contained in this tax legislation.
—Order! The honourable member should not approach the table and just make a statement--
—We have to acknowledge it somehow, surely.

—Order! The honourable member should know that if he wishes to comment on a statement that a Minister has made, he should seek the indulgence of the Chair as well. The House needs the forms of the House to be dealt with. The honourable member should know that a member should not just stand up and speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite amazing that the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) has moved this second reading motion amendment. I want to comment on his claim in the substance of his amendment that the Hawke Labor Government is the highest taxing Government, which is a quite ridiculous and nonsensical claim.
—You can't add up.

—I can add up. The interest shown by the Opposition was reflected by the fact that the honourable member for Kooyong was not present in the chamber when this debate began. A quorum had to be called so that he could be given time to get to the chamber. That shows his real interest in this issue. The honourable member's amendment contains a rather ridiculous statement about this Government being a high taxing government. The people of this country are aware that it is the Hawke Labor Government that has moved to address the problems of taxation in this country. During all the years that the Opposition parties were in government-under the leadership of Fraser, Menzies or anyone else-they did nothing to try to reduce the amount of tax paid by the ordinary pay as you earn taxpayer.
—Nor have you.

—I hear the honourable member say, `Nor have you'. Let us look at the facts: when we came to government the highest tax rate was 60c in the dollar; today it is 49c. The third rate has come down to 29c and the bottom rate has come down from 30c to 24c. The threshold has been raised to $5,100.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has also acted to address the problems faced by those on low incomes, those on restricted incomes, such as pensioners. The Government this year has acted to overcome the provisional tax problem for pensioners. Honourable members who bothered to read the May statement and the Budget would appreciate that under the previous Government the provisional tax threshold for pensioners was $1,000. If pensioners had a few thousand dollars in the bank-they could have $8,000 or $9,000 after selling their home and moving into a home supplied by a church or other organisation-and earned more than $1,000 in interest, under the previous Government, of which the honourable member for Kooyong was a member, they would have paid provisional tax. This Government has moved to overcome that problem so that now, a pensioner can earn $10,332-a combination of pension, interest or dividends or other income-and not pay provisional tax.

This Government has also acted to ensure that there is a decent rebate for pensioners. It has been increased from $6,142 to $6,892. It is quite ridiculous for the honourable member for Kooyong to make these claims. It is typical because the Opposition is trying desperately to find something about which to criticise the Government. I ask the people of Australia who listen to the broadcast of this debate and who read Hansard to look at the facts. They will understand that it is this Government, despite the difficult economic circumstances that it has faced since coming into government in 1983, that has moved to address the problems. It has not been easy. We have had to take those problems in line, in order of priority. That is what has been done.

The legislation removes the present income tax exemption that applies to income from gold mining. There is a parochial part of me that says, `I don't like that because Mount Morgan is in my electorate'. But every other mining industry faces a tax system. I have yet to hear a reasonable argument as to why the gold industry ought to be exempt. I have heard from some of my colleagues of the export importance of the gold industry. We have given a signal to that industry. The tax is being phased in, and I think that is reasonable.

There is a reduction in the rate of deduction for investment in the Australian film industry from 120 per cent to 100 per cent. There will still be those who say that that measure will take away the investment potential of the film industry. But there ought to be equity and fairness in the tax investment and tax deduction systems. The Government has moved-honourable members will note that this measure is contained in one of the cognate Bills-to establish deductibility for gifts to the Australian National Gallery. I note that this is being supported by the Opposition. There is also a minor fine tuning of the fringe benefits tax. Surely, this fine tuning should go on. Regardless of the wisdom that exists on the Government benches, there will always be the need, as anomalies arise, to fine tune the laws that are on the statute books. There is also a clarification of the law that relates to the refund to overpaid sales tax.

These measures are part of an ongoing program to bring about equity and fairness in the tax system of this country. We are achieving that. It has been a long hard road, but we are moving down the fast track to bring about the clarification, to fine tune and to remove those anomalies. It takes great courage, Mr Deputy Speaker, as you would be well aware from your part in those discussions and being one of the prime movers to ensure that equity does prevail. It takes courage to tackle the problems that exist in this country. I am sure that all honourable members who understand the difficulties that have been before us will understand that they are not always palatable decisions but they have to be made.

Thinking Australians will understand what has taken place. The Hawke Labor Government has addressed problems that have prevailed in this country for over three decades. We have revamped the tax scales, as I said earlier. We have introduced policies to remove the rorts in fringe benefits and have introduced an assets test to bring about fairness. We have introduced measures to stop tax avoidance and tax evasion. It is people's money we are talking about. So often I hear from members of the Opposition that it seems to be something for the Government, as if it is something for Labor members. The money saved is for the people. It means more services for the people and a cut in the national debt. It means more roads and a better and higher quality education system. Everyone realises that there is a need to bring into place a system in which people pay their way based on their ability to do so.

I find it quite amazing that Opposition members stand up in this House time after time and talk about the sorts of problems that are supposed to exist under this Government. Let us go back to the Fraser-Howard-Peacock Government and look at one simple tax system: the income tax zone rebate system introduced by Malcolm Fraser and then Treasurer Howard. It is a tax system that is iniquitous and totally unfair. I notice that the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) is in the House this evening. I am sure he would concur with the points I raise. The anomalies are myriad. That is the system that the Liberal and National parties put in place to, as they say, bring about some special rebate for those who live in the remote areas of this country.

Honourable members who know something of history will appreciate that the system put in place by the Fraser Government was a zonal system based on four zones: zone A; a special zone A; zone B; and a special zone B. This system is anomalous because it is based on a concept of distance from a populated area of 2,500 people. I spoke recently with the honourable member for Kalgoorlie about the sorts of areas he has in his electorate. The situation is quite atrocious when it comes to the minor rebate that is available for people who live in remote areas, who live in isolation, who face difficult, uncongenial climatic conditions, and who face the high cost of living. Let us be mindful that it was the Fraser Government that put this system in place.

I argue that there is now a need for change. We have had six years to see that this system has not worked. The zone arrangement that the Liberal and National parties argued for and legislated for is no longer fair and equitable. I have some figures ragarding the sorts of problems that exist. From looking at the maps that I obtained from the Australian Taxation Office, one finds that a person who lives within 250 kilometres of the central Australian town of Alice Springs does not obtain the full tax rebate. It is quite amazing that one can live in any of those small areas around Alice Springs but does not receive the full tax rebate. One receives a miserable $270 as a rebate; in other words, from a tax debt of $4,000 one subtracts $270. One can also claim a 50 per cent add-on of the rebates allowable under the Tax Act. That is quite an amazing situation. The same situation does not exist only for those people who live within 250 kilometres of Alice Springs; the same thing is true of anyone who lives within 250 kilometres of Katherine in the Northern Territory.

It just amazes me that the Liberals and Nationals get up here and talk about equity and fairness when this is the system they introduced. In my own State of Queensland, again I refer to zone A. If one lives within 250 kilometres of Mount Isa-and one can imagine the sorts of townships that exist in that area, towns such as Camooweal, Dajarra, Urandangi and Cloncurry-one is not eligible under the previous Fraser National Party system. The National Party are the people who are supposed to represent the country people. They never deemed that one was eligible for the maximum rebate in the zonal tax system. One hears these honourable members opposite stand up and say how wonderful things were under their regime and how things are supposed to have deteriorated.

The maximum for zone A, for special zone A, is $938 plus a 50 per cent add-on for the relevant rebates. But if one moves into zone B one comes down to a pittance of $45. Can anyone imagine receiving $45? It would not even pay the extra cost on potatoes for a year or, for those who have a drink, the extra cost on beer, let alone petrol and all the other everyday needs of people. The sort of thing that angers me as a Queensland member is that if one lives within 250 kilometres of the far western township of Longreach one does not get special category A, zone A, or special zone B. One ends up with a $45 rebate. That is pathetic. It must be changed. It is the same when one looks at Charleville. If one lives within 250 kilometres of Charleville one is not eligible from the proper zone rebates.

If we move from Queensland to New South Wales we find the same thing. One can be within 250 kilometres of Bourke and not be eligible for the rebate. One is not eligible for zone A; there is no chance of getting that. But one cannot even get special zone B, because one is within 250 kilometres of a township that has 2,500 people or more. Further south, at Broken Hill, the same is true. In Western Australia-I know the special interest of the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell)-if one lives within 250 kilometres of Kalgoorlie one does not get the full zonal rebate. The same is true for Newman and Broome. Imagine a tax rebate system under which someone who lives within 250 kilometres of Broome in the north-western parts of Western Australia is not eligible for the maximum zone rebate.

I am asking members of the Government to consider very carefully a proposition that we have this matter referred to the expertise of our economic committee that the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown) used to chair. I also ask that it be referred to the rural task force, because we need to bring down a new policy. We have isolated townships in my State of Queensland-Urandangi, Duchess, Hughenden, Julia Creek, Quilpie, Cunnamulla, Dirranbandi, Augathella and Tambo-which are not eligible for the top rate because of the rules that exist. We have anomalies. Mining towns in my electorate such as Moranbah, Middlemount and Dysart are not eligible for any tax rebate. But because of the way the zones have been drawn across the nation, people in a coastal town like Mackay, which is a beautiful place to live, receive zone B rebate. It does not make sense. It certainly is not fair. I know it is a matter of concern for many members of the Government. It is a matter that must be addressed. I argue that, as we move down the track to bring about equity and fairness in the tax system across this nation, we must address the problems facing those people who live in country and central Australia.

One only has to travel in these regions. One only has to have an electorate like mine, Capricornia, which covers 53,000 square kilometres. It takes 7 1/2 hours to drive from one end to the other. That gives one a good understanding of what distance is all about. I have no understanding of what the honourable member for Kalgoorlie has to put up with because his electorate, I believe, is about 10 times the size of Ireland and other such countries.

I know from my own experience of the sorts of problems that exist. I know from talking with people in the consumer movement that one can buy potatoes in Brisbane for $1.99 a kilo but in Mount Isa the price is $3.99. If one goes into my own electorate one pays almost twice for the ordinary newspaper. One will pay 64c a litre for fuel, yet in Brisbane one can sometimes get it for 49c. These are the sorts of problems that the income tax zone rebate system is supposed to address.

If one looks at the documentation that is provided by the Treasury-I thank it for the information it has provided-we see that we aim as a Government and as a Parliament to try and give some sort of assistance and subsidy to those who live in remote parts of this nation. We try to address the problems of the high cost of living and the problems of remoteness and distance that in themselves cause a great cost in travel. But the present system is unfair. It must be changed. I give special credit to the Treasurer (Mr Keating). I give special credit to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) for the thrust of the campaign that he has embarked upon to bring about a new system of fairness for every Australian. We have had our priorities. But I argue that those priorities now ought to target people in country areas. It might be said that $938 is a lot of money as a tax rebate. It is okay if one can get it, but $45 is a pittance. Unless we can raise the quantum, unless we can change the zonal system and unless we can bring about a new system that is based on a local authority structure, population and the elements of distance I do not believe we will meet the needs of those people in country and rural Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this cognate debate I intend to concentrate particularly on the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2). The House will recall that during the Government's 1985 National Taxation Summit the Treasurer (Mr Keating) favoured proposals for a broadly based consumption tax, proposals eventually killed off by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) after concluding a back room deal with the Australian Council of Trade unions. Undeterred by his failure to secure support for a consumption tax policy, the Treasurer instead set about imposing a covert consumption tax.

SPEECH.PARA: At this point I think it pertinent to add that personally I have strong reservations about the introduction of a consumption tax. Theoretically, when a consumption tax is introduced there is a concurrent reduction in rates of personal taxation. In other words, there is a trade-off. That is to say, the cost of a consumption tax is offset by a reduction in personal rates which should leave taxpayers no worse off than before. That is the theory. However, once a tax is established the rate of tax applied inevitably begins an upward climb as government seeks to increase its revenue take, as happened with value added tax in the United Kingdom.

The least that can be said for the introduction of a consumption tax is that by announcing its intention to impose such a tax the Government is being honest. It is telling people what it is proposing to do and giving them the opportunity to present their views. This dishonest way of introducing a consumption tax is to do it the way the Hawke Government has done.

Since 1985 the Treasurer has set about expanding the wholesale sales tax base. This has had three major effects: firstly, it has adversely impacted on the living standards of all Australians, particularly families; secondly, it has resulted in a huge increase to Consolidate Revenue; and thirdly, it has placed an onerous burden on Australian small businesses.

In effect, the Treasurer who failed in his efforts to have a consumption tax brought in in 1985 has, since that time, been introducing a consumption tax by stealth. I should at this point remind the house that the Budget estimates an overall increase in sales tax revenue of 14.4 per cent during this financial year. Sales tax will represent about 10 per cent of all revenue collected.

The Treasurer's policy of introducing a consumption tax by stealth, in which he is aided and abetted by the Prime Minister, particularly angers me as I represent an electorate that is predominantly made up of growing families-the group hardest hit by this dishonest policy. The most dishonest factor in all of this is, of course, that, with the introduction of the Treasurer's consumption tax by stealth, there has been no tax trade-off. Personal tax rates bracket creep has already amassed over $7 billion since 1985-86.

The now familiar picture of the Grim Reaper is an apt personification of the Treasurer. The honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) is firmly in the record books as the highest taxing Treasurer since the Second World War. This Government's economic policies, overseen by the Treasurer, have crushed the living standards of Australian's, yet the Government has not batted an eyelid. As I and my colleagues in the Opposition have said many times before, Labor has savaged Australians, and in particular Australian families. So savage has been the Labor Government's attack that a family on average weekly earnings, with a dependent spouse and two children, would need a minimum tax cut in July 1989 of $56 per week to restore household income to its March 1983 level.

If we strip away the language of the draftsmen, it becomes clear that this Bill represents yet another attack on the hip pockets of Australian consumers and a further administrative impost on small business. No one, it seems, is immune from the Treasurer's great tax grab. From the man who has not seen the inside of a supermarket or a corner milk bar since 1983, we now have the decision that even the little pleasures of life enjoyed by Australia's children are to be taxed, albeit through the cash registers of small business so as not to have the appearance of a tax. Thickshake mixers used in the manufacture of thickshakes and ice-creams are henceforth to be taxed at the rate of 10 per cent. The biggest consumers of these two products, as we all well know, are Australian children.

It was bad enough when the honourable member for Blaxland imposed an iniquitous sales tax on soya bean milk, a product that is vitally important to the health and well-being of the 25,000 children in this country who are unfortunate enough to be allergic to dairy products. In that particular case, it took a long campaign by me, as chairman of the Opposition treasury committee, and various other people to persuade the Treasurer to see sense and have some understanding of the problems faced by those 25,000 children. He finally showed sense in the last Budget when at long last he exempted plain soya bean milk from the 20 per cent slaes tax he had so callously imposed earlier. The repeal of the sales tax on soya bean milk was indeed a triumph. However, it seems that the Treasurer remains intent on getting children to contribute to Consolidated Revenue one way or another. This time he has turned his attention to two products that children consider fundamental: thickshakes and ice-creams. How low can the Treasurer go?

Convenience foods are designed to make life easier and the products themselves cheaper. The trends indicating an increasing use of convenience foods by consumers was not missed by the Treasurer in the last Budget. Noting the trend was one thing; finding a way to get in and capitalise on it was another. The Treasurer knew full well that taxing foods, particularly staple foods, would be very unhealthy politically. This left him with a problem. Just how was he going to add a slice of this expanding market to his ongoing tax grab?

He solved the problem in a most deceitful way. He simply further broadened the sales tax base to include a 20 per cent sales tax on all goods used to wrap or secure products for marketing, delivery and household use. That includes everything from cardboard boxes to plastic wrap and masking tape. Furthermore, containers for marketing biscuits, snack goods and ice-creams are now to be taxed at 10 per cent. For those parents encouraging their children to stay off lollies and instead to eat muesli bars and similar health food bars, the news from this Government is all bad. The Treasurer has introduced a sales tax on these items as well. So much for good health in the Australian community. Other items falling within the Treasurer's broadened tax base include all pre-packaged coffee. Chocolate and malt-flavoured milk drinks with less than 95 per cent milk content will now be taxed at the rate of 20 per cent.

The extensive broadening of the indirect sales tax base, overseen by the honourable member for Blaxland, has, in effect, given Australia a consumption tax without any personal tax trade-off. In concluding, I call on the Treasurer to stop this surreptitious use of the sales tax system. Were the Government's sales tax policy in any way honest, there would have been a personal tax trade-off of substance long ago.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we have heard from the Opposition the usual carping criticism of the Government's taxation policies. The Opposition does not recognise the degree of reform that has been carried out by this Government in the area of taxation. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Bruce (Mr Aldred), gave examples of changes to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act without recognising the sales tax changes that were announced in this year's Budget. The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2) and a Bill that was debated earlier represent an attempt to bring some consistency into the way different items are treated by sales tax. That is never recognised by the Opposition which, for the period of the Fraser Government, was in charge of a tax system which was out of control.

SPEECH.PARA: The typical sort of second reading amendment has been moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, shadow Treasurer and honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). With every taxation Bill, similar amendments are moved by the Opposition. The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) will put into place changes announced in the May economic statement, which include repealing the exemption from taxation of income from goldmining, with effect from 1 January 1991. Again, it is an inequity of the present tax system that this Government is trying to correct.

What did the shadow Treasurer have to say about that? He talked about the levelling of the playing field. He suggested that, instead of going about the changes in the exemption from tax of income from goldmining, we should be looking at different expenditure cuts. When we look at the financial impact of just that one measure, we see that in 1991-92 it will raise $70m and the full year effect will be $300m. The Opposition has a problem. It consistently puts forward amendments to the present tax regime that will cost substantial amounts of money. Then all the eager, young shadow Ministers, such as the shadow Minister who is at the table, the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), want to push the barrow of their shadow ministries. There is one amazing thing about pushing the barrows of shadow ministries: it usually means spending more money. The honourable member for Gippsland the self-styled cranium crusher of the Opposition who wants to stomp around kicking heads, in defending the scientific community is really on about spending more money.

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolutely, in this case.

—There may be an argu- able case for that; but yesterday his colleague-interestingly enough, also from the National Party-the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), as shadow spokesman on transport, said that there should be additional spending on roads.

SPEECH.PARA: Another colleague of the honourable member for Gippsland the shadow Minister for veterans' affairs, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), comes into this place and asks for more money to be spent on veterans' affairs. Where is all the money going to come from? The key shadow economic spokesmen, such as the newly appointed shadow Minister for Finance, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), come into this place and say that what we need are quality cuts in expenditure. So, whilst the Opposition's economic managers come in here saying that there should be cuts, all the eager beavers, who perhaps think that they are moving somewhere-I am not too sure-come in here saying, on behalf of their constituencies, that we should be spending more. I hazard a guess that, if Australia suffers the misfortune of the Opposition becoming the Government, these eager beaver shadow Ministers will be stomped on from a great height and will not get their way. It will be interesting to see how well they fare in protecting the expenditure in their respective areas.

It is the same sort of carping attitude we get all the time. This Government is engaged in an ongoing reform of the taxation system. A whole list of things has been done to tax. The tax system that was inherited by the Hawke Government was grossly unfair, riddled with inequalities and characterised by rorts and evasions which were not being chased by the previous Government. Recently, when the Commissioner of Taxation suggested that he should be having a look at the ways in which big business goes about avoiding tax, we had the spectacle of the Opposition saying that he was getting overzealous. Opposition members have to be fair dinkum. The shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong, comes into this place often and talks about ordinary Australians. I do not know how many ordinary Australians he would associate with, but I certainly cannot see why ordinary Australians would be particularly taken by the Opposition's attitude in saying, `Please, Mr Taxation Commissioner, do not pursue big business. Do not force them to pay their proper tax'. It is a complete nonsense.

Honourable members opposite have criticised a number of other tax measures this Government has put in place: the abolition of entertainment expenses as business deductions, the requirement that taxpayers substantiate their tax deduction claims, the introduction of a capital gains tax, the introduction of tax on non-cash fringe benefits, a foreign tax credit system, the ending of the double tax on company dividends through a full imputation system, the ongoing review and rationalisation of the sales tax regime, which I mentioned earlier, an historic reduction of the rate of company tax, the delivery of genuine tax cuts to all income earners in 1986 and 1987 and, next year, the delivery of further real cuts in taxation.

Then we had the toing and froing, the gut-wrenching by Opposition members, over whether they would support the tax file number which was a further step in the process of reform and which represented a further attack on what, under the Fraser-Howard years, was a growth industry-tax evasion and avoidance.

Perhaps the real problem is that the Opposition has become used to the luxury of being in opposition-the ability to sit over there and just criticise and oppose for the sake of criticism and opposition. Opposition members have become comfortable advocates of lost causes, without the responsibility of government. Many of them are doomed to spend their entire careers on that side of the House. Those opposite who remember being in government know very well the responsibility that it carries, but they have degenerated to the level of the more recently elected members on that side of the House-the level of policy-making by whim. If ever we have seen policy-making by whim, we see it here. I feel sorry for the scientific community due to the present whim of the shadow Minister. The Opposition has made rash and irresponsible promises without having any ability of convincing its colleagues that it can put in place the statement that it makes. It really is a shame that after five years of opposition, we still see a coalition that cannot get down to being constructive and putting into place appropriate alternative policies. That is really what being in opposition should be about. I regret to have to say that in some of the years that the Australian Labor Party spent in opposition, it perhaps ignored that as the main game. But with the actions that we on this side of the House have seen in the life of the Hawke Government, people can be assured that a responsible attitude has been taken to all policy matters, including the area of taxation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) before the House, I wish to concentrate my remarks on the amendment moved by the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), the shadow Treasurer. Let me remind the House of paragraphs (3) and (4) of that second reading amendment. Paragraph (3) states:

SPEECH.PARA: despite the additional revenue gained through `bracket creep', the Government continues to attempt to raise more tax revenue by imposing new taxation on the gold mining industry despite a firm and unequivocal commitment by the Prime Minister prior to the last election not to do so; and
Paragraph 4 states:
The Keating/Hawke Government should be condemned for its indefensible action in breaking its pledge not to impose a tax on the gold mining industry.

I join the honourable member for Kooyong, and indeed the Opposition, in, firstly, supporting this amendment and, secondly, condemning the Government for the imposition of yet another tax in line with a whole series since it came to Government in March 1983.

I want at the very start to place the gold tax in its context. Those who have not visited outback Australia, principally Western Australia or Queensland, do not fully appreciate the cultural development of the gold mining industry. It is deeply ingrained in the consciousness of West Australians and many Queenslanders that there should not be a gold tax, otherwise those parts of their States simply will not be developed. It is not just a question of the Government bleeding yet another resource-based industry. But it is rather a question of: What sort of Australia do we want? Unless we have visited those areas and seen the make-up of those isolated, remote communities of Mount Magnet, Leonora and Kalgoorlie-there is a whole string of them that have grown only in the last few years because of the boom in the gold mining industry-we would not be able to appreciate this. Those areas would never have been developed, at least not to the same extent, but for a tax-free gold industry.

The people who make up those areas are, for want of a better word, the really true Australians. I met hundreds of them in all of the public meetings I have attended in gold mining towns. They are mainly young people who are prepared to suffer the harshness of those areas for a couple of years, build a stake, move back to Perth, Brisbane, Melbourne or Sydney and start from a solid basis. Many are not educated as they have left school young. None are very qualified, yet they are able to get ahead in life because they represent the best things about this country: individualism and effort in working in a team. This gold tax is going to turn those cultural values on their heads. We are going to stop an industry in its tracks, one that is booming for the benefit of individuals, for the benefit of communities and whole States and at the end of the day, for the benefit of our nation. The Government should explain to me the logic of destroying an industry that is conferring such benefit and such wealth on Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the balance of payments argument?

—What about the balance of payments, indeed! As we have reached 40 per cent of the estimated $9.4 billion annual balance of payments deficit-$3.8 billion-in 25 per cent of the time, our balance of payments figures are shot to pieces. Indeed, the Treasurer has admitted as much in recent days. I move now to the economic arguments that surround the rejection by the Opposition of a gold tax. I cannot stress strongly enough on Government members the underlying values which apply to the debate and which cannot be ignored. It is not just a matter of 7,000 people directly involved in the goldmining industry now being placed at risk. Whole communities, many shopkeepers and small businesses and many qualified and unqualified people, will quite frankly desert those parts of Western Australia in droves.

SPEECH.PARA: The imposition of a gold tax by the Government shows a fundamental misunderstanding of the nature of the gold industry. One has to understand that it is not like a jam factory. One must keep building the factory. One does not just roll off easily manufactured bottles of jam whose cost pricing is easily estimated. Because one is forever building the factory, one is totally dependent on exploration.

The imposition of the Labor Government's gold tax is already destroying exploration efforts and, quite frankly, will be the final nail in the coffin of a great many explorers in a very short period. In gold production we are world leaders, but we are world leaders only because of the tax regime that has existed until now. Make no mistake about that: we could not be in the position we are in but for the freedom from the same corporate tax so heavily imposed on other industries. The reason for that is, of course, the low grade ore that exists throughout most of Australia. A comparison of ore grades with those of other countries shows that Australia, because of its previous tax structure-about to end, because of the Labor Government-has been allowed to mine that ore on a large scale. Of course, in all mineral ventures there will be a grey area; there has to be a cut-off line. There will always be low grade ore and low grade minerals. The point with the gold industry is that so much of it is low grade. Very little of it is high grade comparable to other countries.

Because this ore is mined in remote areas, the goldmining industry has to overcome location difficulties. The point to bear in mind is that we are not the only producers of minerals in the world. We are very competitive at the moment, but we have to compete for this investment dollar. The changing of rules by the Government, in a complete diversion from its earlier commitments-made at election time, of course-creates instability. Look at the figures on gold production. In 1983 it was 17 tonnes, in 1988 it will be 140 tonnes. Next year it is expected to be 170 tonnes. Of course, from then on the slide down the slope will be dramatic when the industry starts paying the gold tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will stop!

—The honourable member for Bass, a man knowledgeable in this area, says that it will stop. Forget the expansion; it will stop the normal operating of the gold industry. Let us deal with some of these economic arguments. I am amused when people argue that there has to be equity in the tax system and, for that reason, the gold industry should be paying the same tax. That is a very Whitlamesque statement worthy of a Jim Cairns or a Rex Connor, because it means that everyone is dragged down to the same level. The tax regime for the gold industry should stand as the model, not as the anomaly. When are we in this country going to try to structure our tax regime so as to allow our resource industries to reach their full potential?
—Take taxes off; don't put them on.

—As my colleague says, take taxes off; do not put them on. This is a new tax. People should understand the comparison between the coalition and the Government. We object to the imposition of new taxes. It is a nonsense to say that the gold industry does not pay tax. It pays fringe benefits tax, payroll tax, sales tax. Its employees pay income tax; the industry pays State government costs and charges. But, most importantly of all, shareholders pay income tax on dividends from earned gold mining profits. One has to take into account the fact that although other companies pay corporate tax, they can pass on an imputation credit to shareholders, who then obtain a corresponding credit against those shareholders' income tax assessments. Therefore, the gold industry does pay tax.

SPEECH.PARA: Moreover, it is argued in some sophisticated reports-which incidentally have not been challenged by either Treasury or the Department of Finance-that the Government by putting a brake on this booming industry will lose more tax than it will gain by the corporate tax. I refer to the reports by the very respected financial institutions Ernst and Whinney Services as well as J. B. Were and Son. Time will not allow me to examine or read into Hansard large extracts from those reports, but it is a respectable, legitimate argument, which the Government has failed to counter, that the Government will lose more tax by killing off this industry.

It saddens me when people like the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, bitterly, in vindictive tones, describe those who would argue against a new gold tax as being spivs and political operators. The truth is that he should get out among the gold mining towns and find for himself the battlers who make up that industry. Let him see the young people trying to get ahead without qualifications. Let him see the service station operators, the townsfolk, all of whom are battling in very harsh conditions to make a go of their lives. He went on to say that some 35 per cent of investors are from overseas. That is utter nonsense. At best, the figure is about 18 per cent. Therefore, that factor must also be taken into account.

Because of the guillotine imposed by the Government earlier today, we shall have no chance to examine this important issue at length. But let no one be under any misunderstanding that we fully support the second reading amendment moved by the shadow Treasurer the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) and oppose the Government's new gold tax. Things have gone bad for exploration in the gold industry since the announcement in the May economic statement, the serious downturn in exploration has left drillers upset and rigs are being unused. Of course, production companies are going flat out before 1 January 1991 but the barometer of the future health of the gold industry is exploration.

I very much regret that I cannot examine in detail the crucial issues before this House, but one thing to bear in mind through all this is that the Opposition is not alone in rejecting the new gold tax. The member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell), a man of no little honour and decency, is placed in a very difficult position, Indeed, in the Kalgoorlie Miner of today's date he said that he has not changed his mind on his stand on a gold tax. If we can read between the careful crafting of those words, that means that he opposes a gold tax. That is what he has said up and down the length and breadth of his constituency. But he was a bit coy. He did not tell the Kalgoorlie Miner exactly how he would vote. He simply said, `You will just have to wait and see what happens'. There will be a division on this matter and the member for Kalgoorlie will be put to the test, as will other Western Australians. What comes first, the interests of their constituents or their own political careers within the Australian Labor Party? There are economic and social reasons why the Opposition opposes the imposition of this new gold tax.
Debate (on motion by Mr Campbell) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I intend to contain my remarks to that section of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1988 that deals with the gold tax. I speak on this Bill with some grave doubts and some grave reservations. Tonight I have listened to hyperbole of the highest order. The shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) came into the House and talked about taxation on gold. I ask: Where was the shadow Treasurer when the honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil) and I were moving the charge against the gold tax? He was nowhere to be seen. It was not until there was an election in the air and the Liberal Party was effectively bludgeoned that it decided it would oppose a gold tax.

SPEECH.PARA: I am opposed to a gold tax for reasons that I have already enumerated. In 1987 I believed that the right thing to do in the national interest was to oppose a gold tax in the Budget. I did that because there were certain circumstances prevailing at the time. There was a clear need for funding the current account; and gold had the capacity to earn a lot of overseas revenue. Also, I was aware of the uncertain and emotional nature of the industry, and I was not at all sure about how the industry would react-and I did not think it was worth taking the risk.

I was also aware of the perilous state of the heavy engineering sector; and I was aware that the gold industry was the only thing driving it at the time. I think they were all good, sound reasons. I did not have a lot of support for that view. I acknowledge that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was one of the few in our Cabinet who recognised the political value of this at the time; and I thank the Prime Minister for that. I also acknowledge the help that Senator Richardson gave me in that regard. I might say that at the time that was won entirely on political grounds. Had I, or Brian Burke, or Julian Grill waivered for one moment there would have been a gold tax, because the mining industry waged a pathetic campaign. I might say that the performance of Mr Duncan Bell was loud, brash and ineffective.

In regard to the Gutman report, the evidence that the mining companies lodged with Gutman was just trash. Gutman, rightly and quite soundly, brought in his recommendations on the basis of what the mining companies said. There was a lot of good evidence presented to Gutman; and that evidence was produced by the Western Australian Government, which got leaders of the mining industry together and said, `Look, you are not being effective; we will do it with you.' The Western Australian Government, and in particular Julian Grill, did the work, and it was a very good document indeed. In the final analysis, the reason there was no tax was that the decision was entirely a political one. I might add that despite the millions of dollars that Western Mining Corporation Ltd paid into this campaign, and its employment of Mr Duncan Bell, it was singularly ineffective.

I shall go into a few things that have been said in the debate tonight, because I actually care about the industry and I also know about it, which members opposite clearly do not. The honourable member for Kooyong, posing as he usually does, said that the gold tax will destroy the industry. It will not destroy the industry. The honourable member said that it would destroy exploration; that there would not be any money for development. The truth of the matter is that the goldmining industry failed in Western Australia when there was no tax. It failed because the price of gold fell. It failed because the mining companies had not undertaken any development. Do honourable members know why mining companies had never done any development? Those companies had not done any development because in the gold mining industry it is not tax deductable. Quite clearly, if there is a regime of tax deduction, companies will explore and develop because that is where they reduce their tax.

It is true that there has been a downturn in drilling in the goldfields. This is not as a result of the tax; it is the result of the failure in October last year of the stock market. All the money that was funding a lot of these things has dried up. However, high quality exploration is still continuing. The good quality drillers are still working very well indeed.

I might add also that there are some people that one simply cannot help. The goldmining industry was offered an out by the State member for Kalgoorlie, Ian Taylor. He said to the gold companies, `Without public support, you are lost'. That is quite clearly true. I remember what happened during the last campaign. I have a large file of letters on the gold tax. Most of those letters I wrote myself. I had to send those letters to people and say: `Sign these letters'. For every genuine letter I got in opposition to the tax, I have a dozen from people saying, `You are a self-interested little so and so. We should have a tax'. There is no support outside the goldfields for this issue. Anyone who saw the campaign waged by Mr Bell in Bendigo will know that that is the case.

The truth of the matter is that the mining companies were offered an option by Ian Taylor. He said: `If you contribute $10 an ounce from the open cuts, $2 from your deep mines and $2 from your tailings, we can get public support behind you. You can be on the board that distributes this money. We can get public support for you and fight for you'. Those people would not be in it. Those people could not even determine their own self-interest. One gentleman at the meeting we convened at the town hall got up and said, `The South Australian Government understands the mining industry. It charges only 30c a gram State royalty'. Incidentally, that is 30c more than the State of Western Australia charges. Do honourable members know that 30c a gram is equivalent to $9 an ounce? So we said quickly, `We will settle for $9 an ounce'. That was not good enough. Although that charge showed great understanding on the part of the South Australian Government, it was not good enough for the companies I am talking about.

Only two companies agreed to pay that levy. The Bond Corporation agreed to discuss it. Goult Pro Partners in Kalgoorlie immediately said that it would pay. Jack and Chris Savage from Goult Pro understand their obligations to society. They immediately agreed to pay. The Bond organisation negotiated and has now agreed to pay $2 an ounce. That is not much but a lot better than ever offered by other companies, particularly Western Mining which raped and plundered in Kalgoorlie for years. Without that public support there is no hope of holding up a gold tax.

I intend to vote against this legislation. Honourable members should not worry about that. I intend to cross the floor to vote against the legislation for a lot of historic reasons. I do it without any great enthusiasm, and I do it with a sense of shame for the attitudes I have heard tonight from members of the Liberal Party. It was said to me yesterday by a member of the Liberal Party, `At least you can say that we will not lose any votes on this. Nobody will vote against us if we vote against the gold tax'. That might be true in isolation, but I think that a lot of people will see the duplicity of the Liberal Party. They will see its cynical opportunism, and could very well vote against it for that reason. Many honourable members opposite have expressed that view to me. Honourable members opposite know in their hearts that they are doing the wrong thing. I add that the man honourable members opposite tout in here tonight, the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong, directly after the 10 May economic statement, was all in favour of the gold tax, as was the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). Recently in New York the Leader of the Opposition said the he could not see any reason for not having a gold tax. What a difference a little bit of silver makes to honourable members opposite.

I ask honourable members opposite to look at the royalty applying in the Northern Territory. This is a front end royalty of very substantial dimensions. It has not stopped exploration of the Northern Territory. It is going ahead apace. The gold industry is lamenting the introduction of a gold tax-a gold tax which is paid only on profit; only after all expenses have been deducted. I might add in this respect that the Hawke Government is as pure as driven snow, because the Prime Minister gave an undertaking that there would not be such a tax in the life of this Government. Clearly there is not going to be one. Furthermore, all expenditure from 10 May can be carried forward as deductions.

On 11 May I was in my office and I was a little upset about what had happened. I got a call from London from the chairman of the board of one of the top 10 gold producers in this country. He said to me, `I would not worry. Wherever the money comes from from overseas for the gold industry-whether it comes from Europe, America or Britain-it is probably in reality coming from Britain'. He said, `In the board rooms of Britain the Hawke Government is held in high regard. It is a very responsible manager of the economy'. He said that for a long time they had factored a gold tax into their calculations because, frankly, they could not see any reason why there was not a tax because of the gold tax in every other gold producing country. He said that they would continue to put money into the goldmining industry because they had confidence in the Government.
At a time when there was no suggestion of a gold tax in this country, Alan Bond removed his gold operations and centred them in America where there has always been a tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why wouldn't he?
—Because there has always been a tax there; he obviously considered that it was better, for whatever corporate reason, to operate in a climate where he was going to pay a tax.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask honourable members opposite to consider also other imposts on the industry. The price of cyanide, which is essential to the industry, has quadrupled. We have been taken to the cleaners on cyanide-a contrived arrangement. We were victims of a cartel. The price of cyanide has dropped back to about three times the price that prevailed at the time, but it is still a substantial cost and this impost will be harder for small miners to bear than income tax. If honourable members opposite understood anything about business they would know that. Where have our great mining companies been in the development of the cyanide industry? Clearly, they are the users of the cyanide. I would have thought that some of them would have had a little foresight and they would have put their money into developing this industry.

There are a lot of other things that I would have liked to have covered but, being aware of the limited time available, I reiterate that I will be voting against the imposition of a gold tax. I certainly wish that it had been otherwise. I do this with no great enthusiasm; and I am not inspired by the sordid little campaign run by people opposite.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would appear, from all the interjections we have had from honourable members on the other side of the chamber, that they like their high taxing Labor Government a lot more than I and my constituents do. Tonight we are facing more tax impositions on top of a whole range of tax Bills that went through the House last week and the week before. We have seen a $1 billion clawback in depreciation allowances; last week we saw the imposition of the tax file number which will affect the mining industry probably as much as any other; and we will see a new tax imposed on gold.

SPEECH.PARA: This country has been built on gold and wool. After 200 years, the year of our bicentennial celebrations, what do we see the Labor Government doing under the guise of a tax equity or some other economic jargon that comes from the Treasurer (Mr Keating)? The Government is using this excuse to impose yet another tax. I am totally opposed to it. I support the amendment which the Opposition will be moving tonight to oppose this new gold tax. Who needs it? Can someone come into this House and explain to me why we need more taxation when a $5 billion surplus was announced in August? It is beyond my imagination and I am sure that it is beyond the imagination of every taxpayer in Australia. The Labor Government has promised tax cuts. Every day we hear the Government saying that we will have tax cuts. We have tax bracket creep imposed on our personal tax system. We have seen massive increases in personal taxes and taxation has increased at the highest level ever in the history of this country in our bicentennial year. The Government is clawing in roughly $85 billion in tax revenue. Our economy is dependent on how we spend the taxes. We do not need a surplus of $5 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why?

—We do not need that sort of surplus. It is just a nonsense. The Government has taken $5 billion out of the economy. Supposedly it was intended to bring down interest rates. We were told that in August, on the night of the Budget, and in the subsequent weeks. What have we seen since then? Within eight weeks of the Budget being brought down we saw interest rates go through the roof again. They climbed by 2 per cent or 3 per cent. They dropped to 11 per cent for 10 days after the Budget and are back to 15 per cent and 16 per cent. The Treasurer told us on Budget night that this massive surplus was needed to keep down interest rates. It just has not done that.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason for the massive surplus is to enable the Government to pay back some of the debt of the early years of the Hawke Government. It is not the previous Government's debt. All governments rack up some debt, but this Government has accumulated debt at the highest and fastest rate of any government in our 200-year history. We started digging for gold in 1850, and we built this nation on gold. We were at the peak of our standard of living in the 1880s, and gold was the substance that put us there-gold and the big increase in beef, wheat and wool growing. It was gold more than anything that brought that prosperity and tonight, for the first time in 200 years, that industry has to suffer yet another tax. As previous speakers have pointed out, it is not the only tax the industry pays. It pays a whole range of other taxes that have been introduced, as well as the normal personal income tax, taxes paid by workers in the industry and the massive sales taxes.

In Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2) for the first time the Labor Government is imposing a tax of 20 per cent on wrapping goods. The government is not happy; it has to tax everything that moves. It is going to tax every bit of plastic that blows about the place. Sales tax will be imposed on thick shakes and ice-cream. I thought we were on a health kick in this nation. We saw the Government reduce the tax on light beer; one can buy a light beer with less sales tax than applies for a thick shake. On thick shakes and ice-cream people now have to pay 10 per cent sales tax. What is this doing to the dairy industry? Why should that tax be imposed? Farmers have been producing milk for 200 years without having to pay sales tax. Milk has always been regarded as a health product and one that we should encourage our children to drink. We have had schemes throughout the nation where State governments have subsidised the distribution of fresh milk to school children. But what do we see these measly, scroogy Australian Labor Party people doing? They want to impose a 10 per cent sales tax on ice-cream and milk. What a measly, scroogy thing to do in this our 200th year-our bicentenary year. The government has placed a 10 per cent sales tax on spoons and serviettes. We cannot even spill our food now without paying sales tax. It is ridiculous.

There are all sorts of other impositions. I must give credit where credit is due. We are seeing a 10 per cent reduction in the company tax rate, and I think that is excellent. The only thing we would like is for that rate to match the personal tax rate. We would like to see personal tax rates at the top level-not just the bottom level that the Treasurer was talking about-brought down to 39 cents in the dollar. If taxation is brought down and the economy is stimulated, the Government will take just as much tax revenue out of a bigger cake. But the Government is continuing to impose more and more taxation, making it harder and harder for people to produce, and they continue to run into this massive trade deficit.

Surely to goodness in the future we will need every ounce of gold we can produce in this nation. As time goes by we will need the gold to survive the crash that the Labor Government is heading us towards. We cannot continue to run a deficit of $1 billion a month.

We cannot continue to trade at that sort of rate. Something has to give; something has to crack. This nation will not survive with the sort of deficit trading it has now. This Government must give more stimulus to business to produce and more stimulus to exporters. It cannot be about knocking off the incentives that the previous Government put in place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10 p.m., the time allotted for the second reading stage of the Bill has expired. The question is that the words proposed to be omitted stand part of the question.
—The question now is that the Bill be now read a second time. Those of that opinion say `aye'; to the contrary `no'. I think the ayes have it.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, there is no-one speaking so can I talk about the gold tax to get on the record that I support the amendment moved by the shadow Treasurer?
—Order! The House has to resolve itself into committee.
—You are still in the chair though, Mr Deputy Speaker.

—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: some confusion appears to have arisen just at the moment because two speakers were jumping simultaneously. With the greatest of respect to them, they were speaking at the same time, while you, frankly, were also attempting to make a point. In all of that confusion to which you, with respect, contributed no little amount, you did not hear a call for a division.
—There was no confusion on the part of the Chair; there was no call for a division.
—I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—I will hear the honourable member for Bass. The Chair did not hear a call for a division.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I understood I had the call to speak.
—No, you did not have the call.
—I was speaking at the time.
—I have heard the point of order. The honourable member will resume his seat.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, you said there was no call for a division on the second reading. It was not the intention of the Opposition, because of the time constraints, to divide on the second reading amendment, but it is our intention to divide on the amendments we will be putting.

—I thank the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. The Chair, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and the Government were quite aware of the proceedings; no direction from other members of the Opposition was required.
