SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 9, page 3, lines 27-30, omit paragraphs (b) and (c).

The Opposition has no argument with paragraph (a) of clause 9 but wishes to omit paragraphs (b) and (c). In view of the time constraints that we are faced with, I also foreshadow that the Opposition will be opposing clauses 10, 16, 17 and 26. We intend to seek to divide the Committee, if there is time, given the constraints of the guillotine that the Government has imposed, on clauses 9, 10, 16 and 17. In any event I want it recorded that we are opposed to those clauses, plus clause 26. It is the time constraint that requires me to speak beyond clauses 1 to 9 at the moment.

The two paragraphs of clause 9 that we seek to omit are the first of the measures relating to the Government seeking to impose a gold tax. I said earlier that we are opposed to those elements that impose a gold tax because we gave a very firm commitment only last year that we were opposed to the introduction of a tax on gold mining. We keep our word, in contrast to certain other people. I discern in particular, quite apart from the remarks that I made in my speech in the second reading debate, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer (Mr Keating), Senator Gareth Evans, and therefore the Government. It seemed evident to me from the remarks of the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) that he will not be supporting the Opposition's amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is.
—I was going to plead with him at this late hour that he change his mind.
—Do you want me to change my mind?

—If that had been correct I was going to ask him to change his mind and vote with us. I am pleased to get the indication from the Leader of the House that he will be with us when we move these respective amendments. I oppose the way in which the House is being run tonight with the guillotine down. It is outrageous when yet another tax is found to be dumped on Australia because of the effect it will have on our balance of payments. I am also interested in seeking to divide and put the Opposition's view by way of voting on as many of these amendments as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The gold tax issue has been around for a considerable amount of time. I would like to make the point, given the remarks of the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell), that the Opposition's position has been consistent since as long ago as June 1986 when we pledged to repeal a gold tax. That is exactly what we are doing tonight for the reasons that have been enumerated by the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), and by the shadow Minister for science and energy, the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran). I think it is important to recall that in principle it might be correct for the Government to argue in favour of a gold tax but it reminds me of the debate we had here over a long period concerning the resources rent tax. The Government has tried to apply an in principle tax but in its implications it has ignored the realities and the historical context in which this tax is to apply to a particular industry. It has refused to identify and acknowledge the investment requirements with regard to the matrix between exploration needs and risks. In doing so and in imposing this tax, which is only going to return somewhere in the vicinity of $300m in a full year based on all the estimates that we have seen from the Industries Assistance Commission, the A.C. Goode and Co. Ltd survey, the J.B. Were survey, the Bain and Co. survey, the expense it is going to in collecting the tax, the estimated return, is going to be outweighed by the damage it is going to do to the industry. That is the very point that has been made time and time again by the industry and in this House tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to listen to reasons why the honourable member for Kalgoorlie is going to cross the floor. We feel for him. It is no small matter to cross the floor in this House from either side but the reasons he gave for doing so lack some consistency. He says that he supports the Hawke Government in this gold tax but finds himself personally unable to support it. That is as far as he goes. He does not substantiate any arguments either way. He does not stand up and say that it is going to have a dramatic effect on the community which he represents which I visited some 10 days ago. Eighty per cent of the gold in this country is found and mined there. I find that his arguments and accusations about the Opposition taking pieces of silver are offensive, unnecessary and, of course, inaccurate.

Our position has been consistent since 1986, when the shadow Minister, Senator Durack, put down in quite concise terms our position with regard to the gold tax. The honourable member for Kalgoorlie is the only one who has the courage to be able to see what a gold tax will do to an industry which, historically, has supported this country. In recent years we have seen the benefits to our balance of payments position-a move from $500m a year to $2,500m. It is a massive increase and of massive benefit to this nation. To impose a tax which is incorrect and improper and which will damage an industry that has dramatically helped our balance of payments indicates the shortsightedness of this Government and its inability to understand the industry in a very vital area from which we as a nation can benefit.

For Senator Walsh to say in the Senate that we are letting $100m go to the benefit of foreign treasuries is a fallacious argument. All that that does is acknowledge his inability to address that particular problem. The Government is pursuing 36 per cent of the industry that is foreign-owned, the money from which goes to other countries rather than to our Treasury. It is ridiculous to then penalise the two-thirds of the income that is earned by Australian companies. I find the whole argument by the Government in favour of this proposal lacking in substance and in logic and, more importantly, lacking in understanding of what this country needs in a tax regime.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I point out that in this legislation the Government has very carefully made sure that it does not tax income received from the sale of gold leases. I have heard some lamenting about prospectors. These days most prospectors make their money by selling their leases to companies to develop and mine them. This legislation does not tax that income. I think that is a very important consideration. I point out to the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), who has just spoken, that I did not at any stage in my speech say that I supported the imposition of the gold tax, for very special reasons.

`(2) If the asset is disposed of within 12 months of the time of its actual acquisition by the taxpayer, subsection (1) of this section has effect as if the references in that subsection to the indexed cost base to the taxpayer in respect of the asset were references to the cost base to the taxpayer in respect of the asset.
`(3) Expressions used in subsections (1) and (2) that are also used in Part IIIA have the same respective meanings in those subsections as they have in that Part.
`(4) For the purposes of any application of subsection 160zk (1):''.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill 1988 gives effect to the Government's decision to sell the assets of the Defence Service Homes Corporation to Westpac Banking Corporation and to put in place arrangements for the delivery of Commonwealth-subsidised housing loans by that bank. This major change in the way benefits under the Defence Service Homes Act 1918 are delivered is of the greatest importance to the Australian veteran community and to present and former members of the Defence Force.

In this context, representatives of the veteran and service communities have been involved over the last two years in looking at ways of improving both the benefits available under the defence service homes scheme and their delivery to the client group. There has been close consultation with these groups during development of the revised arrangements.

The arrangements with Westpac involve the sale of the interest of the Defence Service Homes Corporation in its portfolio of about 134,000 mortgages and terms contracts for an amount equal to the face value of those assets. At 31 October 1988 the face value was approximately $1.39 billion including accrued interest. In addition, Westpac will pay a premium of $100m to participate in the defence service homes scheme. Under the new arrangements, Westpac will take over responsibility for all future lending under the scheme; this will include delivery of certain ancillary benefits such as instalment relief and special loans for widows in hardship.

For several years the Government has been unable for budgetary reasons to make necessary changes to the defence service homes scheme including: removal of the 10-month waiting period for loans to buy homes, now costing borrowers several thousand dollars in bridging finance interest charges; and an increase in the maximum first mortgage loan from the present level of $25,000, which was set in 1980, to a more reasonable proportion of the cost of acquiring a home. There will be no waiting period for Westpac loans, which will be repayable over a period of up to 25 years and will be portable from one home to another. Home buyers will be able to borrow in excess of $25,000 as a first mortgage with the Commonwealth subsidising the repayments on the first $25,000 of any loan; borrowers will also save by not having to meet two sets of loan establishment charges or pay second mortgage interest rates on the amount borrowed in excess of $25,000. The revised arrangements will remove the need for a statutory corporation and the Defence Service Homes Corporation will cease to exist once the handover to Westpac is complete. The future administration of the defence service homes scheme will be undertaken within my portfolio. It is estimated that under the revised arrangements there will be resource savings of up to 360 staff and $11.5m per year.

The revised defence service homes scheme will involve: the assessment and determination of the entitlement of eligible persons for benefits under the scheme; and the payment of subsidy in relation to both the assets sold to Westpac and those new loans made by Westpac. The subsidy will be an amount paid to the bank, not the client, on a monthly basis, reflecting the difference between the interest paid by clients on their loans-6.85 per cent on new loans and various rates below that rate on mortgages sold to the bank-and an agreed rate of return to the bank. It is estimated that the subsidy cost in a full year will be $145m. The revised arrangements agreed with the bank do not involve any change to the status of people who are already eligible under the Defence Service Homes Act-any of these people who have not previously sought assistance under the scheme will be able to apply for the new benefits.

The Bill will give effect to the Government's decision that persons who enlisted in the Defence Force after 14 May 1985 will not become eligible for benefits under the scheme-the form of housing benefit to be provided for these persons is being considered. The defence service homes insurance scheme is not included in the business sold to Westpac. This business will continue as a self-funded cooperative home insurance scheme, being operated by the Commonwealth and administered within my portfolio. Other benefits under the scheme will continue to apply and be delivered by the Commonwealth or the bank as set out in the agreement which is attached as schedule 1 to the Bill.

When announcing the proposed changes to the scheme the Government promised that eligible persons and borrowers would not be disadvantaged under the new arrangements. The agreement with Westpac and this Bill provide for a considerable improvement in the range and quality of benefits available under the scheme. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: LANDS ACQUISITION (REPEAL AND CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 3 November, on motion by Mr West:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Bill is complementary to, and a necessary part of, the Lands Acquisition Bill 1988 legislative package. As it will facilitate the implementation of the new legislation, with its greatly improved provisions, the Opposition will not oppose it. Our concern is that the new legislation is promulgated as quickly as possible. In the earlier debate I referred to the situation at Badgerys Creek. It is essential that acquisitions are completed without delay so that the new airport planned there can get under way. There has been enough political bickering and delay. It is time that all the necessary acquisitions were concluded, not only out of justice and fairness to the landowners, but because the airport is needed urgently to relieve the pressure on Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support (Mr Punch) has made a commitment on behalf of the Government for phased development of a new airport at Badgerys Creek. It is time for the Government to get on with it and for the compensation provisions of the new Lands Acquisition Bill to be applied to those acquisitions which have not yet been concluded. Most of this Bill's provisions are of a consequential procedural nature which are necessary for the operation of the main Bill. They should be implemented as soon as possible. In the interest of `justice' and `fair treatment' for people whose land is acquired, I would again ask the Minister to monitor carefully the operation of the new legislation, and to promptly correct anything that creates an anomaly. Let us not wait for years before doing something about it.

For the information of honourable members, I would like to acknowledge that, following the debate on the Lands Acquisition Bill 1988, I received a message from the Minister saying that he had not just brushed aside some points I had made about mining regulations and the proclamation of the Bill. He informed me that the regulations did not have to be completed before proclamation of the Bill, as this contingency was provided for under clause 124 (8) of the Bill. The Minister also indicated that it was expected the Bill would come into force in December or early January. I ask the Minister: Can he now say exactly when the Act will be proclaimed?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lavarch Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the previous speaker, the honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife), has just indicated, the Lands Acquisition (Repeal and Consequential Provisions) Bill is related to the Lands Acquisition Bill passed earlier by this Parliament. The Bill has two primary purposes: firstly, to provide a legal framework for the transition period between the new Lands Acquisition Act and its 1955 predecessor, and, secondly, to repeal and amend other related legislation, including the Airports (Business Concessions) Act 1959, the High Court of Australia Act 1979, the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975 and a number of other pieces of legislation which make reference to the 1955 Act.

SPEECH.PARA: The transition from the existing regime to the new lands acquisition provisions will be biased in favour of those landowners whose property is currently subject to a resumption proceeding; that is, the advantages outlined in the new legislation will be made available to any landowner whose land is being resumed, but in respect of whom the actual process to date has not quite been finalised. As a result, the sorts of protections outlined in the new scheme will be available to these landowners. These protections include the issuing of a pre-acquisition declaration. This is a statement of intention for the resumption and specifies the reasons for which the Government requires the land. It also details-and this is extremely important-the rights of the owner so that the owner knows that he can appeal against the Government's decision as to whether the land should be taken. If there is no great dispute on that point, there are certain rights in regard to the calculation of compensation.

As a solicitor prior to my election to this place, what I find particularly important is the fact that once such a statement is given by the Minister of his intention to resume, a note will be made on the title of the property. This is an extremely valuable safeguard for prospective purchasers so that that information is known. In the past, there have often been long delays between the time that the Government indicates its intention to take land and the time when the process is completed and there is transfer of title. I certainly welcome that change.

The other change outlined in the major legislation relates to specific time limits as to when certain steps have to be taken during the resumption proceedings. Again, this is a major step forward. I hope that the framework outlined in this package of legislation will be seriously looked at by all State governments, in terms not only of their own acquisition programs but also acquisition programs by other boards or local councils even, all of which from time to time go through the process of acquiring property.

Rights of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal after an initial approach to the Minister are also guaranteed. These are extremely valuable provisions. I have had the opportunity of seeing both sides of the resumption procedure, firstly as a solicitor acting for people whose land is being resumed and, on the other side of the fence, as a shire councillor on occasions when the council went through the resumption procedure. In Queensland there is no real right to challenge the purpose for which the State Government or local council is claiming the land. Certainly, there are rights of appeal to the Lands Court if there is a dispute as to the level of compensation to be paid, but one cannot challenge the purpose. If there is any suggestion that the land is not needed for the purpose for which the council wants it, that is too bad. One has to accept that at face value and cannot challenge it, but one can argue about the level of compensation. I hope that this excellent legislation will be looked at by State governments with the idea of introducing some of these provisions.

The detailed compensation regime outlined in the initial legislation, the advantage of which will be given by this Bill to land owners in the transitional stage, is also worthy of support and comment. I was impressed with the idea of a solace payment to compensate for intangible values attached to the property being taken. Under the old regime and the standard regime that is in place throughout the States, intangible values, such as the family history attaching to the land and things of that nature, are not taken into account. Normally if there is a battle about compensation between a couple of valuers in the Lands Court arguing about the value of the land, what it could be sold for and its development potential, there is never any suggestion of taking account of the sentimental or other values that might attach to the property. The fact that that element is provided for in this legislation is a great move forward. Certainly, it means a greater cost to government in its resumptions program, but it is far fairer to landowners. That is a move to be greatly welcomed.

Given the lateness of the evening and the limits on time, I will not go on at great length. The Bill is a relatively non-controversial piece of legislation. It is really an adjunct to legislation which the House has already approved. I understand the Opposition will not oppose the Bill. When the final Act comes into play-and I accept the point that hopefully it will be as quickly as possible-it will set in place a model piece of legislation for the Commonwealth which hopefully will become the norm throughout all Australian jurisdictions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank the participants for their brief contributions. This Bill, of course, is all about the transitional and consequential arrangements which will apply to the introduction of the use of powers under the new Act, the Lands Acquisition Act 1988.

SPEECH.PARA: I should pick up a couple of questions raised by the shadow Minister for Administrative Services, the honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife). He raised the issue of the application of the new Act to Badgerys Creek. I can inform the House that the Government identified the site for the second Sydney airport back in 1986 and offered to acquire, by agreement, any property in the selected area. There are 243 properties on the site; and by the end of October this year, 108 properties had been purchased for an expenditure of $25.6m. In the context of the 1987-88 Budget, the Government undertook to provide $15m, in real terms, each year for four financial years for the acquisition of all properties on this site. The Government wants to apply the 1988 Act to any remaining acquisitions on that site from the time the new Act commences. Acquisitions on that site have been proceeding within an established order of priority-namely, hardship cases, followed by proposals to be acquired submitted by owners in the order in which they have been received.

Pre-acquisition declarations will be issued to owners in the order of that established priority listing. These declarations will give owners the right to appeal decisions to acquire their properties as provided by the 1988 Act. I might inform the House that the application of this process will highlight one of the ways in which this Bill goes further than the recommendations of the Australian Law Reform Commission. The Commission was concerned that, in a multiple acquisition project, an owner who wished to appeal the decision to acquire his property, but who was served a pre-acquisition declaration late in the course of the project would find his case prejudiced by the number of acquisitions that had already occurred.

To overcome that problem, the Government has included in the Bill subclause 31 (2), which states that the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, in hearing any appeal, must disregard any acquisitions that have already occurred. Furthermore, if an owner on the Badgerys Creek site finds that, due to his particular circumstances, he needs the Commonwealth to acquire his property immediately, special considerations will still be able to be applied. The case would be considered by the community-based hardship panel. If that panel recommended priority purchase, and the required timing would not allow for the normal pre-acquisition procedure specified in the 1988 Act, then the urgency provisions of clause 24 could be used.

So, regarding the matter of compensation, to this date none of the properties on the Badgerys Creek site has been acquired using the compulsory process. All of the properties acquired so far have been acquired by agreement-that is, at a price agreed to by the owners. Given the special nature of the acquisition at Badgerys Creek, the Government decided, before it had acquired any properties, that it would apply special terms to these acquisitions. So, as well as paying the market value of each property, disregarding any influence caused by speculation of the timing and location of the new airport, the Government has agreed to pay the costs involved in the vendor obtaining legal and valuation advice; legal and survey costs and normal out of pocket expenses involved in the sale to the Commonwealth, including mortgagees' solicitors' costs for the discharge of any existing mortgage; legal and survey costs and normal out of pocket expenses incurred in acquiring a replacement property of similar value to the one acquired by the Commonwealth; and reasonable removal expenses. These are all items of compensation identified by the Bill that will be paid following a compulsory acquisition. Although none of the properties at Badgerys Creek have been acquired by compulsory process, these costs have been paid on all properties acquired so far. They will be paid on all properties remaining to be acquired.

The issue that concerned the Opposition on the debate on the major Bill, the Lands Acquisition Bill 1988, was what conditions would apply to mining and exploration licences issued under the 1955 Lands Acquisition Act up to the time that the regulations contained in the new Act were ready. Any mining and exploration licences issued under the 1955 Act will continue to apply. The Lands Acquisition (Repeals and Consequential Provisions) Bill 1988 does not contain any transitional provisions relating to mining and exploration licences because the Lands Acquisition Bill 1988, when introduced, already contained the required transitional provision. That provision states that until such time as the new mining regulations are available and after commencement of the 1988 Act the current provisions of section 51 and subsection 53 (2d) of the 1955 Act will still apply. Consequently, enactment of the 1988 Lands Acquisition Bill does not have to wait for the preparation of the mining regulations. I expect that the new Act would commence early in 1989.

Once the new Act is passed by the Senate regulations will need to be drafted, delegations will need to be prepared and the Department will need to be geared to adopting the new procedures. However, none of these tasks will give rise to undue delay-provided we get it through the Senate with minimum delay. The only extensive regulations required by the major Bill are those relating to the mining and exploration provisions. However, subclause 124 (8) of the 1988 Bill will allow for commencement of the Act before those regulations are available by stipulating that the pertinent sections of the 1955 Act will continue to apply until the new regulations are available. The delegations under the 1988 Act required to permit ongoing government business need to be identified and documented. These delegations are extensive, allowing as they do for the processing of literally thousands of leasehold agreements of a standard commercial nature entered into by the Commonwealth, particularly in regard to office accommodation.

The Department of Administrative Services needs to be prepared to adopt the new procedures which can become quite complex because of the protection being provided to owners with whom the Commonwealth is negotiating. Of course, forms need to be prepared and officers who will be undertaking acquisitions need to become familiar with the new documentation. All of these processes have already begun. I am happy to inform the Opposition, the House and the public that I expect that this 1988 Lands Acquisition Bill, to which this transitional and consequential Bill applies, will be proclaimed very early in 1989-I expect by about February.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Migration Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1988 seeks to make three changes to the Migration Act. Its objectives are, firstly, to speed up the processing of visas through ports of entry into Australia; secondly, to allow immigration clearances of certain direct flights into Australia to be completed at an overseas airport; and, thirdly, to ensure that statutory visitors are properly covered by the Act. These amendments in regard to visas have a double goal; the first part of the goal is to simplify the process and the second part is to speed up the processing of the entry of people into Australia. The target that the Department has set at airports is 30 seconds per passenger rather than the current 70 seconds. That time saving will be highly significant for visitors and tourists coming to Australia. The objective is to endeavour to retain the integrity of the system but, at the same time, provide a simplified and a speedier process.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition will not be opposing or amending these provisions. We think that they are sensible and desirable objectives but we have some qualifications that we want to make that the Government should be aware of because they really hinge on the integrity of the process. It is not just the tourists we need to be catering for; the whole process of permanent entry and the possible abuse of the system also have to be considered because of the changes that are being made.

The current process for entry into Australia for a visitor, an overseas student or a permanent resident is that a visa is issued at a foreign port. An Australian official approves the right for somebody to travel to Australia and that person then takes up a visa. As I have indicated, this visa may be a visitor's visa, a temporary visa, a student visa, or a resident visa. That gives the people the right to travel to Australia. On arrival at our front gate another process is gone through-that is, the process where permission to enter Australia is granted. Therefore, we have a twofold process: the grant of a visitor's visa, or the grant of a visa of any sort, and the permission to enter. The adoption of this process is a sensible one and, historically, one can see the reason for establishing the grant to travel to Australia.

The second check is the grant to enter for the purposes stated by the person seeking to travel to Australia. The proposed changes are a simplification whereby the grant of the visa for permission to travel is not changed but the grant of entry takes place within the same document. So instead of a two-step process we have a 1 1/2 step process-a process where the right to travel is granted and, almost automatically, that same document becomes the document for entry into Australia.

But within the changes entry is retained to the degree that permission stands but the processes by which entry is granted are varied under the new arrangement. It requires in practice for the travel document to be stamped but it is no longer a requirement for the officer at the front gate of Australia to select the appropriate stamp and process to match the visa. The officer does not have to say, `Is this a visitor's visa? I will approve a visitor's visa, select the right stamp and stamp the passport'. All he has to do is stamp the passport with the date and the port of entry. So that becomes an entry permit, as the Bill proposes. However, at the same time, the officer granting entry must make a computer registration. The two things-the stamp and the computer registration-constitute the grant of entry. That will speed up the process; it will also limit the chance for abuse. Once that person granted entry makes a decision-for example, a visitor arrives travelling on a visitor visa and the grant of entry by chance happens to be a permanent residency grant-that permanent residency grant cannot be overridden. Once permanent residency is given, be it by mistake or design, that person cannot have that status revoked. So the visa issue becomes the critical part of the process. It is the front-line decision at the foreign port that establishes the status of the person travelling to Australia under the new proposals. That status is checked at the front gate, and the simple process of computer entry and a stamp showing the port and the date concludes the arrangement.

There are some flaws in this process. It does mean that the front-line decision has to be absolutely accurate. If false information is fed in about the status of the person seeking to travel to Australia, then there is little check that can be made on the person's arrival in Australia. With the increasing sophistication of computers and telegraphic links it is hoped that the registration of a desire to travel to Australia and the grant of a visa will be transferred to Australia and computerised here so, when the person arrives on the aircraft, the information held about his visa and his travel desire is checked against the passports they hold. The man at the front gate ought to be able to key into the computer the details of the visa in front of him on the visitor's or resident's passport, which should be matched by the information gathered from overseas. This does mean that that overseas information is critical, so staffing levels and capacity at our overseas posts are a critical factor. It means, too, that we need good information from a number of sources, whether from security sources or departmental records. We must be able to identify people seeking to come into Australia and determine whether they pose a risk of being likely to try to defeat the system or whether they have criminal intentions. That information will be computerised and theoretically should be sounder.

The second proposal in this legislation is the offshore clearance of intending migrants. It is sensible and I can see little problem with it. The concept is that where Australian officers may be required to fly to a port such as Hamilton Island, where there is no regular immigration clearance, they will be able to approve people for entry into Australia at an overseas post. They will be able to go to the airport and, as people walk onto the aircraft, approve migration entry into Australia. Of course, there will need to be Customs checks and, in some instances, health checks. The conditions that the changes to the Act impose are that it must be a non-stop flight and that there must be no capacity for the person to corrupt the process. It allows the prospect of tourists being processed in New Zealand or, maybe at some time in the future, in Japan for entry into Australia. They will arrive and be able to go straight from the aircraft, having been approved prior to their entry onto the aircraft.

The final provision is one that strengthens the situation in regard to statutory visitors-those people brought to Australia for a special purpose, perhaps to appear in a court case, where they have no real claim on Australia and are required by the Minister or the court to leave immediately they have fulfilled their duty here. Those amendments are sound amendments.

I come back briefly to the integrity of the scheme, and refer the House to discussion paper No. 12, on computer crime, by the Gibbs Review of Commonwealth Criminal Law. It makes interesting reading because it examines what sort of penalties should apply and what processes in law should apply to those people seeking to abuse computers. The report contains sections on unauthorised access to computers, the damaging of data, computer related fraud, unauthorised use of computers, and omission to introduce or record data. All of those areas in immigration processes are critical. The fact that we can have multimillion dollar movements of drugs means the price for Australian officials and the prospect of paying for the unauthorised use of computer systems increase. It means that people will be willing to take the risk of either making a false entry or failing to make an entry at some stage or other in the system. As best I can establish, there would need to be a conspiracy between two people. Two operators would have to conspire to allow couriers or other seeking to abuse the system through the system as it now stands.

The Opposition is concerned about information that has come to it about the security of the computer system serving Melbourne and the ease with which it can be penetrated. That has come from reliable sources, and we were informed that we should know that. We were informed not by departmental officers but by people who are related to the Department's operation of those computers. That is a matter of concern because the more we become reliant on computers the more there will be the temptation for people to act fraudulently, to damage, make unauthorised use of or omit data from computers. The Gibbs review examined all of these factors with great care.

I note with interest that the penalities in the legislation appear to be substantial. We will be keeping an eye on this part of the legislation because, whilst the penalties for a person other than an authorised officer appear to be substantial, in today's terms they may not be. The penalty for a person other than an authorised officer tampering with or modifying data is $20,000 or imprisonment for 10 years, or both. That appears to be substantial but the sums of money we are talking about are substantial, too. I remember, as the Minister at the table, the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Holding), would remember, that the computers in Sydney just happened to break down on two occasions at one gateway when Robert Trimbole was passing through. Nobody has ever been blamed for that. The culprit-because I believe it was deliberate-has never been identified. Australia knows what that man and his network did to the lives of young Australians, in Sydney and Melbourne in particular, and it raises the whole Donald Mackay episode again. The computers went down at the very time that man was passing through Customs. That is known to the Government, it is known to the people of Australia and it is known to the press

We are now establishing a process which becomes even more reliant on computers, and the prospect of corrupting them has been identified by the Gibbs review. I am not certain that the Department has seriously considered what it is going into and the prospects of corruption. I have been somewhat assured by the check systems within the proposed computer plan, but again I say that the gains an individual can make are great. The gains will amount to hundreds of thousand of dollars from a small change of information or a failure to register information. The Government has to decide whether it is going to legislate in this area and whether it will carry across into areas such as migration those penalties and that legislation. Something needs to be done at this point because it not only applies to immigration but it will start to apply more and more to the Australian Taxation Office with the tax file number and the possible abuse or manipulation of that system.

I commend to the House the report of the Gibbs committee. I also commend it to those who are concerned about these matters. I refer in particular to some of the findings of the committee. The Scottish Law Commission identified eight different categories of computer misuse and has recommended legislative action in respect of one. I will read to the House the possible abuses that can occur. In this instance they can assist people seeking to profit from drugs brought into Australia where there is a simplified system. Some of the categories of misuse are: erasure or falsification of data or programs so as to obtain a pecuniary or other advantage; obtaining unauthorised access to a computer; eavesdropping on a computer; taking of information without physical removal; unauthorised borrowing of computer disks or tapes; making unauthorised use of computer time or facilities; malicious or reckless corruption or erasure of data or programs; and denial of access to authorised users.

Within the last week we have had serious reports about what hackers have been able to do to computers. If the National Aeronautics and Space Administration program can be penetrated by hackers, nobody can tell me that Australia's Department of Immigration computer cannot be accessed by hackers and similar people. If they cannot get into those systems to adjust, change or manipulate then I am very surprised. What this House needs is the assurance that every possible step will be taken by the Government, starting today. It should not just make the normal commitment it often makes that it will look into it-the mirror response-and that it will make sure the protections are there. We have heard enough of those excuses. They have led to a lot of problems in Australia's immigration program. Australians need the assurance that the improved system will have maximum safeguards. The rewards for people abusing Australia's immigration programs are substantial and every step must be taken to prevent that occurring.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The legislation before the House is not opposed by the Opposition. While it has set out some concerns it has, generally the suggestion is that there is support for the moves that have been initiated. There has been a dramatic growth in international air travel in recent years. It has presented tough problems for many nations. Since 1985 Australia has welcomed more tourists than ever before. The key to our success in managing the increasing international visitors is an integrated computerised visa system called IRIS. IRIS stands for immigration, records and information system. We have found that by the end of this year nearly 90 per cent of all Australian visas will be produced by computer. This computer system is at the very cutting edge of technology in this area. It has been accepted, along with our new computerised passport format, by a number of countries, including the United States, the United Kingdom and Canada, which will be followed to try to internationalise our passport and visa structure within our international framework. It offers for Australia a very efficient system, a system that can be quicker and streamlined and also one that can maintain the integrity of our immigration process.

SPEECH.PARA: As was mentioned by the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), presently at peak times there are difficulties with immigration at our ports of entry. There are large queues. It sometimes takes as long as two hours to process those who have arrived in this country. That can be very annoying and disconcerting and certainly creates an unfavourable impression of Australia-one which, we hope, is soon changed after those people who arrive here have seen what Australia has to offer.

This new visa system and the legislation which amends the 30-year-old Migration Act will bring into effect some of those changes. The legislation allows visas issued overseas to operate as an entry permit if a person is allowed to enter Australia. At present, the visa allows on to travel to Australia, but an entry permit must be granted once one arrives. The front line officer is often a customs officer working as an immigration agent, and in the 60 or 70 seconds that he has to assess the person in front of him there are a large number of things that he must do. Most of them at the moment are done manually. He has to examine the passport of the prospective visitor. He has to look at the details on the entry card that has been filled out by that person. He has to enter some of those details into the computer. Checks are done on alert lists for those who are to be stopped or not allowed to enter the country. He must then translate information on to the passport and he has to stamp the visa.

There are six different stamps that he can use. He can use a stamp which authorises entry for permanent residents; one that authorises entry for permanent resident status after temporary entry; one that allows for a temporary stay as indicated, where employment is not allowed; one that allows for a temporary stay until the date shown where employment is allowed; one that allows for an extension of the original entry period but does not allow employment; and another that authorises extension to the original entry period where employment is allowed. There are a number of decisions that that officer must make in a very short period.

Clearly, the new visa proposal and, when it is in place, automatic scanning of those visas will allow much more time for that officer to make an assessment from the passport as to the identity of the person. Presently he is pressed trying to do all of these other things. The view is taken that he does not have the opportunity to make a visual assessment of the passport and the person in front of him. Indeed, contrary to what the honourable member for Mitchell has said, I believe that this process will reduce the number of errors that are being made. Certainly, scanning and the provision of information on alert lists will allow the same integrity in the system. I believe that the additional time that is allowed the officer will give him the opportunity to make a better assessment on visual grounds. Clearly, that is very important.

One of the reasons that we have introduced this legislation is the belief that it will streamline and simplify the process and also reduce the number of errors that are made. As was pointed out by the honourable member for Mitchell, once that passport is stamped with the permanent entry visa, it cannot be revoked. So some of these decisions are very important.

The legislation also allows for the pre-clearance of direct flights into Australia. This has special implications because, if one looks at the recent history of visitors to this country, one finds that in 1975 half a million people came to Australia as visitors. Nine years later, in 1984, the figure was one million. Four years after that, we are expecting over two million visitors. There has been an exponential increase in the number of people coming to Australia. Indeed, the countries from which tourism is growing most rapidly-New Zealand, the United States and Japan-are all countries in which it would be possible for these pre-clearance issues to be determined. Indeed, it would be possible for the procedures on arrival in Australia to be greatly improved. Certainly, because of the massive impact that our policies have had on tourism in Australia, it is believed that this measure will increase the effectiveness and the efficiency of our dealings with those people who come to Australia as tourists.

I was interested to read in today's Bulletin magazine that new charter flights will arrive in Cairns and Perth. I am sure that those people who go to Perth will enjoy what they find there. Britannia Airways, which is one of the largest charter companies in the United Kingdom, has proposed to operate weekly charter flights from Luton to Perth and Cairns alternately, providing about 5,000 extra seats. This will occur during the peak tourist time in Australia-the summer-when a large number of people, particularly from the United Kingdom, want to come to Australia.

The other aspects of the legislation relate to penalties for misuse of computer facilities. I believe that the honourable member for Mitchell raised one or two valid concerns that would concern all of us in this House. I believe that the legislation will make a difference to the effectiveness and efficiency of processing visitors to Australia at airports and I commend it to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this debate I want to touch very briefly on the detailed proposals contained in the legislation which are designed to improve and accelerate the processing of people who come to Australia. They fall largely into two categories: firstly, visitors to this country who come here for a short period without any intention, or publicised intention anyway, of staying here permanently and then return to their place of permanent residence and, secondly, those who come here as migrants. I was interested to observe in some newspapers today that in reference to the overall question of migration there was a suggestion that current immigration levels may have to be cut dramatically in the 1990s if living standards are to rise and a community backlash is to be avoided. Similarly, they raised the question of the nature of our migration program.

SPEECH.PARA: This year, our bicentennial year, tourism has increased and that has made a wonderful contribution to communities in all parts of Australia. They have benefited from that tourism. I hope that the growth rate continues. However, I recognise that 1988 has provided some particular attractions to tourists from all parts of the world to come to Australia. We should be realistic about the future. I hope that the level of tourism continues to rise, but I suspect that there will be a levelling out as a consequence of 1989 not having the special celebrations in Australia with a whole feast of attractions that have drawn people, like a magnet, to Australia from many parts of the world. Therefore, we face this processing of visitors and those who come to Australia as migrants.

I agree with the idea expressed in the newspapers that we could have to ask ourselves what the migration level should be; therefore, what the level of work that the migrant element of entrants to Australia will provide through the facilities dealt with in this legislation will be. I want to use this opportunity to broaden out that issue and to say, as I have said before, that we need to determine a population strategy for Australia. If we wish to replace our population, I would prefer the replacement to come from those born in Australia. If we want to increase our population, those born here along with those who come as migrants to this country should form the basis of our increasing population.

In other words, I advocate that more children rather than more migrants should be our objective. This is the way in which Australia should be replacing its population. Migration should be relied upon only to the extent that it is in the national interest to increase our population. Before we concern ourselves with population increase, we should decide how we want to achieve population replacement. We should set population objectives not only for next year but also for this and the next century.

The serious problem of Australia's fertility rate was again highlighted in the release recently of the Births, Australia data for 1987. One measure of our population is the fertility rate. This tells us the number of children a thousand women would bear if they experienced the fertility rates of the year shown. A fertility rate of 2.1 is required for the population to replace itself. The annual average total fertility rate for the period 1966 to 1970 was 2.866. This was well above the total fertility rate of 2.1 necessary to replace a population. However, in 1987 the total fertility rate plummeted to 1.851, well below the replacement rate. This is evidence of a birth dearth which Australia is currently experiencing. There are no signs that that birth dearth is about to change.

An alternative measure of population growth is the female net reproduction rate. This indicates the average number of daughters a woman will bear during her lifetime. A female reproduction rate of 1.1 ensures that women are replacing themselves. In 1971 the female net reproduction rate was 1.362, well above the replacement rate. However, in 1987 the female net reproduction rate of 0.883 indicates that there will be fewer women to bear children in the future. There are four factors which determine Australia's population. These are births, immigration, emigration and deaths. At a time when Australians are concerned as much about the number of people migrating to Australia as they are about who is migrating and what they can contribute, we should be paying far more attention to the causes of the dramatic decline in our birth rate.

There are a number of causes for the birth dearth that Australia is experiencing. One of the causes is the hostile treatment of families by the taxation and social security systems of the present Government. The totally inadequate allowance made by these systems for those who maintain children denies many the choice of increasing their family size. Many young families would like another child but they feel they cannot afford it and cannot give an extra child a fair start in life. If young Australians were given the choice they would opt for larger families rather than an increase in the migration program. If young Australians could afford it many would choose to have three children rather than two, two children rather than one. Some call for increased migration to lower the average age of the population and, therefore, overcome some of the difficulties, so these advocates think, of an ageing population.

The answer to an ageing population is not migration but a higher birth rate. Thirty thousand extra births in 1987-88 would have decreased the average age of Australia's population by the same amount as 143 migrants who came in or were expected to come in in 1987-88. The harsh impact of this Government's policies on family incomes is evidenced by the following figures: the family allowance has fallen by 36 per cent in real terms; the dependant spouse rebate for a family with children has fallen by 27 per cent in real terms; average home repayments are now more than $675 per month, a 93 per cent increase over the March 1983 figure. The costs of giving children a fair start in life are not adequately recognised either by the tax system or by the social security system. Many couples would, if given the choice, have more children. However, the present Government has taken this choice away by implementing policies which are unduly harsh on couples wanting to have another child. In my view the Labor Government's promised tax cuts should be directed towards families with children as a priority over tax cuts for all. The decline in Australia's fertility rate will continue unless family equity is restored to the tax system and the price of choosing to have more children is substantially reduced.

This important issue lies behind the question of the need for facilities that are dealt with in this legislation. Dramatic figures are confronting many countries. West Germany, with a population of 60 million today, will, in the view of some experts, have a population of 50 million in the year 2000 if the present fertility rate continues. Again based on the current fertility rate, 100 years from then the population will have declined to 16 million. If that is happening, one can well ask what numbers of people and tourists from not merely West Germany but Western Europe will be visiting Australia in the year 2100. We may well say that this is not going to be a concern for us. I believe it is a concern for those who make policies today that will have an impact on the future destiny of this country.

In conclusion, I want to emphasise what my colleague the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), has drawn to the attention of the House. I believe that we must take advantage of technological advance and speed up the processing of entrance to this country. We must make that simple by using the modern technology of the computer. But it is very important that we ensure that the systems that are in place have adequate security. It is very important that information which is stored in computer databanks in the migration area and which is linked with other areas, as must happen in order to monitor those who might attempt to come into this country illegally or bring in illegal imports, be available only to those who need to know and not to those who think they need to know.

The Government is introducing legislation which is designed, it is argued, to achieve a sufficient level of security. I think this Parliament will have to monitor continuously the effectiveness of those security arrangements. In addition to having adequate security and access to information for only those with a need to know, it is terribly important that the systems that are in place are accurate. Much harm can be done to individual citizens if by accident, or worse still, by any malicious design on the part of someone with access to the computer entry database, inaccurate information about an individual is put onto the database. One is faced with a difficult dilemma. On the one hand we want to ensure that information is available only on a need to know basis. On the other hand, if information is to be accurate, how do we ensure that adequate checks are made? We are concerned here with information which is sometimes sensitive in regard to individuals and in regard to the security of Australia in terms of protecting it from illegal immigration and illegal imports.

How can we be sure that the system is designed in a way that does not put any honest Australian at severe personal risk and disadvantage because for some reason or another inaccurate information has been put on the files and kept secretly because it was necessary that only a close group of individuals have access to it? When that hapless citizen comes into Australia or seeks to leave Australia as a tourist the information is brought up to the embarrassment, disadvantage and prejudice of the citizen. I reinforce what the shadow Minister has said about the importance of making sure that this legislation works effectively not only to achieve its objectives but also to protect Australian citizens from the misuse of information about them and to protect them from the disadvantage and prejudice that could arise consequential upon inaccurate information being recorded against their names.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of the lateness of the hour, I will not expand on the comments I would like to make. I am sure that will please not only you, Mr Deputy Speaker, but also the Minister Assisting the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Holding), who is at the table, and both sides of the House. Nevertheless, this is an important debate and one should say at the outset that we are a very popular country. Many people want to come to Australia to live. Last year about 1.3 million people wanted to come here. We only had an immigration program for about 140,000 people. There are always many people who are very much left out in the cold. If they have relatives here, the relatives feel that they are being disadvantaged.

SPEECH.PARA: The Migration Amendment Bill (No. 2) relates to the new master plan of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. The plan is for the rapid processing of passengers. Passengers on international flights are well aware of the frustrations and delays caused by paperwork in entering foreign countries. These frustrations and delays are compounded in the case of prospective migrants to a country. Some members of this House, including me, have in the distant past experienced as a migrant some of these frustrations and delays. This Bill is aimed at eliminating the frustrations and delays by amending the Act to allow for entry to Australia using one document only in contrast to the present visa and entry permit.

The first amendment will allow the holder of the visa that is in force to travel to this country and, upon entry at a proclaimed airport, enter in accordance with the conditions endorsed on the visa. After arrival at a proclaimed airport, the visa will now have the status of an entry permit. The visa can, however, be cancelled at any time prior to entry as can now be done under section 11b of the Migration Act.

There is no doubt in my mind that by having the conditions of entry and length of stay specified on the visa, and the visa operating as an entry permit, processing time at the point of entry will be greatly reduced. This will help to overcome at least some of the frustrations to which I referred earlier. This proposal will not entirely eliminate the use of entry permit provisions because it is clear that these will still be amended for a number of reasons. For example, the new arrangements are only to operate at proclaimed airports which handle most of the migrant traffic. So they will still be used at those airports not so proclaimed.

The second amendment will take account of persons who apply for change of status, from temporary entry to permanent entry. The third reason is that it will take account of the fact that not all persons travelling to and entering Australia will be holders of the visa in the new form. The second amendment is also welcomed. This allows for prospective migrants to be examined for immigration clearance before departure for Australia on certain designated flights. It is on this matter that I seek guidance from the Minister. Clause 6AA (6) states:

The Minister may, by instrument in writing, declare a specified flight by an aircraft on a specified day between a specified foreign country and Australia to be a pre-cleared flight for the purposes of this section.

Whilst there is a discretion-`the Minister may' not `the Minister shall'-I am wondering what problems could be caused if a Minister declared a flight to be a pre-cleared flight and that flight had engine trouble at the port of departure, causing passengers to be transferred immediately to another flight which has not been pre-cleared. Will there be a process by which the Minister can immediately revoke the instrument in writing and reissue a new instrument in writing? As I said, this is a small matter but it is worth examining. I note in this connection that if the pre-cleared flight lands at another country prior to arrival in Australia, the pre-clearance has no effect and passengers will be processed in the normal way. Other members in this debate have referred to the need for safeguarding the integrity of the electronic records and systems in the Department. I am sure that the Department has taken notice of the Gibbs Review of Commonwealth Criminal Law and will take appropriate measures to see that there are no abuses of the system. There are penalties attached and I feel that the wider community does require these penalties. Whilst they may be regarded as substantial by some people, I think those penalties are very much warranted in this instance. I do not wish to pursue the matter any further. I support the Bill before the House and welcome the fact that it is a positive measure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-A number of points made by the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), dealt with his concerns about some of the provisions of the legislation, although he indicated that the Opposition was basically supporting the thrust of the legislation. Like anyone who knows anything about either immigration or the tourist industry, he would know that the objectives of this legislation are primarily to provide easier access for legitimate tourists coming here. The first consideration the honourable member raised was the question of checking visa decisions. I point out that the decision is checked on two occasions following its issue overseas. The first time it is checked is when the data arrives in Australia, and that is checked against the stop list. That stop list is drawn up after consultation with police forces in the country of origin, so that information is available. Secondly, it is checked when the passenger arrives at the airport. The migration visa can be cancelled at any time prior to the point of entry into Australia and up to exit out of the airport only after entry. The honourable member seemed to imply that if someone fraudulently managed to come in with a resident permit that could not be rectified.
—Under the current system.

—Under the current system any person who obtains a visa by fraud or by misrepresentation can have his resident status nullified by the operation of section 16 of the Act. So a provision exists in the current Act which, on discovery of that kind of activity, provides for that person to face expulsion from Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The offences in the Migration Act relate to unauthorised tampering. There can be unauthorised tampering that is not necessarily associated with fraud or with intention to cause damage. But in considering the seriousness of this offence, one must also consider that tampering, in this sense, is covered not only by the provisions of the Migration Act and this legislation but also by the Crimes Act, which provides very serious penalties for tampering involving fraud with the intention of causing damage.

The provisions in the Migration Amendment Bill do not purport to implement the Gibbs Review of Commonwealth Criminal Law. The recommendations of the Gibbs report are being considered at the moment by the Attorney-General's portfolio. The system is designed to facilitate entry into and exit out of major points of arrival for passengers from specified countries where there will be no interruption in the journey to Australia. Japan will be a major area where these provisions will operate. Frankly, they are directed at facilitating the movement of what are essentially tourists from Japan.

If the honourable gentleman considers the provisions in the light of those comments he will see that the general approach has been thought through. Many of the concerns which were raised by him clearly have been considered by the Department and the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) in the preparation of this legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

(5) Did he express reservations about the legitimacy of the contracts to the President of Denison Mines, Mr J. Fowler, at a meeting in April 1988; if so, what was the nature of his reservations.
(6) Is he able to say whether other Ministers have expressed reservations about the contracts; if so which Ministers have done so and what are the details of their reservations.
(7) Did Mr Fowler state in a letter to him in May 1988 that Denison's new contracts ensure the sale of the total production from Koongarra over a 10 year period.
(8) Is it a fact that in his response to Mr Fowler's letter he stated his belief that the new contracts were a photocopy of an agreement to supply uranium from 1984 to Japanese firms.
(9) Does the agreement referred to in his letter relate to an existing Denison contract; if so, is it tied to production from one of Denison's Canadian mines and not applicable to Koongarra.

(10) In view of the fact that the existence of new contracts worth $1.76 billion were used as a basis for a campaign to change the ALP policy to allow new mines, will he make a public statement on the status of the contracts; if not, why not.

(11) Does he still stand by his position paper issued in April 1988 which states that there is no overwhelming economic justification for changing the 3 named mines policy of the Government; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) A document purporting to be a Denison contract to supply uranium to a Japanese utility was fleetingly shown to me at a meeting with Mr J. D. Fowler on 19 April 1988. I have stated on a number of occasions that I was unsure of the status of the document I was shown. I have advised the company of my views on this matter.
(4) I am aware of reports that Denison Mines has made such claims.
(7) Denison Mines' letter to me of 26 May 1988 was tabled in Parliament on 2 June 1988 so that the matter to which the honourable member is referring is now well known.

(11) The honourable member will be aware that a Review Committee has been established by the National Conference of the ALP to review its uranium policy. The terms of reference of the Committee cover all aspects of the policy including the three named mines policy. The honourable member has accurately described my views on the matter of immediate expansion of the policy.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 27 September 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: In the context of the World Bank review of the valuation of its capital and the issue of the voting power of small member countries, does Australia, as a neighbour of the small Pacific Island countries, support the provision of special shares which will protect the voting power of those countries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: In discussions leading to the recent general capital increase of the World Bank, the Executive Directors noted that voting power in the Bank should reflect, to the maximum extent possible, members' subscriptions to the Bank's capital. The Executive Directors also recognise that dilution of the voting power of small members caused by a general increase in the Bank's capital was an issue requiring further consideration.
Australia recognises the problems of smaller members of the World Bank, particularly of the small Pacific Island countries and shares their concern about possible losses of voting power.

The constituency system of representation in the Bank Board of Directors is a major way in which the smaller or poorer member countries can join with larger or more developed members and have an input to, and influence on, Bank policy at the Board level. Within its constituency Australia has taken a genuine and particular interest in the problems of its Pacific Island member countries and in the problems of the Pacific Island countries in general.

Australia proposed a special additional quota increase for smaller countries, including the small Pacific Island countries, at the time of the Eighth Review of IFM Quotas, in recognition of the fact that quotas based on their small economic size provided inadequate access to the resources of the International Monetary Fund. This point was reflected in the results of that quota review. Australia supports similar treatment for smaller member countries under the current Ninth Review of IMF Quotas.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 11 October 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the miscellaneous sum of $177.2 million listed as estimated receipts in 1988-89, shown in Table 4 of Budget Paper No. 2, include the proceeds from the anticipated sale of defence assets; if so, which assets are involved and what are their budgeted sale values.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The $177.2m estimate of miscellaneous receipts in 1988-89, shown in Table 4 of Budget Paper No. 2, includes sale of larger items of warlike stores, principally Mirage aircraft and Centurion tanks, and it is estimated that proceeds in 1988-89 will total some $43m.

(2) The sale of Defence property and other surplus/obsolete etc. assets do not form part of that sum. They are included under the Department of Administrative Services in Table 2 of Budget Paper No. 2, in the categories of Australian property real assets and surplus assets. The amounts concerned are $25.844m and $26.502m respectively. The former comprises estimated proceeds in 1988-89 from the disposal of:
Australian Government Aircraft Plant, Bankstown, N.S.W.
The $26.502m covers on-going processes of disposal of such items as used vehicles, plant and machinery, C130A spare parts and other similar material.
(3) It would not be in the Commonwealth's interest, at this stage, to make public details of the estimated sale values for individual items.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Social Security: Advertising and Public Relations

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 18 October 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What sum did the Minister's Department outlay in 1987-88 for (a) radio advertising, (b) television advertising, (c) newspaper advertising, (d) public relations and (e) the publication and distribution of journals and magazines.
(2) What is the projected expenditure for each of those categories in 1988-89.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to items 1 (d) and 2 (d) above, the expenditure for ``public relations'' refers to all outlays by the Department for publicity and information initiatives under its National Information Program, other than advertising and publication and distribution of journals and magazines.

The increase in expenditure in 1988-89 is associated with major initiatives announced in the Budget. These are the Jobs, Education and Training (JET) program ($1,500,000), the New-Start program ($630,000), the Child Support Scheme ($1,085,000) and the Family Allowance Supplement scheme ($700,000).
